author: Aakash Gupta
full_text:
Social media creates attention monsters. Instead of the most original thoughts, creators pursue the strongest hooks. One startup wants to change that:

How many layoff posts have you seen lately? Remote work copy-paste jobs?

When the incentive is to seek attention and get likes, behavior follows.

But compare social media to podcasts. The incentives are totally different. With a podcast feed, the creator is directly sending content to fans who have subscribed. So, instead, the incentive is for high QUALITY content.

Is it possible to create the same dynamic for writing? This inspired Chris, Hamish & Jairaj (pictured) to found Substack.

Their mission? â€œMake it simple to start a publication that makes money from subscriptions.â€ If they could create a new market of content, by making it economical for writers, they could create a new media.

So far, itâ€™s been working. The last time we got subscriber numbers from Substack, they had over 1M paying subscribers. That was up ~100% from the year prior. At an average cost of $7 per month, and 10% take rate, thatâ€™s a yearly revenue of $8.4M. Not bad for a company <6 years old.

Itâ€™s working out for its content creators, too. The top 10 writers make over $20M a year combined. Lenny Rachitsky shared he makes more on Substack than he did as a PM at Airbnb. Substack is set to be the next Twitch or YouTube, each of which have 10K+ creators living on them.

What product strategy and positioning has allowed Substack to get to this point?

1. Substack offers true independence for writers.

You own your email list. So, you can always walk away. This is totally different from Twitter, LinkedIn & Facebookâ€™s options.

2. Substack focuses on making the experience easy & simple.

Time to publish is super low. Compared to competitor ConvertKit, Substack offers less customization, analytics, and advertising monetization features. It just makes writing super simple.

3. Substack gets the fundamentals, like SEO & deliverability really right.

My 1 year old Substack crushes my Wordpress blog of 10 years on SEO. Others have measured the same for email deliverability vs other providers. Substack is #1 in the 2 most important areas.

Substack can pursue this focused positioning because it is built for one persona:

Â· Not for social media personalities. They might prefer Twitter or LinkedInâ€™s offerings
Â· Not for techies. They might prefer Wordpress or ConvertKit
Â· For writers who wants to focus on writing.

What can we learn from Substackâ€™s phenomenal product growth?

1. You can create wholly new markets, instead of competing in saturated oneâ€™s.
2. Simpler is better, especially if you have a focused persona.
3. Getting the basics really right, instead of just ok, is a great wedge.

author: Aakash Gupta
full_text:
I thought there'd be consensus on how to monetize AI by now. I was (mostly) wrong.

There's outcome-based pricing (see: Intercom, Crescendo, Chargeflow), credit pricing (see: Salesforce, Lovable), work-based pricing (see: Imagen, EvenUp), hybrid pricing (see: Monday, Clay), and lots more.

The only thing people seem to agree on is that AI credits are bad. But they're also a lifeline to protect against exploding costs. The top 10% of your users might account for 70-80% of your AI costs. (Heck, even MoviePass is selling credits these days.)

I'll be unpacking how to (profitably) add AI to your product with Aakash Gupta from Product Growth and Axel Sooriah from Atlassian Jira Product Discovery.

On the agenda: why AI products fail to make money, the connection between pricing models & profits, the evolving unit economics of AI, and how product teams need to work differently.

Join us for a LinkedIn Live on 12/4. Register here: https://lnkd.in/ebgT38D4

Hope to see you there!

#ai #ad #atlassianpartner

author: Adam Robinson
full_text:
Kyle Poyar just analyzed new data from 6,525 SaaS startups and it's WILD. Only 3.3% reach $1 million ARR in less than a year from first revenue. And just 1-in-1000 reach $10 million in less than a year!!

Thats not what you'd think if you only listen to VCs on Twitter.

You'd think if you're not at $100M ARR in 6 months you might as well give up.

Kyle partnered with ChartMogul and dug into their dataset on subscription metrics going back 10+ years and here's what he found: 

For startups that reach $1M ARR, it usually takes 2-5 years from monetization. 

1. Only 3.3% of startups reach $1 million in under 1 year
2. 13.4% reach $1 million in under 3 years
3. 25.1% reach that figure within 5 years

You can map yourself onto the curve below (see graphic). 

It takes time to find PMF and move from founder-led sales to repeatable growth. And premature scaling can kill a great business. 

That's why many of the best companies started slow:

- Lovable spent 18 months building before their breakthrough success
- Clay grinded for 6 years before seeing revenue traction
- Bolt spent 7 years to get to $700k ARR before their new product exploded

Tomorrow Kyle (Founder of Growth Unhinged) is joining me on Unf*ck My Startup LIVE to share the realistic playbook for sustainable startup growth.

If you're a founder feeling discouraged by hyper-growth narratives, this session will provide the data-driven clarity and actionable strategies you need to build a long-term, successful startup.

Join us here (3pm ET): https://lnkd.in/gs-Yyc4p

author: Adam Robinson
full_text:
Adam Robinson has bootstrapped RB2B to $5.5M+ ARR w/ only 3 people (ğŸ¤¯). He just ran a wild experiment to replace RB2B's sales-assist team with a $99 per month AI avatar. Here's what happened next.

First off, very few are suggesting AI as a replacement for salespeople. Remember, for example, how Salesforce said theyâ€™re actually hiring 2,000 more salespeople to sell AI?

Well, Adam is an outlier. He's bootstrapped RB2B to date & is on a mission to hit $10M ARR as profitably as humanly possible.

RB2B's sales-assist team was supposed to help customers who weren't ready to buy via self-serve. But there was no convincing data that sales-assist was actually incremental. So Adam wanted to see if AI could do the job instead.

Four weeks into replacing a human sales-assist rep with the AI avatar, RB2Bâ€™s metrics lookâ€¦ almost identical. And the AI avatar had 1,683 (!) conversations in its first 22 days including:
 - 304 demo requests
 - 98 SOC2 docs
 - 16 custom pricing quotes

About 10% of the conversations captured an email. 70% of folks who talked to the avatar said the experience was positive. Almost none of the answers were flat-out wrong.

You'll want to read the full story in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/epFMtymA

Iâ€™m not sure AI is ready to be aÂ replacementÂ for sales. But it can helpÂ augmentÂ the sales motion, filling the gaps left behind between fully self-service versus fully sales-managed. 

#ai #genai #sales

author: Adam Tank
full_text:
I spent over $1,000 on an online writing course.

Here's why investing in writing is the best professional career move you can makeğŸ‘‡ğŸ½  

1ï¸âƒ£ Writing is the fastest way to build a professional brand

- My water & tech focused newsletter has gone from 0 -> 3,663 subscribers in just over 12 months

- Customers, partners, and connections all appreciate learning about you and your interests outside of what your company does

- Easy way to stay top of mind with people you don't often connect with.

2ï¸âƒ£ You can meet INCREDIBLE people from all over the world, many who become close friends and co-workers

- Writing online gives you 24/7 opportunities to find like minded people in places you may never visit in person. My life would be nowhere near as interesting without fellow writers like Cam, Robbie, Will, Stephen, Amanda, Karena, Florian, Louie, John, and Jim in it.

3ï¸âƒ£ Refining your thinking leads to better business outcomes

- Your ability to clearly and concisely convey messages in writing, especially in a remote world, directly impacts your ability to be successful at work.

- It's always nice to avoid an extra meeting when it can be taken care of in an e-mail or memo.

If you're interested in learning where to start, the team at Write of Passage is putting on a series of free webinars next month that talk about how to start writing online.  

Link in the first comment below!

author: Adam Tornhill
full_text:
Bad code is bad only if you need to change it. If it looks bad, but is stable, it doesnâ€™t pose any concerns.

This might seem trivial, but it has deep implications. The main one is that you should focus your quality work on ğ—µğ—¼ğ˜ğ˜€ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜ğ˜€ (cit. Adam Tornhill): the parts of your codebase that are frequently subject to change.

As humans we are bad at judging this intuitively, so a lot of work on tech debt is simply misguided: it either happens on badâ€”but stableâ€”code, or on areas that are active but already in relatively good shape.

This is also hard to evaluate because activity distribution is extremely skewed: in most codebases, ~5% of the code gets 90% of the activity.

This reminds me of something from my startup days.

During an M&A conversation, the buyerâ€™s consulting firm ran a technical due diligence. They found several areas of poor quality codeâ€”as we expected. In fact, over time we had doubled down on specific parts of the product we cared about, while phasing out others. The latter stayed experimental: less testing, more duplication, etc.

What I didnâ€™t expect was how hard this proved to be to argue. We pointed to the strategic parts we were proud of, but they weighted the sketchy marginal code as an equal part of the whole.

In other words, the ğ—³ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—¾ğ˜‚ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ˜† ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ—°ğ—µğ—®ğ—»ğ—´ğ—² wasnâ€™t considered.

Eventually the M&A failed for a variety of reasons. This was not explicitly mentioned as a blocker, but I always suspected it contributed.

I had a chat with Adam a few months ago that influenced a lot of how I think about this topic. I wrote an article from it, which I am linking in the comments ğŸ‘‡

author: Addy Osmani
full_text:
Why does "vibe coding" not lead to anything productive, for the most part? A great person to answer is Addy Osmani: he has been working on Chrome for 10+ years, and has just published his new book: Beyond Vibe Coding.

One point Addy makes is that as software engineers, we should do a lot more AI-assisted software engineering and probably less vibe coding. But these tools are working, and they are changing how development is done in places like Google Chrome's dev team, and beyond.

Watch or listen:

â€¢ YouTube: https://lnkd.in/eDhMXq-C 

â€¢ Spotify: https://lnkd.in/e_BVsnsb 

â€¢ Apple: https://lnkd.in/eE7geiHd 

Brought to you by:

â€¢â  Statsig â  â€” â  The unified platform for flags, analytics, experiments, and more. https://lnkd.in/eQkXqjMZ 

â€¢â  Linear â€“ The system for modern product development. https://lnkd.in/egxywckg

An interesting quote from this episode from Addy:

â€œI haveÂ more recently been focusing on the idea of spec-driven development, having a very clear plan of what it is that I want to build. 

There are definitely places where I still vibe code. If itâ€™s for a personal tool, something throw away, in the old days, if an engineer or a PM had an idea, maybe we would put together a quick mock, maybe we would put together a wireframe or a sketch or something like that. Perhaps work with UX to come up with something a little bit more polished.

I also think that tests are great. And if you are open to tests, it can be a great way of de-risking your use of LLMs and coding. Because sometimes, even if youâ€™re using state-of-the-art models, you can end up in a situation where maybe the code looks more convoluted than you would expect."

author: Advith Chelikani
full_text:
I need to address something.

Last week this WSJ article about us went viral.

A lot of opinions lacking context about us as a company and people spread.

Here are important points I want to clarify:

1 - There are multiple founders that were mentioned in this article. What other founders said about their own companies does not apply to us.

2 - This article was about FOUNDERS, not employees. The title is "AI Startup Founders Tout a Winning Formula..." At Pylon, the founders (Advith, Robert, me) work insane hours. I've made posts about this and broken down the math on how there are months of non-stop 92 hrs work weeks. It's my belief that founders should work exceptionally hard. Why would anyone ever join your team if the leaders of the company aren't putting in everything to help make the company succeed? At the same time, our expectations for the general team are completely different.

3 - We've never mentioned "996" culture or asked our team to come in on weekends. Some people do end up coming in on Sunday but we've never encouraged it, prescribed it, or mentioned it as an expectation during our interview process.

4 - A while back we had made a post about how we as founders lived in the office when we first started the company. For some reason people think non-founders did too. That is false.

5 - The "No Fun" part is incorrect (at least for us). Our initial motivation for starting a company was for fun and adventure. But... what fun looks like for us is quite different than what fun is for others. We find the process of company building to be incredibly fun, meaning our work is fun.

6 - I have no problem with work-life balance. Our team should definitely have a life outside of work. You should decide what type of lifestyle you're excited about and go for it. Once again, this article was about founders, not employees (at least for Pylon). For founders, my personal opinion is that building a venture-scale business requires going all-in.

author: Advith Chelikani
full_text:
We raised Pylon's $31M Series B in 7 days.

We didn't need the money.

And we weren't fundraising.

We were focused on supporting customers, building product, and selling.

But investors expressed interest.

...and word spread fast ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥

Within 7 days we signed a term sheet with a16z and Bain Capital Ventures.


-- Company --

- Pylon was 2 years and 7 months old
- We had 4.5 years of runway.
- We had only burned $3M of $20.3M previously raised
- Team was 37 people


-- Exact Timeline --

During the weeks leading up to the raise, I started accepting requests for coffee chats at Pylon. I'd chat with investors for 30m where I'd talk about Pylon, hear about their firm, and then talk about our fundraising plans. I'd share "we're not fundraising but if someone were to give us $30M at $XXXM valuation, we'd be interested".   

July 4th - We decide we're going to raise, quickly
July 4th-10th - Many investor conversations
July 10th, 8AM - Partner presentation for BCV
July 10th, 1PM - Verbal offer from BCV
July 11th, 10AM - Partner presentation for a16z
July 11th, 11AM - Verbal offer from a16z
July 11th, 11PM - Term sheet signed


-- Fundraising History --

Jan 2023 - Pre-Seed from Y Combinator ($125K raised, $1.79M val) 
Mar 2023 - Seed led by General Catalyst ($3.2M raised, $20M val)
July 2024 - Series A led by a16z ($17M raised, $90M val)
July 2025 - Series B led by BCV & a16z ($31M raised, ğŸ¤« val)

This brought total raised to $51M.


-- Notes --

- Why raise? a) signaling to prospects, customers, and employees and b) there's downside to not raising after getting inbound interest. We asked ourselves "would we get better terms in 6 months when we expected to raise?" and the answer was "no". Delaying the raise introduced risk if we started to perform worse over the coming months or if market conditions worsened.

- Why only $31M? We didn't need the money and wanted to minimize dilution. 

- We decided to run our Series B process the same way we ran our Series A process: a) build a great company then b) let investors come to you. If you don't need money you have leverage. In comments see one year ago how we raised our previous two rounds.

- Compared to early stage investors (up to Series B), growth stage investors (Series B+) are very different. Early stage think more about potential while growth funds are more focused on actuals and numbers. Part of what we loved about BCV and continuing to work with a16z is that they were able to do bothÂ well.


ğŸ¥: Advith, Robert, and me ubering over to BCV's office. We didn't need to prepare much for the presentation itself. The work that mattered (building the company) had already been done. Fundraising meant cashing that hard work in.


-- What is Pylon? --

We're building the first support platform purpose-built for B2B.

People call us the Zendesk killers.

Yes, it's filled with useful AI.

Check us out ğŸ‘‡ï¸ 
usepylon.com

author: Advith Chelikani
full_text:
Welcome to the Pylon office ğŸ‘‹

We had originally toured the place as a joke. We were 13 people looking at an office that could fit 100 (!). But the more we joked about it, the more excited we got.

This was THE iconic UserTesting / Postmates / AMCO building right across from the Caltrain station.

It was an office that Advith, Robert, and I had regularly walked by for the past 6 years.

It was right across from the Caltrain station which meant that future employees in South Bay could easily commute up.

And most importantly it felt like a place that our team would be really excited to work out of.

So as we were outgrowing our live/work loft a few blocks away and looking for a new home for Pylon, we quickly negotiated a 3 year lease and signed. 

In the last 9 months since moving in, the team has 2.4x'd to 32 employees, and we're on track to fill it up by the end of the lease.

It was 100% the right decision.


-- Notes --

- Our previous office was 1.9k sqft and we grew in it until 13 people. We infamously both lived and worked out of that office before it got so crowded that our founding AE Sergio had his desk 2 ft away from Advith's mattress

- Our new/current office is 6.97x the size (13,256 sqft)

- If you want to get people excited about working in-person in an office you need to make it a nice place to come into. We were optimizing for that

- We also felt that being close to the Caltrain would allow us to attract a larger in-person team from the rest of the peninsula

- Because we sell to a lot of tech companies, the iconic painted logo on the outside of the building was also a major plus for us. We effectively got two giant billboards on the sides of our building included in our lease price. And there's heavy foot traffic since we're right across from the Caltrain, it's on the Waymo route, and there's a bike path that goes right past it

- I'm believe we're trendsetting with this video. I'm going to bet that by mid-next week we'll see multiple other startups start doing office tours ğŸ˜‚

author: Advith Chelikani
full_text:
Advith and Robert are the best co-founders I could ask for.

Part of what's made our relationship great is we're aligned on some of the most important high level details of the company:

WHAT - Build a generational company ($10B in 10 years)
HOW - Grindy, low-ego, best idea wins, hire similar people
WHY - Building a startup is the most exciting way to spend time 

This alignment has made decision making incredibly easy.

-- 

Before starting Pylon we were friends.

1/ Advith and Robert met first at Caltech where they were both studying computer science, organizing HackTech (Caltech's hackathon), and competing at puzzle hunts together.

2/ I met Advith through the Kleiner Perkins fellowship (a program for college students who are interested in building startups). Robert had gone through the same program just one year earlier.

3/ After graduation Advith and I lived together for 3 years and became incredibly close.

4/ During the pandemic Advith later started living with Robert and started exploring startup ideas together. I had already been in pivot hell working with others.

4/ A year later Advith, Robert, and I came together and joined forces, and lived together.

--

We're still incredibly close and I rarely see others with similar amounts of trust and closeness.

author: Advith Chelikani
full_text:
Having FUN at work is underrated.

It's a big reason why people join Pylon.

And I do mean the work itself being fun, not fake-work.

Fun at work can mean....
- building cool stuff
- working with smart people
- debating ideas
- learning a lot
- moving really fast

While anti-fun is...
- useless meetings
- playing politics
- doing throwaway work
- micro-managers
- fixing tech debt
- peers motivated by ego or status

--

Fun is actually the core reason Advith, Robert, and I started Pylon.

Don't get me wrong, we love our product and the customer support category we're in... 

But honestly, we could've worked on anything and had fun doing it.

For us the company building, people, product development, and adventure are what make it fun.  

It's almost like startups are the ultimate, hard-mode board game, where the goal is build a $10B public company in < 10 years.

--

If you want to play STARTUP with us checkout our jobs page! 

We currently have 3 open roles (all in SF):
1/ Software Engineer(s)
2/ Account Executive(s) 
3/ Product Support Engineer(s)

https://lnkd.in/gmcYnSnd

author: Ajay Krishnamurthy
full_text:
INTRODUCING AI REPORTS [BIG]

Support leaders don't have time to read every ticket.

Now, AI summarizes daily/weekly/monthly customer interactions for you. 

You can make reports for whatever you want...

"Provide a high-level summary of support activity for the week."

"Which types of tickets take us the longest to reply to?"

"Give me an executive summary of customer health for the month. Include key wins, challenges, and areas of concern."

"List any tickets that weren't closed properly this week."

"What are common issues that keep coming up across customers?"

"Summarize any notable escalations or high-priority issues that required special attention."

"Highlight top moments where customers complimented our team."

"List the top 5 most common issue categories with a brief description of trends or patterns observed."

...and they automatically get sent to you in Slack. 

AI reports synthesize information across call recordings, support tickets, CRM data, and any other customer data you have in Pylon.  

Internally, we're even using them across non-support teams (sales, marketing, product) to get customer insights. 

This is a huge release and we can't wait to see what teams build.


â€”

Shoutout to Ajay Krishnamurthy and Ben S. who absolutely crushed this project.

Link to docs in the comments ğŸ‘‡ï¸

author: Alan Stein
full_text:
Landing an engineering job without the right tools is like assembling IKEA furniture without an instruction guide.

It's already hard enough with the guide, now try removing it.

Recently, I noticed a big uptick in messages either:
1. Telling me they're looking for a job
2. Asking for advice about landing one
3. Asking for referrals

In short, it seems tough out there right now.

That's why tonight, me and ex-Google/Meta executive Alan Stein are teaming up for an event to answer all your questions and get you the help you need.

Alan will share the 6-step process that's gotten hundreds of engineers jobs at top tech companies, and we'll both be there for plenty of Q&A.

Join us and 150+ engineers tonight at 5PT/8ET: https://lnkd.in/ekRQh8d8

full_text:
(R)evolution is here, we like it or not.


During the last Infoshare 2025 Conference Jordan Cutler showed this slide: The engineering team structure we've known for years is changing, as we speak. Because AI and other tools / tech is more and more equipped in doing things for us, the skillset vs engineering role is shifting. 

ğŸ‘‰ Junior is becoming a Mid
ğŸ‘‰ Mid is becoming a Senior
ğŸ‘‰ Senior transforming into Staff Engineer (with a part of completely different skills)

I wanted to come back to it because we had a great conversation with Ari Block during our Leman Tech Leadership Podcast recording session. We've discussed how there are big predictions about engineering teams in overall. Interesting and necessary trend to follow, and build risk management around it. So we take care of our teams and businesses as well.

Do you see this transformation as well? Let's see what's already visible!

author: Allison Saxon
full_text:
FOLLOW FRIDAY - you remember that? From the early days of Twitter.

I'm bringing it back. I just decided.

Some people for you to follow:

1. Allison Saxon - she runs events on our team at Exit Five; she is responsible for Drive, Marketing Leadership Retreat, and all of our workshops, meet-ups and dinners around the U.S. this year.

2. Anthony Blatner - he runs Speedwork, a LinkedIn Ads agency. We met through Exit Five, and Anthony and his team have been running our LinkedIn ads for the last year and we have seen insane results through the combination of organic + Thought Leader ads.

3. Ding Zheng - he runs Eventshark, a great video production company for B2B. We became friends through work and our love of music and fitness. Now he's texting me from China sending verses at 3 AM or giving me a random idea. Good people, and since 2024 he's become so much more than "the sales rapper."

4. Jess Cook - recently promoted to VP of Marketing at Vector, OG Exit Five member, and we had a great podcast session yesterday. I got to ask Jess about how they are doing influencer marketing, the ROI of having a podcast at work, and her path from content marketer to VP Marketing. Plus some talk about kids and work and managing it all.

5. Louis Grenier - cancer survivor and marketing genius; reminded me why I love marketing in the first place this week after recording a podcast on how to stand out. And yes, you can even stand out in B2B.

6. Erik Jacobson - founder of Hatch (video/podcast production company), and has been my podcast partner for the last ... five years maybe? Yes podcasting "works" yes even in B2B yes you don't need a huge audience to feel something from this. This guy has given me so much wisdom on strategy here, and his company has helped run my podcast for years and i would have quit three times without them. Also just a good person, which means the world.

Those are just some of the people on my mind this week (just looking back at my calendar on this Friday morning and trying to see where the week went)

Feel free to continue this in the comments. I'm always looking for new people to follow here, who had your attention this week?

Join me and the Exit Five team + hundreds of people who: 

- Work in B2B marketing like you do
- But are also cool people in real life like you are too - with hobbies, interests, families (imagine that!)

The whole thing is: come to learn about marketing and sharpen your skills (we think marketing is a craft) but stay because the people are fun to hang out with too, and we need a bit more connection in real life.

It's going to be great. We continue to put more into this event every year and it will continue to pay off.

author: Amos Bar-Joseph
full_text:
GTM Engineers went from non-existent to the most talked about role of 2025. OpenAI, Ramp, Webflow & more are hiring for it. But it turns out itâ€™s not as popular as it seems.

GTM engineers are meant to bring technology and automation to solve hard GTM problems (of which there are many!). I think of GTM engineers as people who can both identify friction points across the buying journey (ICP targeting, ICP pipeline, conversion, CAC, etc.) and then quickly run automated, 1:many experiments to eliminate them.

Itâ€™s essentially a growth hire, but focused on a primarily sales-led or sales-assisted funnel rather than a product-led one.

Despite the buzz, I havenâ€™t met many actual GTM engineers yet. There really arenâ€™t a lot of software companies hiring for GTM engineers, either.

Here's what the data shows (see it for yourself here: https://lnkd.in/ezfJ_JJf)

1. There were 128 GTM Engineer jobs posted in the last 3 months. 

Sounds like a lot, but that's 1 for every 14 in RevOps. 1 for every 35 in SalesOps. And 1 for every 92 SDRs (!) -- which nobody is calling a hot job.

2. 45% of those with a GTM engineer title are actually agencies or consultants (shoutout to Amos Bar-Joseph). 

3. The roleâ€™s popularity is a far cry from other AI-native jobs like AI engineers, prompt engineers or automation engineers. In fact, it barely registers in Google Trends.

---

Before hiring a GTM engineer, Iâ€™d suggest you:

 - Start with an agency or consultant to prove value with a specific use case
 - Redeploy someone internally who has the business context paired with the system knowledge
 - Upskill the existing GTM team and equip them with next-gen tooling
 - Hire a great Head of RevOps (or RevTech) and fully resource their team

Don't miss the full story in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/ezfJ_JJf

Then, let me know what you think. Is GTM engineering online hype or is it still the next hot job?

#gtmengineer #ai #marketing

author: Anders Krohn
full_text:
Gun to my head, if I had to build an AI GTM product, hereâ€™s what I would doâ€¦

First off hereâ€™s what I wouldnâ€™t do:
1. No all in one tool, bad idea.
2. 100% no audio recording tools, unless itâ€™s in person like limitless.ai
3. No signals
4. Nothing that involves email or email infra
5. Nothing that tries to write messages
6. No CRM
7. Never lead gen

Hereâ€™s what I would do:
1. A VERY thoughtful CRM cleaner (h/t Anders Krohn).
2. ZoomInfo for you databases.
3. A SDR / AE monitoring tool tied to systems workflow (so monitor their screens and improve their workflows).
4. Message testing framework even virtual responders based on call transcripts.
5. A call transcript connector tool that just constantly extracts the necessary context on your customers for the LLMs.

These are just a few ideas.

But for the love of god, stop building the single app to try and do all GTM. 

Itâ€™s silly and wonâ€™t work.

author: Anish Kachinthaya
full_text:
Introducing... ğŸ” AI Knowledge Assistants ğŸ”

Maintaining your help center is notoriously hard. It contains a LOT of content, your product is constantly changing, and new team members don't have context into your existing content. 

Now, AI Knowledge Assistants will automatically keep your articles up to date. 

Here's how it works...

1/ AI continuously scans your support interactions to identify missing or outdated topics in your knowledge base.

2/ If a topic is missing, AI drafts a brand new article based on how you've responded to past customer issues.

3/ If a topic needs an update, AI drafts edits to an existing article and you can review before publishing.

Instead of knowledge base hell, you now have a help center that writes itself. 


â€”

Shoutout to Anish Kachinthaya for absolutely crushing this project (and for giving a great explanation of how it works).

author: Ankit Sobti
full_text:
We are entering the age of AI-first APIs ğŸ¤–

As engineers, we've built applications for different *consumers* throughout the decades. First for humans (visual interfaces), then for other software (APIs), and now for AI â€” which is neither human nor traditional software.

AI agents are a weird middle ground: they make API calls like software, but they can also figure out how to use tools, make sense of unstructured data, and make unpredictable mistakes â€” more like humans.

So today I published a long piece together with Ankit Sobti, CTO of Postman, exploring how all of this changes API design. Here are some key principles:

â†³ ğŸŒŠ ğ—œğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—³ğ—®ğ—°ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—¼ğ—¹ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—®ğ—´ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—» â€” From human-first UIs to API-first for deterministic software, we're now entering the AI-first era where consumers have both machine precision and human-like understanding.

â†³ ğŸ’° ğ—§ğ—¼ğ—¸ğ—²ğ—» ğ—²ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—¶ğ—°ğ˜€ ğ—°ğ—µğ—®ğ—»ğ—´ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜†ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ â€” Every byte costs money when processed by LLMs, creating new design tradeoffs between verbosity and clarity that didn't exist before.

â†³ â±ï¸ ğ—Ÿğ—®ğ˜ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ˜† ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—±ğ˜€ ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—³ğ—³ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¹ğ˜† â€” AI's multi-second processing times force us to rethink API orchestration, favoring batching, predictive responses, and streaming.

â†³ ğŸ”„ ğ—¦ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—³-ğ—µğ—²ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¯ğ—²ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² â€” AI consumers can retry creatively and work around errors, but only if APIs provide rich, actionable error information.

â†³ ğŸ“š ğ——ğ—¼ğ—°ğ˜€ ğ—¯ğ—²ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—² ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ â€” Your docs aren't just guides anymore; they directly shape production behavior at scale, requiring the same rigor as code.

We also covered MCP â€” the emerging standard for AI-API connections â€” and looked ahead to agent-to-agent communication protocols like Google's A2A.

A lot of this may look like speculation, but this is all very near future, which is being shaped right now in front of us. And this future belongs to systems that can think, adapt, and collaborate. Time to start building them!

Full article (free!) in the comments!

author: Anna Shipman
full_text:
How do you translate *engineering* to executives?

Today we published a fantastic guest article by Anna Shipman, CTO at Kooth Digital Health, on something every engineer struggles with: getting buy-in from executives.

Anna brilliantly unpacks this from first principlesâ€”explaining how execs think, what they care about, and why the gap existsâ€”and then provides a ton of practical advice on how to bridge it!

The core insight, to me, is that you should think at executives like your *users*. You need to understand their needs, constraints, and context â€” just like you would for any product you build.

Here are the three top takeaways I learned from Anna:

â†³ ğŸ¯ ğ—¢ğ—½ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—ºğ—¶ğ˜‡ğ—² ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—²ğ˜…ğ—²ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜€ â€” execs think horizontally across the business, optimizing for company-wide impact, so tie your proposals to broad business outcomes. Show how you'll measure impact, always include the "so what," and explain technical concepts clearly.

â†³ ğŸ“‹ ğ—•ğ—¼ğ˜ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—º ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—² ğ˜‚ğ—½ ğ—³ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ â€” executives have broader spans of responsibility, meaning less time per area. Lead with a short executive summary stating what decision you need and why. Only include what's crucial for decision-making, and anticipate the questions they'll ask: cost, ROI, alternatives, timing, risks, and how you'll measure success.

â†³ ğŸ”€ ğ—•ğ—² ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—¼ğ˜„ğ—» ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜€ğ—¹ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—¹ğ—®ğ˜†ğ—²ğ—¿ â€” don't expect your CTO or other execs to translate technical details into business language. Do that work yourself by connecting engineering work to the business outcomes they care about.

Anna's article is packed with concrete examples you can use immediately. It's one of those pieces that can genuinely level up your career.

Full article in the comments! ğŸ‘‡

author: Annie Duke
full_text:
How can we make good decisions under uncertainty? ğŸ²

This is the question I explored with Annie Duke, former world-class poker player, decision science expert, and author of the bestseller book "Thinking in Bets"

Annie has lived at the intersection of cognitive psychology and high-stakes poker for 20+ years, and developed unique insights into how we can make better decisions when the outcome is unclear.

Here are a few takeaways from our chat:

â†³ ğŸ¯ ğ—¥ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—® ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—½ â€” judging decisions by their outcomes rather than their process is dangerous. A good decision can have a bad outcome due to luck, and vice versa.

â†³ âš¡ ğ—–ğ—µğ—®ğ˜€ğ—² ğ˜€ğ—µğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜ ğ—³ğ—²ğ—²ğ—±ğ—¯ğ—®ğ—°ğ—¸ ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—½ğ˜€ â€” even in ventures that take years to mature, there are always early signals. Identify what's "necessary but not sufficient" and track those milestones.

â†³ ğŸ”¢ ğ—¤ğ˜‚ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—³ğ˜† ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—¾ğ˜‚ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ â€” when someone says "this is a great market," ask them to rate it 1-10. This reveals hidden disagreements and forces precision.

â†³ ğŸ¤ ğ—šğ—®ğ˜ğ—µğ—²ğ—¿ ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—½ ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—±ğ—²ğ—½ğ—²ğ—»ğ—±ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¹ğ˜† â€” anchoring bias and groupthink kill good decisions. Always collect opinions separately before discussing them together.

â†³ ğŸ›‘ ğ—£ğ—¿ğ—²-ğ—±ğ—²ğ—³ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—² ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¹ ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—® â€” we're terrible at quitting when we should. Write down clear signals that would make you stop, before you start. A marathon runner with a broken leg isn't heroicâ€”they're making a bad decision.

You can watch the full episode here:

â€¢ Substack: https://lnkd.in/dFhUWez7
â€¢ Youtube: https://lnkd.in/d5kSmX8W

author: Anton Zaides
full_text:
Imagine you are checking some dashboards and notice new signups dropped by 50%. What do you do?

Most people will start with:
âŒ â€œI think I know whatâ€™s happening. The signup page might be down again; didnâ€™t that happen last quarter? Or it could be related to that iOS update we shipped. But itâ€™s also December, and it could just be a weak time for signups. Maybe it will go away on its ownâ€¦â€

Whatâ€™s the problem with this? 

ğ—§ğ—µğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ˜€ğ—²ğ˜ ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—»ğ—±ğ—¼ğ—º ğ—µğ˜†ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜ğ—µğ—²ğ˜€ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—±ğ—¼ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—»â€™ğ˜ ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—® ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¿ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¹ğ˜† ğ—²ğ˜…ğ—µğ—®ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—². 

If you get lucky, you find the problem; but if youâ€™re not lucky, you might spend the entire day chasing down dead ends.

And if you donâ€™t finish the investigation quickly, youâ€™ll likely ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¿ğ˜ ğ—´ğ—¼ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¶ğ—» ğ—°ğ—¶ğ—¿ğ—°ğ—¹ğ—²ğ˜€ since you lose track of what you already looked into.

ğŸ¯ The solution: Break the problem into an issue tree that follows the MECE principle.

------------------------------------

Yeah, I also have framework fatigue. Too many acronyms to remember, and most of them are useless in the day-to-day. 

Last week, Jordan's and Torsten's article made me reconsider. 

I promise you, it's quite genius:
https://lnkd.in/dRgTyAJp

ğ˜ğ˜¯ ğ˜µğ˜©ğ˜¦ ğ˜±ğ˜°ğ˜´ğ˜µ, ğ˜'ğ˜® ğ˜¥ğ˜ªğ˜³ğ˜¦ğ˜¤ğ˜µğ˜­ğ˜º ğ˜²ğ˜¶ğ˜°ğ˜µğ˜ªğ˜¯ğ˜¨ 1 ğ˜°ğ˜¶ğ˜µ ğ˜°ğ˜§ 5 ğ˜¦ğ˜¹ğ˜¢ğ˜®ğ˜±ğ˜­ğ˜¦ğ˜´ ğ˜§ğ˜³ğ˜°ğ˜® ğ˜µğ˜©ğ˜¦ ğ˜¢ğ˜³ğ˜µğ˜ªğ˜¤ğ˜­ğ˜¦. ğ˜ˆğ˜­ğ˜­ ğ˜¤ğ˜³ğ˜¦ğ˜¥ğ˜ªğ˜µ ğ˜µğ˜° ğ˜‘ğ˜°ğ˜³ğ˜¥ğ˜¢ğ˜¯ ğ˜¢ğ˜¯ğ˜¥ ğ˜›ğ˜°ğ˜³ğ˜´ğ˜µğ˜¦ğ˜¯!

------------------------------------

ğ— ğ—˜ğ—–ğ—˜ = ğ— utually ğ—˜xclusive and ğ—–ollectively ğ—˜xhaustive.

You break down the problem into non-overlapping segments, that cover ğ—”ğ—Ÿğ—Ÿ ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—¼ğ—½ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€. 

You start by dividing the possible root causes into high-level groups. Then, you break these groups down further, ensuring every possibility is captured and none of the buckets overlap.

âœ… After: â€œThere are ğ˜ğ˜„ğ—¼ ğ—¼ğ—½ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ for what could be happening: Either something is broken, or the data only makes it look like thereâ€™s a problem. If somethingâ€™s broken, it could be isolated to a specific OS, or affect all devices. And the issue could be at any of the three steps of the signup process, so weâ€™ll check them one by one.â€

Donâ€™t rely on luck to find the root cause. The MECE framework gives you a structure that ensures you will find it, and makes it easy to:

1. get everyone on the same page on whatâ€™s being investigated.
2. divide the work between different people or teams.

Another benefit of using this structure is that since you have an overview of all possible things you need to check, you can prioritize what to investigate first.

For example, you can see that checking for a data issue or seasonality first can potentially save you a lengthy investigation.

------------------------------------

In the article, Jordan and Torsten also covered:
1. Acing interviews 
2. Giving investigation updates
3. Explaining something to your colleagues
4. Deciding what to work on

author: Anton Zaides
full_text:
Made it on stage and back alive!

Presenting to over 700 people was both amazing and nerve-wracking.

I spoke about how to 10x your productivity using AI as an engineer, and in short, it's more about WHEN you use it rather than HOW you use it.

You need to understand what AI excels at and what it struggles with. For example, AI will struggle with:

âŒ Writing a design doc from scratch (because it doesn't know about your systems)
âŒ Creating a presentation deck for you (because it can't tell stories from your perspective)
âŒ Fixing a bug across multiple systems (because it can't fit that in the context window)

It MIGHT be good at these things later, once AI knows us and all the context we have in our brain more, but right now, it isn't. 

Instead, use AI either when context is less relevant, or when you can quickly give AI the context it needs to do a good job. Here are a few examples:

â€¢ One-off scripts -> It just needs to solve a small problem and save you time from writing the code manually
â€¢ Diagramming -> It's great at taking text and transforming it into structure. Get LLMs to convert your paragraphs into mermaid diagrams, then paste those diagrams into your docs
â€¢ Answering questions tuned to you -> My Googling has gone down 90% since AI. I always ask AI the question unless if recency matters, since my answer will get tuned specifically for me.

These are just 3 of the 10+ examples I gave in the talk. To access the slides, head to my profile and check my media under the Pinterest experience!

And finally, a big shout out to the fellow creators there that supported me up there (and helped calm my nerves)-- Anton Zaides, MichaÅ‚ Poczwardowski , Gregor Ojstersek , Jade Wilson , Aleksandra LemaÅ„ska ğŸ™ and thank you to to my team and org (Web Platform, Client Foundations, Core Foundations) for supporting me on the deck and process. Y'all are the best!

author: Antonia Scheidel
full_text:
How do you create good, sustainable, automated processes for your team?

This is pretty much the holy grail of engineering management, and this week we explored it on the podcast with Antonia Scheidel.

Antonia is Director of Engineering at Duolingo, where she rose through the ranks starting as an intern 12 years ago. She's an expert at designing processes that help teams get work done â€” without becoming bureaucratic nightmares.

I learned so much from our chat! Here are a few takeaways:

â†³ ğŸ¤– ğ—”ğ˜€ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—½ğ—²ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—² ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—±ğ—¼ ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—¼ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—° ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸ ğ—»ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ˜€ â€” if you find yourself repeatedly nagging engineers to update JIRA, you're fighting human nature. Automate the copying of data between systems.

â†³ ğŸ“¢ ğ— ğ—®ğ—¸ğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—°ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² â€” notifications that tag people publicly create accountability. When engineers see how their updates affect designers or QA, they understand why it matters.

â†³ ğŸ¹ ğ—§ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—°ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—¸ğ—² ğ—® ğ—°ğ—¹ğ—®ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—º ğ—½ğ—²ğ˜ â€” it needs care and feeding from everyone on the team, not just the manager. Make it everyone's responsibility to keep it healthy.

â†³ ğŸ’­ ğ—§ğ—µğ—² ğ—²ğ—ºğ—¼ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—µğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ—»ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¹ â€” constantly asking people to do (tedious) tasks damages relationships. If something is compromising your ability to coach and mentor, it's worth automating.

â†³ ğŸ¯ ğ—Ÿğ—®ğ˜‡ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—® ğ—³ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—², ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—® ğ—¯ğ˜‚ğ—´ â€” acknowledging you have finite hours in the day is wisdom. Invest in processes that free you up for the work that matters most.

You can find the full episode in the comments!

How do you grow beyond senior as a designer?

I've taken over 6 months to answer this question in the most actionable way in my new book.

Most senior designers do not want to become managers. So I focused on the IC-roles (whether it's called Staff, Lead, or Principal at your organization).

I researched how 50+ companies evaluate designers and employees, including Etsy, Medium, Dropbox, Square, Figma, Zendesk, and Intercom.

I also interviewed 19 product designers on their progression at Figma, Instacart, Dropbox, Etsy, Twitter, and smaller companies.

The book includes actionable techniques that helped other designers get promoted beyond senior: understanding business, finding project opportunities, setting standards, selling ideas, mentoring, increasing visibility, and more.

(If youâ€™re mid/junior-level, check out my previous book The Path to Senior Designer).

author: Austin Hughes
full_text:
For our Series B, I sent 24 cameos to our customers with the goal of generating $0 in pipeline. My team thought I lost my mind.

I spent hours researching which celebrities would resonate with our customers - just to say thank you.

Kevin Oâ€™Leary thanking our customer by name. 
LaVar Ball hyping up anotherâ€™s success. 
Steve Wozniak sharing his hiring tips.

20 out of the 24 customers replied within minutes. 

These arenâ€™t just customers. 
Theyâ€™re the people who built this company with us. The ones who gave us feedback that shaped our roadmap.

If you want to do something similar, hereâ€™s the framework I took away:
1/ Make it zero-lift. Customers shouldnâ€™t have to do anything to enjoy it.
2/ Make it personal. Show you see them as people, not just logos.
3/ Make it aligned. Celebrate in a way that reflects your values. For us, that meant: customers are true partners in the journey.

Yes, fundraising is a chance to generate pipeline.
Itâ€™s also a chance to show gratitude with no ROI in mind.

p.s. credit to Austin Hughes ğŸ¤ for the idea

author: Ben Horowitz
full_text:
If you donâ€™t enjoy your job, and youâ€™re reading this, there IS a WAY out.

This is my favorite book, the Wisdom of Insecurity by Alan Watts.

I want to be tactical, though, you can create your own luck. You can navigate out of your situation.

But to do so requires some advice from the Shawshank Redemption:

Pressure Over Time

Optionality is built in years and months, not days and weeks.

The best optionality is built by becoming an expert, and itâ€™s usually by combining two things (in my case, customer empathy and data w/ AI). Iâ€™m the best in the world ONLY when you mix those three things. This is a Ben Horowitz concept, and itâ€™s beautiful.

But the way in which you can get everything that you wanted is to find out what you enjoy doing, and just begin.

Begin by working on it, talking to people about it, building little prototypes, working for people or companies for free to learn it. 

When you do that, you subtly convince the other people that love what you love that youâ€™re in it for passion. 

This is the single thing that people want to hire for, a hunger for the work itself. For its own sake.

Weather itâ€™s gardening, or dental hygiene, or making hats, or ice skatingâ€¦ I promise you there are others out there that feel the way you feel.

Then, once you know them, and once they know your only agenda is to find joy in what you doâ€¦ they FIND ways to help you. Because they see the joy, they likely feel the joy, and they want other people to feel the joy.

The people I completely avoid building relationships with are those that are money driven, not because itâ€™s bad (I love money), but just because itâ€™s the outcome they seek not the process they love.

That only gets you so far, because you lose your purpose when you make enough money. All that money ever got me, besides freedom from 9-5, is a ridiculously over priced coffee grinder. 

Start working on the side, finding your community, doing the things you feel drawn toâ€¦ and when you do, youâ€™ll draw in others.

And one day youâ€™ll wake up, and youâ€™ll have so much optionality you wonâ€™t know how to chose.

Thatâ€™s when you really become free, when you get to define your days around your joy, not your job.

Invest daily now, and I promise it will compound over enough time.

author: Birgitta Boeckeler
full_text:
How do you create an AI coding workflow that actually works? ğŸ¤–

In this weekâ€™s podcast episode I had the pleasure of speaking with Birgitta Boeckeler, distinguished engineer and global lead for AI-assisted software delivery at Thoughtworks.

Birgitta's full-time job is to figure out how engineering teams can make the most out of AI â€” and she shared some fantastic insights about what's working (and what's not) in real-world teams.

Here are a few takeaways from our chat:

â†³ ğŸ”„ ğ—›ğ˜‚ğ—ºğ—®ğ—»-ğ—¶ğ—»-ğ˜ğ—µğ—²-ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—½ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—¸ğ—²ğ˜† â€” small, incremental changes with constant review beat large autonomous agent workflows. Non-determinism is a feature, not a bug.

â†³ ğŸ“Š ğ—£ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† ğ—´ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ—¿ğ˜† ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—±ğ—¹ğ˜† â€” from negative to 10x improvement, depending on tech stack, codebase quality, and team practices. And remember: if coding is only 30% of your work, you can't exceed 15-20% overall improvement.

â†³ ğŸ§  ğ—•ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—»ğ—°ğ—² ğ˜€ğ—¸ğ—²ğ—½ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—º ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ—®ğ—ºğ—¯ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» â€” the best teams combine critical thinking about AI's limitations with ambitious experimentation. Both perspectives bring value and you should reward them.

â†³ ğŸ—ï¸ ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜'ğ˜€ ğ—´ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—± ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—µğ˜‚ğ—ºğ—®ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—´ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—± ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—”ğ—œ â€” modular, well-structured code helps AI as much as it helps developers. Clean architecture still matters.

â†³ ğŸ¯ ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—¸ ğ—®ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ â€” evaluate probability, impact, and detectability for every AI-generated change. Your experience and "scars from the past" are still crucial.

â†³ ğŸ”§ ğ—§ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ˜€ ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ â€” whether terminal-based like Claude Code or IDE-based like Cursor, successful tools integrate deeply with existing workflows. 

You can find the links to the episode in the comments!

author: Brian Balfour
full_text:
PMF is no longer a binary yes/no (if it ever was). It's more like a treadmill where the speed keeps getting turned up. 

Growth legend Brian Balfour from Reforge joined me & CJ on today's Mostly Growth podcast to talk about the PMF treadmill and what you can do to avoid falling off.

My biggest takeaways:

1. PMF isn't enough. It's only one of "Four Fits" to build a successful business. The others: Product Channel fit, Channel Model fit & Model Market fit. AI changes each of these all at once.

2. PMF isn't a milestone that you achieve & move on. It's more like a threshold and that threshold keeps going up over time as a product category matures. 

3. Customer expectations used to rise linearly. New tech shifts w/ AI mean customer expectations can spike exponentially. You need to go faster just to stay in the same place (and even that might not be enough).

4. If you look at PMF as a treadmill, product investments aren't necessarily R&D. They might be more like COGS: necessary to keep serving customers and avoid PMF collapse.

5. As companies ramp up product velocity to stay on the PMF treadmill, product *delivery* is no longer the bottleneck. Product *adoption* is. Companies are releasing features faster than customers can absorb them.

---

Also inside the episode: platform shifts, fave new products (Gamma -- an AI native PPT, Boardy -- an AI superconnector & Tolan from Portola -- an alien best friend), almost getting banned on LinkedIn, and putting lifting maxes on your resume.

full_text:
If youâ€™re worried about hearing from the media that software development might be "over" because of AI, here's some perspective.

Bryan Cantrill has had an incredible career: worked on operating systems at Sun, built an AWS competitor at Joyent (an AWS competitor), and is now building a new type of "server computer" at Oxide Computer Company (where he is cofounder and CTO. I love how amazing Oxide is, and did a deepdive on them a while back: https://lnkd.in/eZMBSBaG)

When he started out, in 1992, conventional wisdom was that software in the US is over, because all of it will be outsourced - heck, it's happening. No point in graduating in this field. It was a rational argument at the time, and those predicting it truly believed it.

Looking back, software development was just getting started, and many golden decades would follow.

author: Bryan Cantrill
full_text:
How have servers and the cloud evolved in the last 30 years, and what might be next?Â Bryan Cantrill has been at the thick of the industry since the Dotcom Boom and Bust, and shares fascinating stories from both this time; on how AWS was born; why Kubernetes was key for GCP to gain ground, and why they're building a completely custom server rack computer at Oxide Computer Company. Bryan is one of my all-time favorite people to talk with -  don't miss this one.

Teaser - he talked about how Jeff Bezos tricked almost everyone in tech to believe that the cloud was a terrible business, and how Oracle (yes, Oracle!) taught him something extremely valuable he uses to this date:

â€¢ YouTube: https://lnkd.in/eXh9uait 

â€¢ Spotify: https://lnkd.in/eEw8DgCX 

â€¢ Apple: https://lnkd.in/eeJJMcv4

Thanks to our wonderful season sponsors:

â€¢â Â StatsigÂ â  â€” â  The unified platform for flags, analytics, experiments, and more. Check it out: https://lnkd.in/eQkXqjMZ

â€¢â Â LinearÂ â  â€” â  The system for modern product development. They now support AI agents and you can also build your own - see how: https://lnkd.in/ew6kPJ_w

----

My favorite part of the episode is when Bryan talked about how the "Dotcom Bust" was much better for innovation than the "Dotcom Boom:"

â€œA boom can get you to care about things that you actually donâ€™t care about. This is because in a boom, everyone is so financially driven that itâ€™s hard not to become financially driven!

But [the financial side] is actually not why I got into this. So during the bust, I was definitely able to put a meal on my table and a roof over my head. But [the Bust] was a reminder about whatâ€™s important.

We did better technical work in the Bust than in the Boom.Â I think thatâ€™s because in the Bust it was like: okay, now weÂ reallyÂ have to focus. We have fewer resources. These fewer resources actually force more creativity!

So all of the things that we did, certainly speaking at Sun and system software, soÂ ZFSÂ filesystem] andÂ DTraceÂ [dynamic tracing framework] andÂ Service Manager FacilityÂ [unified service management framework in Solaris 10], all these things that were really revolutionary for the operating system. All of these [innovations] happened in this same kind of post-Bust period of time, from 2001 to 2005.â€

author: CJ Gustafson
full_text:
Quick poll: have you ever voluntarily shown up for a panel?

I don't know about you, but I keep tricking myself into thinking I should go. And I always regret it.

At a typical panel (a) everyone agrees with each other, (b) nobody wants to say something controversial, and (c) the best speakers get about 5 mins of talking in a 30 min session, so they never get below the surface.

If you agreed to join or moderate a panel, here's some (unsolicited) advice:

1. Pick one speaker per question. Not everyone needs to answer.
2. Find a POV where you *disagree* with 80%+ of the room. That's the most fun to hear about.
3. Stop talking about strategy, start talking about specifics.
4. Bring one tactical piece of advice that a listener can apply to their job in the next 24 hours. It doesn't matter if it's in the weeds (actually, that's a good thing.)
5. Maybe pay CJ to show up? If he doesn't do panels, how else will he pay for that Wonder playzone membership?

---

PS, if you like this clip, you'll <3 the Mostly Growth pod with me & CJ. New episodes drop on Wednesday & Friday mornings.

author: Casey Newton
full_text:
An anon poster pretended to be an UberEats software engineer, and baited the internet to believe something completely false:

This Reddit thread claiming that a "major food delivery app" is pocketing priority fees and driver benefit fees blew up a few days ago: https://lnkd.in/eFG7M3Vr

It got the attention of journalist Casey Newton (at Platformer.) Casey reached out, and started chatting with this person over Signal. He asked for evidence of the claims, and got a photo of the UberEats badge of this "whistleblower" and a 14-page supposedly internal document uncovering damning things.

Except the badge is absolutely fake and AI-generated, as is the document! I know, because I worked at Uber, still meet with people who work at Uber and the badge has not changed, and looks nothing like the one on the photo. There is no "UberEats" badge; it is not green; the title is obviously not on the badge (if it was, a new badge would need to be issued on every promotion). (I would upload my own badge that I still have - but now I worry that doing so would make it easier for the next troll to create a more realistic badge, and eventually fool a less careful journalist!)

Casey figured out he is being baited and fed AI-generated documents, and confronted this poster: who then simply deleted their Signal account. A lot longer post by Casey with all the details, and the fake 14-page, AI-generated document: https://lnkd.in/euQGqV6e

The problem is how it took this baiter a few minutes to generate plausible sounding lies, but hours for a journalist to figure out it's all fake... and the lie keeps spreading online. As Casey put it so well:

"The rapid spread of the whistleblowerâ€™s post illustrated yetÂ another maximÂ they taught us in J-school:Â A lie can travel halfway around the world before the truth can get its boots on.Â With AI tools at their fingertips, hoaxsters can make those lies travel even faster."

(All other claims were also false, as confirmed by Uber and DoorDash. If there was a whisper of truth in it, you can bet real whistleblowers would come out: there are thousands of people working at each company, and even more ex-employees who would say something if there was an ounce of truth in it...)

author: Cassie Young
full_text:
AI-native companies have been shattering growth records. The elephant in the room: what Cassie Young calls an impending "gross retention apocalypse".

It becomes nearly impossible to sustain hypergrowth when you have a larger and larger install base that walks out the door each month. Thereâ€™s a term for this: burning through your TAM.

I analyzed data from ChartMogul on 3,500 software companies, mapping out companies based on two dimensions: annualized net revenue retention (NRR) from September 2025 and year-on-year revenue growth.

What the data shows:

1. On the whole thereâ€™s a very strong correlation between NRR and long-term growth. 

2. Early-stage startups can grow fast (200%+) even with NRR below 40%.Â (Many B2C/self-serve AI startups fall into this bucket.)

3. Yet low retention companies are at extremely high risk of growth going in reverse; three times as many are shrinking compared to growing quickly.

---

I'm not sure if it's too late for a 2026 prediction. If not, here's one to add: there's a resurgence in investment in CS & professional services as buyers shift from AI experimentation >>> consolidating around a handful of preferred AI partners.

The full report is available here: https://lnkd.in/e3wp5Py6

author: Charchris Sloan
full_text:
Now is the time to upskill. Stop thinking about how AI will eliminate your role and start thinking about how it will elevate it. Jordan Cutlerâ€™s advice? Diversify your skillset:

â€œDevelop your people and AI skills, use AI to solve problems and ensure you have the people skills to work with *anyone*â€.

He advises entry-level engineers to follow the 3 Eâ€™s framework:

- Education: Evolve your understanding of the foundations, for example, embeddings and AI's probabilistic nature and randomness. There are AI courses on Udemy that can help.

- Exposure: Curate your â€œinformation dietâ€ and read content from credible experts (e.g., Ruben Hassid), whether in newsletters or following them on LinkedIn.

- Experience: Start building products. AI can guide you to an output, and youâ€™ll quickly understand whether your code has worked.

For more tenured engineers, he recommends using AI to improve communication and design better systems:
- Use tools like v0 to get to a higher fidelity prototype with minimal effort
- Use tools like WriteEdge and @chatPRD to discuss/debate ideas

In summary: use AI to reduce the â€œtime to valueâ€ for a product

We discuss this and more in this weekâ€™s edition of Hiring Humans (We also share some great resources to feed your information diet too ğŸ‘€)

author: Charleen W.
full_text:
We built a clickfarm at our office.

The result was 1,000+ likes in 60 minutes.

Last week we announced our Series B and knew this would be a huge moment for the company. 

So we asked the entire team to come into the office at 8am and engage with the post and send it to everyone they knew.

Engineers who normally come in at 10am showed up before 8, sales team who's usually on calls was ready to engage. Everyone came early.

At 8am, every Pylon employee liked, commented, and reposted. Then each person shared the post with their friends, previous coworkers, family members. We made a challenge to see who could message the most people. Charleen came out on top with 52 (!)

Turns out having a bigger teams gives you more people to mobilize for an announcement :) and we took full advantage of that.

We wanted to make this big.


-- NOTES -- 


1/ This was possible because our team has reached critical mass. For every big announcement after we'll continue to have more and more people who can engage.

2/ We don't do this for every post or event. This was exclusively for our Series B announcement, considering how infrequently fundraises happen.

3. Don't stop at team boundaries: don't stop until you solve the problem

full_text:
Confirmed for the first-ever Pragmatic Summit: Chip Huyen, author of the best-selling book AI Engineering (that I cannot recommend enough.)

Chip worked as a researcher at Netflix, was a core developer at NVIDIA (building NeMo, NVIDIAâ€™s GenAI framework), and co-founded Claypot AI. She also taught Machine Learning at Stanford University. Talk about first-hand experience on from academia through industry, to startups!

A few months ago, we sat down for a podcast, talking about the evolving field of AI Engineering: https://lnkd.in/eGAWT5kM

And here's an overview of the AI Engineering stack, also written by Chip: https://lnkd.in/ekrPx8GV

On 11 Feb, in San Francico, on this one-day summit, we'll answer the question: How is AI reshaping software engineering, dev workflows, and the modern engineering stack? 

The speaker lineup is standout - people like Laura Tacho (CTO, DX), Sualeh A. This is what engineers tend to focus on, depending on their level:
âœ… Junior Engineer: What tickets are mine?
âœ… Senior Engineer: How do we ship quality on time?
âœ… Staff Engineer: Why are we building this?

As a senior engineer, change your communication patterns accordingly (using empathy). With staff, focus more on the problems, vision, and strategy. With other seniors, focus on developer workflows and tools. To juniors, offer a predictable steady flow of meaningful work.

See chrislaffra.com/c4e for more information.

author: Chris Lattner
full_text:
8 interesting learnings from my conversation with Chris Lattner about how he created Swift, Mojo - and before all of these, LLVM:

1. Demonstrate business value inside a large company, first! 

Apple hired Chris to work on LLVM (a new type of compiler, created by Chris), because they were frustrated with GCC. However, it took Chris some friendly advice from his manager, and he â€œgot the vibe that, after a year, if Appleâ€™s not using in some product, then theyâ€™ll ask to start doing something else.â€ This realization pushed Chris to find the first team to be the internal customer to LLVM: which was the OpenGL team, where he was able to â€œdo something very small that actually had value.â€ After this, more teams inside Apple onboarded to LLVM.

2. Chris built Swift in secret, for more than a year. 

For a year and a half, Chris built Swift on nights and weekends, while running a 40+ person (and growing!) team during the day. Talk about believing in the value of your side project! 

3. Apple leadership was initially not enthusiastic about Swift. 

When Chris showed off an early version of Swift to leadership, the response was â€œwhy would we want a new language? Objective C is what made the iPhone successful.â€

4. Chrisâ€™s whole career led him to the crossover of compilers, languages, AI and hardware.

In the â€œ1.0â€ phase on his career, he built developer tools (compilers and languages) for software engineers at Apple. In the â€œ2.0â€ phase he worked on AI at Tesla (Autopilot) and Google (TensorFlow and TPUs), and then worked on hardware (RISC-V CPUs at SiFive). At his current startup, all of these past experiences combine: Modular builds tools to make programs portable across GPUs (and CPUs, and TPUs).

5. Why Mojo is both so readable, but also so performant:

Mojo took a lot of inspiration from Python for readability, but also added features to make the language be more performant: for example, compressed floating point formats (the ability to reduce the precision of floating point numbers, by using types like Float16), and metaprogramming capabilities like parameters for compile-time calculations.

6. How Modular hires new grads: 

They look for folks who have intellectual curiosity, are fearless in getting things done, and itâ€™s a positive sign if theyâ€™ve contributed to open source projects before.

7. What Chris is most proud of: helping others start creating software. 

Something Chris still remembers is how, after Swift became widespread, people stopped him on the street, thanking him that they could become iOS developers using this easier to onboard language.

8. Chrisâ€™ success looks a lot different than many people from the outside imagine.

As Chris put it: â€œI donâ€™t expect people to understand me. What usually happens is that these projects over time, they grow and they get to the point where suddenly it clicks and suddenly people start to understand.â€

The full podcast: https://lnkd.in/eMMawVEX

author: Curtis Einsmann
full_text:
A common mistake of developers new to a "tech lead" role: trying to perform every code review. They're concerned that if they don't, something will break.

But reviewing every Pull Request isn't feasible, and doesn't scale.

So, what should you do instead? 6 tips:

1ï¸âƒ£ Enhance your delivery systems outside of code review.

Strengthen your release pipelines with tests, monitoring and rollback. This will help to prevent, detect and mitigate defects.

2ï¸âƒ£ Document code review processes.

Team members should be aware of the expected size, scope and structure for each PR. Add automated checks for testing and approval.

3ï¸âƒ£ Establish paradigms.

Introduce design patterns and structure to the codebase, that others can leverage and build on top of.

4ï¸âƒ£ Integrate automated tools.

Use linters and formatters to ensure consistent style. Set up automated static code analysis.

5ï¸âƒ£ Teach your team to review effectively.

Emphasize the importance of kindness, clarity, and thoroughness. Identify when blocking is or isn't appropriate.

6ï¸âƒ£ Be aware of what's being shipped to production.

Slack/GitHub integration works well. Know when to scan a pull request, and when to do a thorough dive.

ğŸ”‘ Remember: You can't write and review all the code for your team. If you could, hiring others would be pointless.

ğŸ’¡ Instead: put your team in position to ship better software, faster.

-----------
Like this post? It's an excerpt from my video course â€” Master the Code Review! Individual and team licenses available. ğŸ‘‰ https://buff.ly/3PEWlF6

#softwareengineering #codereview

author: Dan Murphy
full_text:
Iâ€™m excited to share an important update about the leadership structure at Exit Five.

After two years running our business as COO, Iâ€™ve promoted Dan Murphy to CEO. 

My role as Founder & Owner does not change; more on that in a bit. 

This promotion isnâ€™t a shift in how we operate â€” itâ€™s a recognition of the role Dan already plays in our business and a critical step in preparing us to scale and maximize our potential in the years ahead.

In the book Traction they talk about the ideal pairing between the Visionary (Founder) and the Integrator (Operator).

That describes the partnership Dan and I have well:

â€¢ Visionaries are creative, strategic, restless, full of ideas, often bald - and honestly a bit dangerous without the right counterpart. They are known to start fires and run.

â€¢ Integrators bring structure and process. They turn chaos into clarity. They run the business, manage teams, keep the trains moving, and allow the Visionary to focus where they are most valuable. Thatâ€™s exactly what Dan has done since joining two years ago.

Dan has pushed me. He challenges every late night and weekend idea. He puts out the fires that I start. He sweats every dollar we spend. And he has consistently held a higher bar for what this company can be. Even if it's sometimes annoying and I want to yell at him :) That's what we need. That's the partner you want.

Exit Five has gone from â€œDaveâ€™s cute little solo businessâ€ to a real company with real scale because of the structure, stability, and leadership he has brought to us.

His growth over the last two years â€” from VP Marketing in his last job to a true operator today â€” has been incredible to watch.

Like in baseball free agency, you get paid for the job you've already done. So this title as CEO reflects who Dan has become and what our company needs for the future. 

We have big plans for 2026, 2027, and beyond. 

I am working harder on this than I have on anything in a while and having the most fun of my career.  Splitting up the CEO and Founder roles will make us all more successful for the future.

My superpowers are vision, content, product, and strategy. Working on copy, hooks, headlines, positioning, storytelling, and training our team to do the same. 

The best role for me at Exit Five is to be editor-in-chief and raise the bar on our ideas, our content, products, and the way we show up in the market. Thatâ€™s where I can create the most value.

This move gives us the foundation we need for a more ambitious Exit Five â€” one with more impact, more innovation, and more opportunity for our team.

Please join me in congratulating Dan on a well-earned promotion to CEO of Exit Five. 

This is an amazing milestone for our little business, and I canâ€™t wait to see where we go from here.

NOTE: He started wearing the fanny pack before becoming CEO. But that's how I knew it was meant to be.

Also, this means I am now in full-time #FounderMode for those keeping score at home.

Congrats Dan!

author: Dan Murphy
full_text:
Happy (official) two year Exit Five anniversary to my guy and our COO Dan Murphy.

In the book Traction and the EOS framework, they talk about the ideal leadership pairing between the Visionary (founder) and an Integrator (the operator).

That framework is exactly what makes Dan and I work so well together.

Most entrepreneurs fall into the Visionary category: creative, strategic, restless (yep), starting fires everywhere (can confirm), big on ideas, lower on follow-through (my bad).

Integrators:

- Bring structure
- Turn chaos into clarity
- Run the business
- Manage teams
- Keep the trains running on time
- Free the Visionary to do Visionary things

Candidly, Dan can be a complete pain in my ass - but that is exactly what I need. 

Dan pushes me. He sweats every dollar we spend. He questions every late night idea we have. He has even mastered the art of putting out every fire that I start.

This is the the reason Exit Five has become a real business, a real company, and something that has already outgrown my name. It's also a profitable growth machine that is making a real impact on thousands of people around the world (I have the receipts in my Apple Notes; the impact goes well beyond B2B marketing).

Dan will tackle any problem, big or small. He's on calls with my accountant, talking to our lawyer, he's interviewing candidates, he's fixing landing pages, he's coding, he's asking me why I spent $25 on a Jimmy John's sandwich at the airport. 

But more importantly he knows what we *can* be and pushes me to raise the bar. Have a high f-ing bar is one of our core values now.

Before this I used to brag about how little I was working, and now I know why: I did not have a clear purpose. I was alone. 

That has all changed in the last two years and I can confidently say that I'm in the prime of my career and we have a great business with product market fit because this guy took my call two years ago. 

His comp was heavily weighted on performance in that first year too. He took a bet on himself, smashed the goals (turns out we're both competitive) and it's be game on ever since.

He's also a good person (imagine that!) A great Dad. Husband. And the guy I would call in a pinch, for anything.

He's also grown - big time. Maturing. Evolving from a VP Marketing to a true COO. And I know there's more to come. 

Thanks for 2 great years Dan. I hope we don't have a public falling out one day where we're talking shit about each other on Twitter!!! <3

Please go follow him on LinkedIn if you are not already.

PS. We celebrated by playing TPC Scottsdale two weeks ago after the E5 team offsite and had a blast. I think it was $500 per person for 18 holes, but we put it on the Ramp card because it's a write off!

Also: I know someone will ask "where can I find my Dan?" Well - I didnt find him on Indeed ("no offense" as my 8 year old says). I found him because we worked together for 8 years at two companies. That was the secret.

author: Dana Lawson
full_text:
One of the ugliest trends in our industry in recent years is the pushback on the value of diversity in engineering teams. 

Also, it has become an extremely charged topic. It feels hard to discuss it without falling into all kinds of partisanship.

So I'll try to be practical.

What is diversity in a team? People immediately think about genders and ethnicities, but it's much more:

â†³ It's people from different levels (juniors & seniors)
â†³ It's different age groups
â†³ It's introverts vs extroverts
â†³ It's people with kids vs no kids
â†³ It's movie guys vs TV show guys

At its core, diversity just means having people around you who are different from you. Who think different from you. This is valuable because we all have biases and blind spots â€” and the more similar we are, the more likely it is that we have the same ones.

In a diverse team, people hold each other to higher standards. This is absolutely obvious to anyone who has been lucky to work on a team like that, but it's (somewhat understandably) hard to grasp for those who have not.

To many, this looks like a moral argument â€” but it is a very practical one.

The most effective argument in favor of diverse teams is not some ethical obligation that companies should match the composition of societyâ€”that's at least debatableâ€”is that ğ—±ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† ğ—ºğ—®ğ—¸ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—¯ğ—²ğ˜ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ ğ˜ğ—²ğ—®ğ—ºğ˜€, ğ—³ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—¹ ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—½.

So how diverse should your team be?

Your team exists to serve your users, so my rule of thumb, which I stole from Dana, is that you want a team whose composition at least reflects that of your community of users. You create better products by better relating to your users.

Do you serve a global, diverse community of people? The best way to serve their needs is to craft a team that reflects that. Which is just common sense.

author: Danny Martinez
full_text:
Software engineering is not dead. Far from it. Jordan Cutler, senior software engineer at Pinterest and author of the High Growth Engineer newsletter (>80k subscribers), says:

Our expectations for each level of software engineer have changed.

If you were previously a junior engineer who needed handholding to start writing code, you could use AI to write code like a mid-level engineer.

Mid-level engineers can use AI to produce the output of a senior engineer. A senior engineer + AI = a Staff engineer, and so on and so forth.

â­ï¸ In next weekâ€™s edition of Hiring Humans, Charchris Sloan, Jordan, and I discuss:

- The advice Jordan gives to entry-level software engineers
- The importance of the â€œinformation dietâ€ for keeping up with AI developments
- How to use AI to improve communication and design better systems
- The engineering skills that companies will interview for in the future

ğŸ—“ï¸ Post dropping on 06/02

author: Darragh C.
full_text:
â€œThe default path was failureâ€ â€” this is one of the first things that Darragh C., CTO of Intercom, told me during our interview about their AI transition.

Without radical action, Intercom would have been swept by new AI-native startups.

To avoid that, they literally bet the house on AI, launching Fin, a separate AI agent product, and directing most resources to it. 

They are also completely reinventing how their engineering team works, as Darragh months ago publicly set the ambitious target of *doubling* the PR throughput per engineer. How is that going? We explored this in depth!

And much more! We discussed how, contrary to doom stories, many junior engineers are actually thriving, how new AI models are bringing diminishing returns, and more.

You can find the full interview in the comments!

We visited the property two weeks and itâ€™s amazing. Feels like a proper exec retreat if I were to picture what one would look like. And it's the perfect spot for a much needed time away to regroup with other marketing leaders.

author: Dave Steer
full_text:
[This week] I'm hosting a conversation on AI and SEO with three marketing leaders that have actual receipts from the past year. Details below.

Each month we host Exit Five Live sessions (don't you dare call it a webinar) open to anyone to dive into a hot topic in B2B marketing. 

Wednesday the session is all about AI + SEO.

AI has created a whole new game for SEO and a lot of brand perception is being shaped outside of channels marketers directly control.

So whatâ€™s a CMO to do? Where should you invest? What changes need to be made to the current playbook? 

Respectfully: how is this any different than traditional SEO? It's not the same thing?

We'll discuss...

My guests:

- Dave Steer (CMO at Webflow; website experience platform)
- Marcy Comer (CMO at EagleView; they do aerial insights / property intelligence)
- Clare Schmitt (VP Marketing at Piedmont Global; they help companies expand internationally) 

So we're coming at this from a bunch of different angles and industries.
