author: David Chang
full_text:
As a $250M company, this is when I knew I needed a VP of Finance:


Early on, I could â€œvibeâ€ my way through numbers.
Mistakes were small and fixable fast.

But once I was debating:
- efficiency vs speed
- ramp time vs headcount
- which parts of the roadmap deserved people now vs later
I knew we needed a VP of Finance. 

Without accurate data and forecasts, I couldnâ€™t answer:
- â€Whatâ€™s the lowest price floor we can set without hurting the business?â€
- â€How do we forecast burn when weâ€™re making headcount or product bets that wonâ€™t pay off for years?â€
- â€œHow many people should we actually hire?â€

When I screened for a VP of Finance, I looked for two things:
1/ Ability: could they wrangle messy data?
2/ First principles thinking: could they get to the root of the issue?

In the take-home, 
I gave candidates a real data room.

I asked them to answer questions like:
- "How much should we commit to X vendor?"
- "Can you forecast our 2025 sales targets?"

I had them walk through assumptions, tradeoffs, and what data was missing.  

David Chang stood out.
He could take unstructured data and turn it into real decisions,

But more importantly,
he optimized for the companyâ€™s actual objectives.

He recognized when flexibility, risk management, or strategic leverage
mattered more than a perfectly precise forecast.

Thatâ€™s why heâ€™s the best VP of Finance.

full_text:
BREAKING NEWS: We just raised our $38M Series B, led by Bessemer Venture Partners, with HubSpot Ventures and Salesforce Ventures joining the round.

When David Gu and I started Recall.ai, the idea was simple: make meeting data accessible as an API.

Three years later, over 2,000 companies - including HubSpot, ClickUp, and Apollo - have launched AI copilots, agents, sales tools, and more on top of us.

Recall.ai is the API for meeting recording. From Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, Slack Huddles, to desktop. 
We give developers one reliable infrastructure layer to capture, store, and analyze the data that powers their products.

This milestone is only possible because of the builders who trusted us early, the team who put in the work, and the partners who believed in this vision. 

Thank you. 
Weâ€™re just getting started.

p.s. couldnâ€™t ask for better partners on this journey  â€” Talia Goldberg and the team at Bessemer Venture Partners for leading the round, plus HubSpot Ventures , Salesforce Ventures , Ridge Ventures, Y Combinator, RTP Ventures, and incredible angels like Paul Graham, Solomon Hykes, Michael Seibel, and Eoghan McCabe

author: David Gu
full_text:
Day 397: They ghosted me AGAIN.
Day 422: Landed for $580K.

The CTO canceled at the last minute. For the 7th time.
14 months of work. 22 stakeholders. 3 different â€œchampions.â€

David Gu poured me a new cup of tea. â€œWhen do we call it?â€

The numbers didnâ€™t lie. Weâ€™d spent 118 hours on this prospect. Our runway was shrinking.
Other deals needed attention.

But something kept nagging at me. Our API usage from their pilot was still active. Growing, actually.

They werenâ€™t uninterested. They were drowning in their own process.

That night I made a decision: No more chasing.

I drafted a final email: â€œWe need to conclude this opportunity by month-end - either as a partner or weâ€™ll reallocate these resources.â€

Then added our non-negotiables:
1/ Executive sponsor required on next call
2/ 14-day maximum evaluation period
3/ No more extensions without commitment

My finger hovered over send. This could kill the deal for good.

I clicked anyway.

5 AM the next day, the CTO called.

â€Apologies for the delays. We need your API. Letâ€™s fix this.â€

That deal closed 422 days after our very first call.

The experience completely changed how we sell at Recall.ai .

We stopped allowing unlimited pilots and set clear success criteria.
We started qualifying opportunities based on timeline, not just fit.
We began walking away from deals with no path to close.

Most importantly, we stopped viewing delays as disinterest.

The results were immediate: win rate tripled, sales cycles shortened, and for the first time, we could forecast with actual confidence.

If they need your product, delays arenâ€™t disinterest. Theyâ€™re process friction.

Lead. Donâ€™t chase.

Whatâ€™s a deal you almost gave up on, and what finally closed it?

author: David Gu
full_text:
Five years ago, I was weeks from shutting down. Now weâ€™re building the infrastructure layer AI products run on.

Every day, millions of sales calls, hiring interviews, and team meetings happen. Critical decisions get made. Problems get solved. Insights emerge.

Then itâ€™s gone. Forever.

We write everything down.
Emails, docs, Slack messages. 
But the most important conversations disappear the moment they end.

I couldnâ€™t let that go.

David Gu and I started building Recall.ai because we believed conversation data would become as critical as databases or cloud storage. People thought we were crazy.

â€œWhy would developers need an API for meeting recordings?â€

Today, over 2000 companies have their answer. HubSpot uses us to power their AI meeting recordings. ClickUp built their notetaker on our infrastructure.

We raised a $38M Series B led by Bessemer, with HubSpot Ventures and Salesforce Ventures joining the round.

But hereâ€™s what Iâ€™m most proud of: we solved a problem that didnâ€™t have a name three years ago.

Every year, 5x more words are spoken at work than written on the internet. Weâ€™re making sure those words donâ€™t get lost anymore.

The infrastructure is invisible. The impact isnâ€™t.

Two years from now, every AI product will be built on conversation data. Weâ€™re building the pipes that make it possible.

p.s. thank you Nasdaq

author: David Gu
full_text:
I redesigned a website for $3,000. It turned into a $10M+ company.


Six years ago, I took a freelance gig for a struggling startup.

The founder, David Gu , was brilliant, but his product was failing.

What impressed me wasn't his idea. It was how he handled it.

When I showed him the proof it wouldnâ€™t work, he didnâ€™t argue. He just nodded and said, "So what should we build instead?"

That question changed everything.

We started whiteboarding after hours. Brainstorming new directions.

Two months later, we shut down his original startup and became co-founders.

We launched Perfect Recall (a meeting notetaker).

For two years, we chased PMF. Built features users liked but wouldnâ€™t pay for. Got excited about metrics that didnâ€™t translate to revenue. Pitched at Demo Day and silence.

Six pivots. Minimal traction. And now, six months of runway left.

One night, after spending the entire day fixing a broken Google Meet integration, David and I sat in silence.

Then he said:
â€We canâ€™t be the only ones dealing with thisâ€¦â€

The breakthrough wasn't adding more features. It was realizing that the infrastructure we built was the product.

We shut down Perfect Recall and launched Recall.ai â€” an API for accessing meeting data across Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, and more.

And suddenly, everything shifted.

The same customers who ghosted us were now asking for contracts.

Six pivots and four years later, we finally had product-market fit.

What made the difference wasn't the perfect idea. It was the right partnership.

David never treated this like a side project. I never had an exit plan.

When everyone else saw failure, we saw iteration.

The journey to $10M ARR wasn't about finding the right product immediately. It was about finding someone you can fail with repeatedly until you succeed.

What's something you've built that turned out completely different from what you first imagined?

p.s. see you at SaaStr!

author: David Gu
full_text:
â€œItâ€™s nice. But we already have something.â€ I closed the Zoom tab and sat there thinking: Why did we shut down our ramen-profitable startup for this?

It was our 100th user research interview.
The call had gone just like the last 99.

Polite. Interested.
But when it came time to ask if theyâ€™d payâ€¦silence.

My first startup, Perfect Recall (meeting notetaker), was ramen profitable. Not growing, but stable.
And Iâ€™d thrown it away chasing this idea in the user research space that clearly wasnâ€™t working.

My co-founder, David Gu , walked into the room.
â€œHowâ€™d it go?â€

I didnâ€™t even look up.
â€œAnother no.â€

We sat there in silence for a few seconds.
Then I said:
â€What if we just built the API?â€

For nearly two years, weâ€™d spent 4-5 hours every day wrestling with meeting data infrastructure.
Zoom APIs. Transcription services. Platform-specific bugs.

Iâ€™d googled â€œGoogle Meet APIâ€ so many times I could recite the results.

But it felt tooâ€¦ niche. Too small.

David nodded.
â€œYou mean for meeting data? I would pay money to not deal with it.â€

Thatâ€™s when it clicked.

The problem didnâ€™t feel important enough because we were focused on market size instead of pain.
But solving a deep pain for real people is the always the best first step.

p.s. that â€œAPI ideaâ€ became Recall.ai. Today, 1,500+ companies use it to get meeting data (recordings, transcripts, metadata) into their AI products

author: David Spitz
full_text:
This data is INSANE. And proves the â€œGrowth at All Costsâ€ era is over. 

Quite literally billions of dollars in enterprise value driven by how cost-efficient your go-to-market (GTM) is. Letâ€™s check it out ğŸ‘‡ 

First - yes, Growth matters. And has one of the largest impacts on TTM Revenue Multiple and Enterprise Value. 

But now Efficiency also matters - how much it costs to grow. Which is most heavily impacted by the ROI of the entire go-to-market GTM investment (40-60% of total revenue invested in GTM). 

__

So hereâ€™s the metric you need to monitor: GTM EFFICIENCY %

GTM Efficiency % = [TTM Total GTM Expenses] / [TTM Total Net New ARR]  * 100%

Put simply, GTM Efficiency % means how much did you spend on GTM to generate $1 in Net New ARR. 

(The smaller, the better) 

Net New ARR = New Logo + Expansion - Contraction - Churn 

Total GTM Expenses = Sales, Marketing, SDRs, Operations, Leadership, Admin, Training, Technology, Data, etc. 

But this number has been getting a lot bigger since 2021 in both the public markets and private markets.Â And it's decimating enterprise value in the process. 

__

So hereâ€™s the thing you need to know: SaaS companies with better GTM Efficiency are valued significantly higher (as a multiple of TTM Revenue). 

GTM Efficiency > 250% -> 3.6X median revenue multiple
GTM Efficiency 175% - 250% -> 6.4X median revenue multiple
GTM Efficiency < 175% -> 10X median revenue multiple

Wow, companies with *efficient* GTM are valued 2X-3X more than SaaS companies with demonstrably inefficient GTM. 

And that makes a difference of hundreds of millions or billions of dollars to shareholders. 

CEOs, CFOs, and Investors take note!Â 
__

The â€œGrowth at All Costsâ€ era is over. 

Drive hundreds of millions or billions of dollars in increased enterprise value in 2025 by hitting your growth target while also maintaining target GTM Efficiency < 175%. 

#finance #b2b #gtm #gotomarket #sales

*Shout out to David Spitz and BenchSights for this breakthrough data and research. Reference data is attached in the comments.

author: David Spitz
full_text:
B2B SaaS revenue growth rates have slowed by over 50% in the past 2 years. 

And CAC Payback periods have skyrocketed by nearly 100% in the same period. 

These two effects combined put massive pressure on core financial metrics, business profitability, and enterprise value. 

The root cause of this is Go-To-Market Bloat (GTM Bloat) where B2B companies invest significant money in Sales & Marketing and do not get the appropriate return on investment.

Sales & Marketing is by far the largest expense on a B2B company P&L - on average 40%-60% of total revenue; and 2-3X more than they spend on Product Development, Engineering, and R&D combined.

GTM Bloat occurs across the entire go-to-market, including People, Programs, Process, and Technology.

(1) People - Too many headcount on each GTM team, caused by outdated financial planning models, in addition to the overspecialization of roles on GTM teams (SDR, MDR, Solutions Consultant, AE, Onboarding Manager, CSM, AM, etc.). Or 90-person Marketing team that should actually be 35 people. Average sales quota attainment of ~40% is another clear indicator of headcount bloat.

(2) Programs - This mostly happens in the Marketing budget. B2B companies dramatically overspend on large scale events and digital performance marketing - up to 15% of total revenue - and do not get anywhere close to an appropriate measurable ROI on these significant expenses.

(3) Processes - Teams, meetings, reporting cadences to support programs that donâ€™t work. SDRs to follow up with â€œleadsâ€ and get a meeting less than 1% of the time. Inefficient processes create significant bloat especially when operated at scale.

(4) Technology - Buying an ABM tool for $200k per year and barely using it. So much bloated headcount increases license & seat costs for all SaaS subscriptions by 2-3X. Too many $100k+/year point solutions used by 1 department or team and not integrated or essential to the full GTM.

__

Solving GTM Bloat is the #1 opportunity in a B2B company today to increase enterprise value. This is now a CEO, CFO, and Board Level issue.

Eliminating GTM expenses that do not provide appropriate ROI could increase EBITDA by 20% or more.

Restructuring the existing investments in GTM to deliver the appropriate effectiveness could increase growth rates by up to 2X (e.g. from 18% to 36% YoY).

Or more than likely, the solution is a mix of both of these - eliminating low ROI expenses to improve EBITDA and doubling down on strategies that are already working to create breakthroughs in growth rate.

#gotomarket #gtm #b2b #cfo 

*Benchmarks on public SaaS growth rates and CAC payback periods â„… David Spitz and BenchSights. Shoutout to David for some of the best work in the industry connecting GTM with Business Financial metrics based on actual data (not surveys, anecdotes, or inaccurate aggregated data).

**At Passetto, we see similar, yet more amplified trends in our standardized analyses of CRM and Financial Metrics of private B2B companies.

Tribal knowledge is engineering teams' biggest bottleneck.

Last week I spoke with Dennis Pilarinos, founder and CEO of Unblocked, on the podcast, and this quote stuck with me. 

Dennis spent his *whole career* working on dev tools: from Director roles at Microsoft and Amazon, to founding BuddyBuild and selling it to Apple, to now building Unblocked, which is one of the few AI dev tools that's specifically NOT about coding.

Here are a few takeaways from our chat:

â†³ ğŸ¯ ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ˜…ğ˜ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ â€” developers spend most of their time searching for the right information, not writing code. One customer's top engineer once spent 5 days writing just 12 lines of code!

â†³ ğŸ§  ğ—›ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—® ğ—¯ğ—®ğ—± ğ—¾ğ˜‚ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—º â€” "there's no such thing as a bad answer from an LLM, it's just a bad question." We're learning to use these tools just like we learned to use Google effectively.

â†³ ğŸ”¨ ğ—”ğ—œ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—® ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—¹ ğ—´ğ˜‚ğ—», ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—® ğ—·ğ—¼ğ—¯ ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—¿ â€” when construction workers got nail guns, they didn't work less - they built more buildings. AI tools let developers tackle more ambitious projects.

â†³ ğŸ“š ğ——ğ—¼ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—ºğ—®ğ˜† ğ—¯ğ—² ğ—±ğ—²ğ—®ğ—± â€” why write docs when AI can extract knowledge from code, PRs, and Slack conversations? Semantic search beats traditional documentation.

â†³ ğŸš€ ğ—§ğ—µğ—² ğ—³ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—®ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ˜€ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—º-ğ˜€ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ â€” imagine AI that not only triages CI failures but proposes and implements fixes. We're moving from writing code to orchestrating intelligent systems.

author: Dennis Pilarinos
full_text:
If AI can understand code without docs, and can write better docs than most humans... what's the point of documentation anymore? ğŸ¤”

Today I partnered with Dennis Pilarinos (founder of Unblocked, former Director at Microsoft/Amazon) to explore this question. And the answer is surprisingly complex.

I believe we are witnessing a fundamental shift in engineering knowledge. AI is making some docs obsolete while making others more critical than ever.

The magic is understanding the ğ—ªğ—µğ˜†/ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜/ğ—›ğ—¼ğ˜„ pyramid:

â†³ ğŸ§  ğ—§ğ—µğ—² "ğ—ªğ—µğ˜†" â€” business context, decisions, constraints. This is 100% a human domain and more valuable than ever. AI can't infer this by looking at the code.

â†³ ğŸ“ ğ—§ğ—µğ—² "ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜" â€” system design, features, workflows. This is where humans and AI will *collaborate* the most.

â†³ âš™ï¸ ğ—§ğ—µğ—² "ğ—›ğ—¼ğ˜„" â€” implementation details, runbooks, API docs. AI can largely own and auto-generate this layer.

The problem is: today most teams have it backwards â€” we spend 80% effort documenting HOW (which AI can largely generate) and 20% on WHY (which only humans can provide).

Time to flip that ratio.

So, the future is not static wikis â€” it's AI assistants that understand your entire engineering context and answer exactly what you need to know, right now. But we need to be intentional about *which* context we still need to record and provide, as humans, and which instead will become AI-generated.

You can check out our full article in the comments!

author: Edward Chiu
full_text:
The Chiu brothers founded Catalyst in 2016.

8 years later they merged with a competitor.

They got the idea while working at DigitalOcean:
- Edward was Head of Customer Success
- Kevin was Head of Sales

While there they faced all normal CS challenges and evaluated existing Customer Success Platforms (CSPs). They didn't find anything they loved.

*an idea is born*

What if they could make a CSP that...
1/ Was simple to implement
2/ Pleasant to use

The first was the most critical.

The challenge with implementations is that you need product data to calculate useful customer health scores, churn risk, etc. CS teams are dependent on engineering and data teams to help them get that data, which often never happens. And even when it does during an initial implementation, it needs to be maintained as new features are released and it's tough to get ongoing resourcing.

One way they tried to simplify implementation was by integrating into the new systems of record that were already capturing a lot of data:
- CRM (Salesforce/HubSpot)
- Data Warehouse (Snowflake/BigQuery)
- Product Analytics (Amplitude/Mixpanel)

This seemingly worked quite well.

Their complete timeline:
2016 - Founded
2016 - $2.4 Seed Round 
2018 - $3M Seed+ Round
2019 - $15M Series A
2020 - $25M Series B
2022 - Series B1 (undisclosed amount)
2023 - Series C (undisclosed amount)


And finally in 2024 they merged with a competitor Totango.


-- Notes --

1/ The CS market was highly competitive before they got started. Gainsight seems to have been the clear thought leadership and had a 7 year headstart. This didn't deter them and they were able to make a major mark and win thought leadership mind-share. There were at least 5 strong players in the market before them:

- Gainsight (2009)
- Totango (2010)
- Planhat (2015)
- Vitally (2015)
- ChurnZero (2015)
â†’ Catalyst (2016)
- Custify (2016)
- HubSpot Customer Success (2024)


2/ I love that they were early pioneers in founder-led marketing on LinkedIn. Nick Mehta probably deserves a lot of credit for the inspiration here, but they milked LinkedIn very well. Between the Edward and Kevin they had 70k on LinkedIn.


--

As we start to build more Customer Success-specific features we're going to be learning from their product and others.

The goal is to build the first support platform, built-for-B2B which is going to include CS personas.

Excited to share more soon here.

author: Elias Kokaly
full_text:
DataGrail's customer data was scattered across 6 fragmented sources... 

...until they used Account Intelligence.

When the customer success team evolved from managing renewals to driving product adoption, they needed complete visibility into account health. 

But customer information was scattered across Slack, Salesforce, Google Drive, and other tools with no single source of truth.

Their support team was already using Pylon, so DataGrail implemented Account Intelligence to unify customer context across post-sales.

Here's what changed:

â†’ 6 data sources consolidated into one customer view
â†’ Significant hours saved per CSM on manual research
â†’ At-risk accounts proactively identified through automated health scoring
â†’ Contraction risks spotted (customers paying for undeployed products)
â†’ Expansion opportunities surfaced (customers using unpurchased products)

AI Web Research fields even monitor external risks like champion departures or major business changes that could impact renewals.

Thanks Elias Kokaly and the DataGrail team for showing what unified customer intelligence can do!

author: Erik Jacobson
full_text:
How can you prove you're not AI? I dunno, check my writing style.

My team gave me a list of 15 questions to answer on my podcast about business, marketing, and life.

We put the episode out this morning (I will link it in the comments) but I loved this question in particular:

"If you only have five minutes to prove you're human and not AI over text how would you do it?"

PLEASE I am WAY funnier and more likable than AI! My AI is corny as shit.

I hope you would be able to know...

And is there a bigger diss today than someone telling you your writing as AI when it WASNT AI.

Anyway ...

This was a fun podcast, complete change of pace. And we have decided to mix in more stuff like this, not just B2B CMO interviews because turns out - people like both.

PS. I want to give a huge shoutout to my friend Erik Jacobson and his team at Hatch --> They are an "All-In-One" B2B Video Content Agency for Podcasts, YouTube, and Social. They have been my podcast production and editing team for 4-5 years now; they graciously provide their services to me and our team at Exit Five and make it so I literally just have to record the podcast and they do everything else: post production, editing, clips, social, strategy etc. Thank you. I don't get paid for that, they just have been super helpful over the years and I'd love to help them out in return with a lead or two from LinkedIn.

author: Ethan Evans
full_text:
I know an engineer who has been stuck in a mid-level role for 30+ years because he doesnâ€™t care what his managers think. He cares about technical excellence. That is great, but it wonâ€™t get you promoted. 

Technical excellence alone does not get engineers promoted because technical excellence alone does not create business value.  To get promoted, especially at higher levels, an engineer needs to make it clear that they have an impact in at least one of these three things: 

1) Revenue Generation

This could mean they launch new features/products, facilitate payments, build systems to handle more customers, or a number of other things. However, the connection between the engineerâ€™s work and the revenue or opportunity for revenue should be clear. 

2) Cost Reduction

On the other side of revenue is cost reduction. A businessâ€™s profits increase when its costs decrease, so doing any work that improves the efficiency of the business will be seen as valuable. 

3) Moat Construction

If an engineerâ€™s work doesnâ€™t have direct impact on profit but does help create a competitive advantage for the company, this will also be seen as incredibly valuable. 

The ways in which an engineer can influence each of these three things is practically unlimited, but the important thing for engineers to understand is that doing value-adding work will lead to promotion. Doing maintenance work (exclusively) leads to a maintenance position. 

This may be a very stable job, which is great if that is what you want. But it wonâ€™t be a fast-growing or far-reaching career. If you want one of those, you have to create growth for the company. 

I wrote an article for Jordan Cutlerâ€™s â€œHigh Growth Engineerâ€ newsletter that goes through how you can become an engineer that drives impact and gets promoted to higher and higher roles. 

The insights come from my 25+ years as an engineering leader throughout my career, based directly on what has led me to promote scores of engineers. 

It includes the list of the 5 top traits in engineers that I promoted, as well as stories and examples of engineers creating outsized value. 

Read the article here: https://lnkd.in/eh-CdNW9

Engineers and leaders- How can engineers create business value and get rewarded for it?

full_text:
Learning from experienced people is the best way to level up as a developer.

And you know what?
 
Many software engineers share knowledge and experience in their newsletter.
 
Here are 8 newsletters that will speed up your growth:

1. The Pragmatic Engineer by Gergely Orosz 
 
Gergely shares every week insights about Big Tech and high-growth startups.
 
Relevant for software engineers, managers, and whoever works in tech.
 
This newsletter is worth the paid subscription for me.

Link: https://buff.ly/3rQNJV5 
 
2. ByteByteGo by Alex Xu

Alex is great at explaining complex software systems in simple terms.
 
His newsletter is a must-read to refresh and learn about system design. 

Link: https://buff.ly/3lKksW9

This is an excellent newsletter about entrepreneurship and engineering.
 
I love the way Louie shares his experience and lessons learned.
 
Every week there is food for thought, and his memes are funny.

Ryan is a staff engineer at Instagram and the insights and tips he shares are invaluable.

The best way to learn new concepts or programming languages is spend time building real-world applications.

Every week John writes a hands-on newsletter that will help you build useful software.

Link: https://buff.ly/3Kf5uDT 

6. Craft Better Software by Daniel Moka

This newsletter focuses on Test-Driven Development (TDD) and Extreme Programming (XP).
 
Daniel knows his stuff and shares excellent tips for writing clean code and best practices.

Level up in AI and machine learning in a fun way.

Every week Sairam provides resources, and simplified breakdowns of hard to understand topics.

Great to become a good practitioner in AI and ML.

The practical ideas, plain speak and infographics make it really useful.

If you liked this thread, you can check my newsletter as well.

author: Finn Thormeier
full_text:
I grew from 1K to 43K LinkedIn followers in 8 months. But I didnâ€™t start with a system or a content calendar. On the Founder-led Marketing podcast, I explained what I did instead.

When I first started posting, everyone around me was talking about frameworks and content calendars.
For someone just starting, those playbooks felt overwhelming.

The hardest part isnâ€™t the system.
Itâ€™s just getting started.

Thatâ€™s why I didnâ€™t worry about whether my posts were â€œgood.â€
If they flopped, nobody would see them anyway.
What mattered was building the muscle of putting words out consistently.

If youâ€™re thinking about starting, hereâ€™s how:
1/ Start by building the muscle. Donâ€™t overthink. Just post what you would read.
2/ Notice patterns. Look back after a few weeks. Themes always emerge.
3/ Experiment. Share the same idea in different ways.
4/ Commit. Give yourself 6-12 months before judging.

Focus less on the â€œhow.â€
Focus more on starting.

p.s. thank you Finn Thormeier for having me on!

Link to full podcast below.

author: Fivos Aresti
full_text:
A modern outbound playbook for 2025:

Many predicted the demise of outbound. Well, it's alive & kicking. GTM leaders told me that intent-based outbound is the no. 2 channel where they plan to invest more in 2026, just behind AI discovery.

Here's an extremely tactical guide to what's working (and AI workflows you can steal) via Fivos Aresti, co-founder of AI-first growth studio Workflows.io.

ğŸ‘‰ Manual cold outreach for ICP target accounts

Signals are great, but most target accounts aren't in market (yet). Start by mapping out the TAM & then filter down to a list of target accounts.

Fivos found 66,000+ companies, then narrowed it to 5,700 ICP targets. These were split into four tiers:

 - Dream 150 accounts (highly manual)
 - Tier 1 (cold calling & more personalization)
 - Tier 2 (automation via email & LinkedIn)
 - Tier 3 (automation via email only)

ğŸ› ï¸ Key tools: BuiltWith (identify HubSpot users), GetLatka (identify SaaS companies), Exa (crawl websites w/ AI), Crunchbase (identify funding), Apollo (identify firmographic info), Clay (research & qualification).

ğŸ‘‰ Automated, signal-based plays for other ICP accounts

These perform 2x-10x better than cold outreach plays. The five signal-based plays they prioritized:

 - Customer alumni play
 - Website visitor de-anonymization play
 - LinkedIn connections of founders play
 - LinkedIn engagement play
 - Social listening play

LinkedIn connections of founders is performing best. Fivos sees a 25.4% (!) reply rate, although much of this is harvesting demand from 1.5+ years of posting content.

---

Get the full playbook including signal-based workflows you can steal in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/eSsYvxJZ

Hope you find it useful ğŸ™

---

Today's newsletter is supported by Metronome, who's organizing an insanely valuable webinar on AI pricing with THE Elena Verna (link in comments).

author: Gourav Khanijoe
full_text:
"Consistency is hard. Still do it." -- this lesson helped Gourav reach Staff Engineer in just 8 years.

He realized that as he grew, projects started to take longer, and it wasn't always a straight path upward.

Projects would always start to feel like a drain at some point. You start to lose confidence, priorities shift, requirements change, all while it's already been going on for 3+ months. 

It's not easy to stay consistent and keep pushing forward in these conditions.

But at the end of the day, if you want to show up like a leader, you need to keep pushing forward and make it easier.

So he:
1. Always broke down into milestones, then broke those down even further
2. Documented decisions to avoid backtracking
3. Reminded himself to reward progress

Doing these allowed him to show up and be seen like a leader. He went on to get more project opportunities, ultimately leading to his Staff promotion in just 8 years.

--
This is just one of Gourav Khanijoe's hard-earned lessons on his 10+ year engineering journey. To see the other four, check the latest High Growth Engineer article here: https://lnkd.in/eeAnZ_-5

author: Hamish Grant
full_text:
How a top 1% GTM org uses AI agents â¤µï¸

Thereâ€™s a lot of talk about AI for GTM. But very few have real AI agents in production with real life customers. 

Enter Hamish Grant and the GTM engineering team at SafetyCulture, a global platform that helps frontline teams find a better way to work. They have 2 million users & 500k free team signups per year. 

The impact of their AI agents so far:
 - Near-100% lead enrichment coverage
 - 2x increase in opportunities created (!)
 - 3x increase in meeting booking rates from AI-powered outbound (!!)
 - 10% lift in feature adoption

How they did it in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/eDW6marH

The top four AI agent use cases at SafetyCulture â¤µï¸

1. AI-powered lead enrichment

Built an AI-powered lead enrichment thatâ€™s platform-agnostic, calling five providers in parallel. This eliminated hundreds of hours of manual research & increased enrichment to near-100% coverage.

2. The AI Auto BDR

Trained an AI inbound BDR to handle (1) personalized outreach sequences, (2) knowledge base powered responses, and (3) meeting booking, synced with AE calendars. Saw a 3x increase in meeting booking rate & a 2x increase in opportunities created.

Tools: Retool (AI agent platform), ZoomInfo, HubSpot, Gong, Salesforce and Redshift.

3. AI lifecycle personalization

The AI Auto BDR already personalizes outreach sequences. SafetyCulture wanted to take this a step further with a feature recommender that suggests adjacent use cases based on peer behavior. This led to +10% adoption of new features, improved retention via deeper usage.

4. AI custom app layer for marketing and sales

Replaced necessary (but clunky) GTM systems with an AI-first interface thatâ€™s one pane of glass for all customer information and the next-best-action to be taken. Over 80% of the marketing and sales team are active users of the custom app layer. BDRs save 30 minutes per opportunity with automated hand-offs.

---

AI adoption is more than just rolling out ChatGPT across the team. And weâ€™re still in the early stages of finding out whatâ€™s possible. Iâ€™m excited to keep following along.

author: Hugo Bowne-Anderson
full_text:
ğŸš« Stop building agents. Here's what you should build instead.

Using agents in production code relinquishes all control to the LLM. While LLMs are smart, they're not THAT smart and will get many things wrong, like...
â€¢ What tools should be used
â€¢ When work should get handed off to the next agent
â€¢ What the output should look like

Agents are also highly non-deterministic. So the results of a documentation generation agent can make all your docs look inconsistent.

âœ… Here are the five AI patterns you should know that aren't agents.
1. Prompt chaining: Call an LLM with a function. Get structured data. Feed that into the next LLM
2. Parallelization: Break up LLM calls across multiple, parallelizable functions. It speeds up the final result and results in higher quality since the LLM can just focus on one thing for each prompt
3. Routing: LLM classifies the input to a predefined set of values, then you call regular code based on what it returned
4. Orchestrator & worker: LLM takes input and generates a dynamic set of substeps from the options available. Those substeps are passed off to workers for processing
5. Evaluation & optimization: LLM takes a result and acts as an evaluator. If it doesn't meet the criteria provided, it loops back and iterates on it, like a newspaper editor.

These patterns and code snippets are all documented in the latest High Growth Engineer article if you'd like to learn more: https://lnkd.in/eRXw6dar. Shout-out to Hugo Bowne-Anderson , the guest author for this article.

And credit to Anthropic and their original article that came up with these patterns ğŸ™

Which patterns have you found most useful in building real-world apps?

author: Hywel Carver
full_text:
Why does developer training feel like a waste of time?

One of the paradoxes in tech is that engineers are among the professionals who care *the most* about personal growth, and yet traditional training most often spectacularly fails.

To dive into this I spoke with Hywel Carver, co-founder of Skiller Whale, who has spent years researching what makes tech learning stick.

Since I work on Refactoring, good learning is super close to my heart, and I learned so much from this chat. Here are some takeaways: 

â†³ ğŸ¯ ğ—ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜„ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—±ğ—´ğ—² â‰  ğ˜€ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ˜€ â‰  ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—±ğ—¼ğ—º â€” information can be Googled, skills need practice with feedback, and wisdom comes from understanding context across multiple experiences.

â†³ ğŸ”„ ğ—Ÿğ—²ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—®ğ—±ğ—±ğ˜€ *ğ—®ğ—°ğ—°ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»*, ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—°ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† â€” hiring for skills gives you speed today, but investing in learning compounds over time and always wins eventually.

â†³ ğŸ“Š ğ— ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜€ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—² ğ˜„ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ—ºğ—®ğ˜ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ â€” attendance rates and completion metrics are meaningless. Tie learning to business outcomes like performance improvements or reduced cycle time.

â†³ ğŸ¤– ğ—”ğ—œ ğ—°ğ—µğ—®ğ—»ğ—´ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ˜„ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ˜„ğ—² ğ—»ğ—²ğ—²ğ—± ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—» â€” as AI handles more code generation, developers need deeper fundamental understanding, like pilots who rely on autopilot but must understand their systems inside out.

â†³ ğŸ¯ ğ—£ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜‡ğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ â€”Â make granular assessments to ensure developers only learn what they don't already know, avoiding the frustration of rehashing familiar concepts.

Check out the full episode to learn how to make developer training actually work!

Full episode in the comments! ğŸ‘‡

full_text:
In the Tech layoffs era, the best thing a Software Engineer or an Engineering Manager can do is to stay ahead of the curve by keeping their skills up to date and as sharp as possible. How to do that? Read tech newsletters! Here are 12 of the best personally vetted newsletters everybody should read.

1/ The Pragmatic Engineer by Gergely Orosz - https://lnkd.in/gQ6NfATy
My absolute favorite newsletter, covering a variety of topics from in-depth analysis of how various companies do things to general solid advice on career growth and engineering management.

2/ Level Up Software Engineering by Caleb Mellas - https://lnkd.in/gmAhnDHW
Empathetic career development tips for software engineers looking to develop both technical and interpersonal skills.

3/ Software Design: Tidy First? by Kent Beck - https://lnkd.in/gwvWkpE8
Excellent mix of technical and non-technical advice from the author of Extreme Programming and TDD. 

4/ Engineer's Codex - https://lnkd.in/gGcf3Nax
Case studies and practical lessons from Big Tech companies.

5/ ByteByteGo Newsletter by Alex Xu - https://lnkd.in/geMg5AnP
Weekly in-depth systems design newsletter, written by the author of â€œSystems Designâ€ vol 1 and vol 2.

6/ High Growth Engineer by Jordan Cutler - https://lnkd.in/giieDcyr
Practical actionable advice for ambitious engineers looking to grow in their careers.

7/ Engineering Leadership by Gregor Ojstersek - https://lnkd.in/gPHYeBN6
Engineering/Engineering Leadership topics to help you become a great engineering leader.

8/ SeattleDataGuyâ€™s Newsletter by Benjamin Rogojan - https://lnkd.in/gnFB7J8a
The best data engineering newsletter, insightful even if you donâ€™t work in data.

9/ Hybrid Hacker by Nicola Ballotta - https://lnkd.in/g9fMdk2k
In-depth lessons on engineering management with excellent illustrations.

10/ Wes Kaoâ€™s Newsletter - https://lnkd.in/geJNC3PN
Excellent advice on navigating work dynamics and career growth from the co-founder of Maven.

11/ System Design Newsletter by Neo Kim - https://lnkd.in/gZyW5kQy
Easy-to-understand explanations of complex architectures.

12/ And lastly, me ğŸ˜Š with â€œThe Caring Techie Newsletterâ€ - https://lnkd.in/gYBS3EMe
My newsletter focuses on soft skills, communication, and building caring leaders and it's based on my experience at Big Tech (Google, Uber) and early-stage startups.

author: JA Westenberg
full_text:
For the new year, I wish you more *thick* desires.

This time of the year always sparks some reflection, and I find myself drawn to philosophical articles more than technical ones. This is the best piece I have read last week, by JA Westenberg: https://lnkd.in/dsYzUH8Q

Quoting part of it:

A thick desire is one that changes you in the process of pursuing it.
A thin desire is one that doesn't.

The thin desire keeps reproducing itself.
The thick desire transforms its host.

Thick desires are inconvenient.

They take years to cultivate and can't be satisfied on demand. The desire to master a craft, to read slowly, to be embedded in a genuine community: these desires are effortful to acquire and impossible to fully gratify.

So, for 2026 I wish us all more inconvenient, effortful, and unscalable desires to fulfill. Things that we don't need to monetize, for which there are no users to attract, but that ultimately change us in the process.

Have a good week! â˜€ï¸

author: Jacob Bank
full_text:
The ability to build & manage AI agents is quickly becoming a core skill for everyone. Here are 5 of my favorite marketing use cases for AI agents -- with templates â¤µï¸ 

1ï¸âƒ£ Lead scoring & qualification

Lead scoring is part art, part science. You want to enrich fields via 3rd party data, but also bring in form data & some human(like) judgement. 

Turns out AI agents are great at this -- and you can add a human-in-the-loop escalation via Slack when the classification isn't clear.

See the workflow here: https://lnkd.in/eeDrZrdv

2ï¸âƒ£ Lifecycle emails

Traditional lifecycle emails are pretty mid (did I say that right?!). But AI agents can track new customers, analyze interesting ones & then automatically draft personalized emails suggesting next steps.

See the workflow here: https://lnkd.in/eeDrZrdv

3ï¸âƒ£ Competitor tracking 

Everyone is racing to write comparative content for AI search. This content needs accurate, real-time info on competitors including features, pricing info, reviews & more (otherwise you'll get penalized).

Turns out that AI is pretty great at scraping text and sending alerts when there are significant updates.

See the workflow here: https://lnkd.in/eeDrZrdv

4ï¸âƒ£ Content research

You need to stay on track with what's trending with your audience & key influencers in your space. But nobody has time to monitor dozens of LinkedIn profiles & Substacks. You can get an AI agent to do the research for you & write a report on the top-performing themes.

See the workflow here: https://lnkd.in/eeDrZrdv

5ï¸âƒ£ LinkedIn coaching

AI models have spiky intelligence. While they struggle with things that seem easy, they're surprisingly brilliant at things like analysis & coaching. You can create your own PhD-level coach to improve your LinkedIn game with tips on what's going well & what to change.

See the workflow here: https://lnkd.in/eeDrZrdv

---

Shoutout to Jacob Bank from Relay.app for sharing his ğŸ”¥insights. 

If you've found other cool use cases for AI agents, please share them in the comments (I'm working on a new piece for Growth Unhinged).

author: Jamin Ball
full_text:
This data should be such a wakeup call for GTM teams. 

Public SaaS companies ended Q1 with an estimated average gross margin-adjusted CAC payback period of 57 months based on data from Jamin Ball / Clouded Judgement (link in comments). Said differently, it takes the BEST companies nearly five years to recover their sales & marketing spending. Five years!

Zero public companies ended Q1 with a CAC payback period of less than 12 months. Only five were under 24 months (Digital Ocean, AppFolio, Atlassian, Olo and Q2). Meanwhile, 24 reported either a CAC payback period above 100 months or negative net-new ARR added.

Perhaps more troubling, this isnâ€™t some extreme outlier quarter. Itâ€™s not something we can continue to blame on â€˜the macroâ€™ or external events. 

The average CAC payback period over the past twelve quarters is now 41 months. CAC payback periods havenâ€™t been healthy since Britney Spearsâ€™s conservatorship ended in 2021!

Public companies can usually afford for their GTM to be inefficient in the short-term. They have plenty of profitable legacy customers who can subsidize sales and marketing. And they can sneak in a price increase or two (or three) to squeeze even more from these folks. 

But the subsidies canâ€™t go on forever. And a reckoning could be on the horizon.

AI isnâ€™t whatâ€™s coming for software GTM jobs, at least not yet.Â The real villain is GTM inefficiency. But AI might just be what saves them.

---

Interestingly, early-stage startups are going in the opposite direction. More on that here: https://lnkd.in/eW2AgEkh

ğŸ For more insights on all things software GTM, don't miss Growth Unhinged -- my free weekly newsletter: https://lnkd.in/exTbjKaM

author: Janis Ozolins
full_text:
There's one thing that literally changed my approach to sharing content during the last 6 months.


Learn to create visuals.

I can't count how many people reach out to me every day to ask how I create these visuals.

They are always surprised when I tell them that I can barely hold a pencil in my hand, that I had no previous design experience, and that it takes me from 10-20 minutes to create one of these.

18 months ago I bought $3.6M worth of Palantir stock, butâ€¦

I have literally no idea what the company does. 

At first I was terrified to go out to dinner with friends because people would keep talking about Palantir. 

I didnâ€™t want to be caught looking like an idiot. 

So I called my friend Jason Levin âœï¸ and told him the truth.

Thatâ€™s when we realized something: no one has any f*cking idea what Palantir does. 

If Palantir can be worth $225B without a single person understanding their business, imagine how much it could be worth if people actually understood wtf it did. 

So we rebuilt Palantir using no code tools and pitched it to investors. 

Turns out VCs had no idea what it did either, because we raised $32M for it.

author: Jason Levin âœï¸
full_text:
In 2024 I invested in 147 startups. 

90% turned out to be frauds. 

At first their CEOs would seem great. They had all the qualities I looked for in founders. 

Stanford dropouts, Forbes 30 under 30, rich parents, etc. 

But within a couple months it turned out they lied about their users and growth. 

My investors kept telling me to â€œdo better due diligenceâ€, but this was highly unrealistic. VCs donâ€™t have time for that. 

So I teamed up with Jason Levin âœï¸  to build an app called Is My CEO a Fraud, that would tell me how likely someone is to be a scammer. 

Within a couple days we analyzed over 15,000 tech CEOs & found thousands of frauds. 

So did we report these scammers to the police? No. 

We launched the first BaaS. Blackmail as a service. 

4,600 founders signed up to avoid having their fraud scores leaked & Iâ€™m finally making back all the money I lost investing in their shitty companies. 

P.S. Jason & I actually filmed ourselves building & scaling Is My CEO a Fraud. Watch that here: https://lnkd.in/eJVgYqyA

So what did we do?

author: Jason Levin âœï¸
full_text:
I screamed at my business partner the other day. 

I was angry because our company was failing. 

See a couple weeks ago Jason Levin âœï¸ built us an app that he promised would go viral. 

The app was supposed to tell people how much they looked like their dog. 

I thought it was genius because 90% of dog owners I know have a disturbing attraction to their pet. 

But then the app broke, and I got pissed off. 

Right before I completely flipped out I asked myself, â€œhow do failing tech companies turn their business around?â€. 

They sell their data to the Chinese government. 

Think about it. 23 & me, Facebook, & TikTok all sold user data to China. 

So we got in touch with a Chinese billionaire & sold all of our data for millions. 

So whatâ€™s the lesson? 

When times are tough in your business, donâ€™t freak out. Be like Facebook & sell all of your users' information to foreign adversaries. 

P.S. Jason & I filmed ourselves building & selling this app. Watch that here: https://lnkd.in/e6Cyxy8N

author: Jason Levin âœï¸
full_text:
Whatâ€™s the biggest problem with NYC? 

Itâ€™s not overly expensive rent. 

Itâ€™s not the homelessness.

Itâ€™s not the crime. 

It's that itâ€™s impossible to find couches to sit on when youâ€™re out drinking with your friends. 

For years, whenever I would get fucked up, Iâ€™d pray to god that the bar I was in had a couch. But it never did. 

I was sick of being uncomfortable. 

So I called my buddy Jason Levin âœï¸ and told him that we needed to build an app to find all the best couches in NYC. 

He told me it was a horrible idea. But I built it anyway. 

Now the app has thousands of users and people around the world are paying us $50/month to find the best couches near them. 

So whatâ€™s the lesson? Sometimes the worst ideas are the most profitable. 

P.S. Jason and I filmed ourselves building this app and getting drunk while we searched for the best couches. Watch that here: https://lnkd.in/eid7Qbht

Everyone knows that building a social media brand is insanely valuable, but the hard part is writing content that stands out. 

Most of the time people start posting: 

- Thought leadership that makes you throw up in your mouth
- Brain dead advice like, â€œwake up earlyâ€ or â€œbe on timeâ€
- Cringe stories about their daughterâ€™s ballet recital 

Not only does this content suck, but it just doesnâ€™t work. So what should you do instead?

Make memes. Memes are one of the easiest ways to build an organic following and get millions of views. 

Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m hosting a webinar on how to make viral memes with my buddy Jason Levin. 

In the past year Jason and I have generated 100M+ views & made hundreds of thousands of dollars for our businesses using memes. 

So if you want to learn how to spice up your social media brand without disappointing your entire family, join the webinar weâ€™re hosting this Wednesday.

Hiring managers: Want someone who takes calculated risks (like appearing on podcasts) but also knows when to disconnect and recharge? Let's talk. I promise my interview skills are even better when I'm not worried about my WiFi cutting out from a cabin in the woods.

author: Jennifer Delevante-Moulen
full_text:
B2B Marketing and AI - What do CMOs care about right now?

I recently sat down with Jennifer Delevante-Moulen (CMO at Knak) and Tara RobertsonÂ (CMO at Bitly) to talk about how each of their marketing orgs are using AI and we covered:

â€¢ LinkedIn AI vs. Reality AI - what people are actually doing vs. what they say
â€¢ Why the board and CEO are asking them to explore AI strategically
â€¢ The most overhyped AI use cases in B2B marketing (and where human nuance still wins)
â€¢ Real success stories, including building an AI-powered content research engine, scaling global localization, and using AI to make creative teams more data-driven
â€¢ How they each personally use AI as a strategic thought partner as CMO

This is a good one to bookmark if you need to hear more about B2B CMOs and how they are thinking about AI heading into 2026.

author: Jennifer Delevante-Moulen
full_text:
Some of the best AI use cases are the most "boring" use cases right now.

The ones we're seeing from real marketers - not the guys that get paid to write about AI use cases as a job - but the actual in-house marketers finding ways to use AI to do better marketing.

Things like style guides, custom GPTs built around your ICP, product marketing resources where you can actually put the voice of the customer into everything you do, deep customer research as the starting point for all of your writing, sales enablement etc.

This example from Jennifer Delevante-Moulen (CMO at Knak) is a good one that fits in the "not super sexy" but "super useful" category -- using AI to find content gaps and then figuring out what content to create.

Clip is from a webinar we did with three B2B CMOs for Exit Five about actual AI uses cases. This is a lane of content we're spending a lot of time in right now, trying our best to help separate the signal from the noise. Because I've found a big gap between how the AI Influencer is using AI vs. how the marketing leader at the 200 person B2B manufacturing company in Ohio is using AI.

author: Jess Cook
full_text:
Content marketers run modern marketing.

Because almost all marketing today is shaped online.

And online marketing shows up as:

- Ads
- Videos
- Articles
- Podcasts and clips like this with Jess Cook
- Social posts
- Newsletters
- Communities
- Influencers

Different formats. But none of it works without a clear content strategy and strong content marketing.

Jess is a great example of this: she started her career as a copywriter for big CPG brands. She cut her teeth writing 200+ variations of a recipe for Rice Krispie Treats.

Then built a career in content marketing: content market manager, director, VP brand and content.

Then turned that into a Head of Marketing role at a startup and was recently promoted to VP on the heels of her success using - wait for it - content to drive revenue.

Not because Vector's content gets a lot of impressions and their podcast is unique or because their little mascot is cute.

But because it's working! Those things are driving revenue. 

I had a conversation with Jess last week (now out on my podcast) and she shared three key marketing plays that she's run over the past year:

1. Influencer Marketing - how does it work in B2B, how did she find influencers, what did it cost, how much pipeline was generated, how did they measure it

2. Podcasting - why they started a podcast, how their podcast stands out, how they record, when/where, how they prep, how they know it's working

3. LinkedIn - we talk a bit about what content types (and strategy) is working well here today

4. Career Path - her path from content to VP Marketing

Erin on my team messaged me last night and said this was the best interview we've done recently - please go listen if you need some tactical inspiration.
first_line: Content marketers run modern marketing.
hook_150:
Content marketers run modern marketing.

Because almost all marketing today is shaped online.

And online marketing shows up as:

- Ads
- Videos
- Art

author: Jess Lytle
full_text:
Why aren't more people adopting AI tools internally?

I was having a long conversation with our Head of Marketing Jess Lytle about this last week.

And she crushed me.

She said: it's the same thing as you telling us to write more on LinkedIn; behavior change is hard. You just have to make it a priority.

She was showing me some amazing stuff she does with NotebookLM and how we can be using this to build a brain for our content flywheel and I was blown away but also frustrated - why aren't we doing this? More? Faster? Better?

Jess said: people are still adverse to change, like "is this really better than ChatGPT?" New tools just feel like another thing to learn on top of everything else -- but once you see how much time it saves you, you will wish you started sooner.

I also am seeing a HUGE GAP with what people are talking about with AI on social media and what people are actually *doing* at work.

PS. Go follow Jess for all things AI in marketing.
first_line: Why aren't more people adopting AI tools internally?
hook_150:
Why aren't more people adopting AI tools internally?

I was having a long conversation with our Head of Marketing Jess Lytle about this last week.

An

author: Jess Lytle
full_text:
It's hard to do good work when everything you do is going to be second guessed by someone else.

The CEO, the CFO, your boss, whoever.

I love marketing because of the creativity. 

The challenge of trying to get someone's attention and keep it.

But marketing is not a coin operated machine!

What's the ROI of this podcast episode? No idea. 

What's the ROI of doing the podcast for three years? I can tell you.

This week on my podcast my guest is Exit Five's new Head of Marketing Jess Lytle.

full_text:
What are code security basics us devs should know about? I turned to Johannes Dahse, a security expert for 20+ years for his thoughts and tactics

Watch, listen or read:
â€¢ YouTube: https://lnkd.in/eJ9KQrRqÂ 
â€¢ Spotify: https://lnkd.in/er4mahjPÂ 
â€¢ Apple: https://lnkd.in/ewADY-faÂ 
â€¢ Summary and transcript: https://lnkd.in/epuQm_Q5 

Brought to you by:
â€¢â Â StatsigÂ â  â€” â  The unified platform for flags, analytics, experiments, and more. Statsig is helping make the first-ever Pragmatic Summit a reality. Join me and 400 other top engineers and leaders on 11 February, in San Francisco for a special one-day event.Â Reserve your spot here: https://lnkd.in/eYTCCX5N

â€¢â Â LinearÂ â  â€” â  The system for modern product development https://lnkd.in/egxywckg

---

An interesting thought from the episode: how quality and security are connected. From Johannes:

"[Security vs code quality] is an underrated topic in the industry today. We talked about the null pointer exceptions or these slow regular expressions, right? That can lead to security issues. Thatâ€™s more of the obvious examples of bugs.

Think about unreadable code, not well-maintained code: thatâ€™s often like spaghetti code. At first, itâ€™s not so obvious how this is connected to security.
If you think about how code is not easy to comprehend, not easy to review. Then you do pair programming or code reviews in your development team â€” then in that spaghetti code, you will more likely overlook security problems of your colleague.

Now, maybe someone found an issue or and issue and reports it back to you. As a developer, you have to fix it. But if itâ€™s not maintainable code, you cannot fix the security problem easily. So quality suddenly becomes a security issue in how the attacker window stays open longer!

Your code quality is super related to code security, especially now with AI-generated code.Â We typically see poor quality of code here. And that becomes a problem for security.â€

author: Josh Blyskal
full_text:
Yesterday, ChatGPT hit 2.5 BILLION (ğŸ¤¯) prompts per day, up from 1 billion in December. It's quickly approaching Google's 14 billion daily searches. Getting recommended by AI engines is no longer just a weekend side project (*guilty*).

Josh Blyskal from Profound analyzed data from 100,000 prompts to figure out how these AI engines actually work. Here are nine practical takeaways that you could start applying now to improve your AI search visibility:

(Don't miss the full deep dive in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/e2GdwgNN)

1. Decide which prompts you want to own.

2. Be aware that answer engines behave differently. ChatGPT & Perplexity share only 11% of domain citations. 

3. Write specialized, specific content. 

4. Create surround sound around your product. The best starting points are UGC & social media sites like Reddit, LinkedIn, YouTube, and Quora.

5. Get mentioned on Reddit. It's the single most-cited domain in ChatGPT & Perplexity. 

6. Use structured comparisons and lists. Remember that ChatGPT loves to "borrow" entire answers in chunks rather than do the thinking itself.

7. Make fewer images and more tables. AI engines can't see images well.

8. Measure your influence, not just clicks. The vast majority of AI search is zero-click (but it can still be highly influential.)

9. Stay on top of citation drift. Half of domains cited change in a given month.

Hope you find this useful! If you have other learnings, drop 'em in the comments ğŸ™

#ai #aeo #chatgpt #marketing

author: Josh Braun
full_text:
Robert Kiyosaki said that 9 out of 10 businesses fail, so he came up with a foolproof plan - create ten businesses. Similar to his approach, businesses can hedge against failure, by: 
1) Creating an idea
2) Take it to market and test as quickly as possible
3) If it has traction, learn why and get feedback; if it doesnâ€™t have traction, try something else
4) Once something sticks, improve it and make it better
5) Put your sales force behind it and then go ALL IN

Too many businesses wait until the idea is perfect, get analysis paralysis or they fear failing. By the time they are ready to launch, another competitor has already brought something to market and theyâ€™ve lost the opportunity. 

Be agile, move quickly and sooner or later (maybe by the 10th one) an idea will stick!

author: Julian Park ğŸ”œ DICE ğŸ”œ GDC
full_text:
A lot of founders ask me how to grow on LinkedIn. 

So I started a workshop series to share our strategy.  

Here's what we covered last week:

1/ Seed your followers by sending 25-40 connection requests a day.

2/ Prepare your profile by changing the default button from "Connect" to "Follow" and writing a good headline.

3/ Post interesting content like actual stories from your company or controversial takes. People hate ads. 

4/ Keep building your audience by sending targeted connection requests. For example, connect with any prospect who books a demo. 

5/ Ask your team to like and comment on posts for engagement. Have the company page post snarky comments to make it fun. 


Along with posting consistently for multiple years, this has made LinkedIn our biggest source of inbound leads to this day.

â€”

Thank you to Julian Park (Bezi), Michael Hess (Outset), Kate Yanchenko (Lamoom), Elaine Zelby (Tofu HQ), Yinan (Steven) Na (Creatify), and Mikhil Raja (SonicJobs) for a great session!

Excited to see more founders invest in their content ğŸ‘€

author: Juraj Majerik

A grad student studying Computer Science at a Danish university (DTU) reached out asking for a suggestion on what to do their master's thesis on. They are passionate about mobile development and Android.

This is what I told them. Sharing it in case it's helpful for others.

The link I shared about a side project that stands out is this excellent side project built by Juraj Majerik https://lnkd.in/e-irpG4Z

One thing I learned over the years: it's worth staying close to the cutting edge, and understanding exactly how it all works (you need strong foundations to do so - and keep improving those foundations!). When you do work, always aim to produce world-class, and share it when you can - including e.g. ongoing research for a thesis (that most people do not share publicly - a shame when it's on a cutting-edge topic). Start early with this mentality, and keep to it. You won't be sorry for doing so.

author: Justin Bullock
full_text:
I made one mistake that slowed down our first 100 deals. Hereâ€™s how to avoid it.

Early on, I thought being easy to buy from meant saying yes to everything.
- â€œCan you extend the trial?â€ Of course.
- â€œCan you do net-60 terms?â€ Sure.
- â€œCan you lower the price?â€ No problem.

I thought this would speed up deals. It actually stalled them.

Thatâ€™s when Justin Bullock, our VP of Sales, introduced me to the Give-Get framework. When a prospect asks for something, you ask for something in return.

- If they ask for a trial extension, ask for a commitment to a decision date.
- If they ask for a discount, ask them to sign by the end of the month.
- If they want flexible payment terms, ask for an introduction to the economic buyer.

This does three things. It shortens the sales cycle. It strengthens the relationship. It prevents discounting away deals that would have closed anyway.

Once we implemented this, deals started moving faster. We built a list of what we were willing to give and what we needed to get in return.

If your sales team isnâ€™t trained on this, theyâ€™re giving away leverage in every deal.

Whatâ€™s the worst give youâ€™ve seen in a sales deal?

author: Justin Bullock
full_text:
Hereâ€™s how we evaluated our VP of Sales as a Series B company:


At the exec level, resumes are polished and interviews are clean. Everyone can talk about leadership.
So instead of abstract questions like â€œwhatâ€™s your leadership style,â€ I focused on exposure.

1/ Backchannel references (specifically direct reports)

I asked them:
- â€œWhatâ€™s one thing he needs to improve on?â€
- â€œTell me about a time you disagreed with him.â€
- â€œTell me about a time when things didnâ€™t go to plan? What did he do?â€

You learn very quickly whether someone takes responsibility or deflects.

2/ How they explain misses
I cared less about whether targets were hit and more about why he thought they missed.

Was it always the product? The market? Other people?
Or did they understand what broke and their role in it?

3/ Whether they can still sell
At this stage, I still want a VP of Sales who can sell (not just talk about selling).

There was always a take-home.
I had candidates sell to us and put together a sales plan.

4/ Personality and trust
This is someone I need to trust to act in the companyâ€™s best interest.

A lot of candidates didnâ€™t make it through this process.
But the right one did.

p.s. Justin Bullock

author: Justin Bullock
full_text:
Saying yes too fast kills more deals than saying no.


In our first year of sales, I thought being â€œeasy to work withâ€ meant saying yes:
- â€œCan we extend the trial?â€ Sure.
- â€œCan you do net-60?â€ No problem.
- â€œCan you lower the price?â€ Happy to.

I thought it built goodwill. Instead, it killed urgency.

Deals dragged. Decision dates slipped. Discounts didnâ€™t help.

Then Justin Bullock, our VP of Sales, gave me a simple rule that changed everything:

If they ask for something, you ask for something.

The Give/Get framework.

It did 3 things instantly:
1/ created urgency
2/ qualified intent
3/ protected deal value

We stopped giving away leverage. Started closing faster.
Now every AE at Recall.ai is trained on it.

p.s. want to build sales tools with real conversation data? Recall.ai gives devs access to meeting data (transcripts, recordings, metadata) from Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, and more.

author: Karri Saarinen
full_text:
The best article I have read this week is "The Profitable Startup" by Karri Saarinen at Linear.

You can easily measure the quality of a piece by the density of highlights you take. So here are a few of my own:

â†³ "I don't know why hiring massive teams ever became the norm. In my own experience, small teams always delivered better quality, and faster."

â†³ "What holds you back is rarely team size â€“ it's the clarity of your focus, skill and ability to execute."

â†³ "For most software startups, ten people before product-market fit should be your ceiling, not your target."

â†³ "After PMF, every hire should address a specific, pressing need â€“ not just fill out an org chart."

â€”

The main thesis here is that today profitability has become easier to reach, especially if you work in a space where there is already a market (you have competition), and no big investments are needed upfront.

Profitability is also a good north star that drives good behavior: focus on business value, donâ€™t over hire, keep talking with customers, and so on.

I like how it feels like the tide is shifting a bit on this. With the (glaring) exception of glorious AI slop startups, it feels like there is a growing sub-culture of small to mid-size companies shipping top quality products, and creating good, sustainable culture in the process.

There is something beautiful about this â€œlong-tail innovationâ€, and I hope to keep doing my small part in helping people who work on it ğŸ˜Š

Here is Karri's piece: https://lnkd.in/d4h5uP3P

author: Karthik Ramgopal
full_text:
The Evolution of LinkedInâ€™s Generative AI Tech Stack

Over the past two years, LinkedIn has undergone a rapid transformation in how it builds and ships AI-powered products. 

What began with a handful of GenAI features, such as collaborative articles, AI-assisted Recruiter capabilities, and AI-powered insights for members and customers, has evolved into a comprehensive platform strategy that now involves multiple products. One of the most prominent examples of this shift is Hiring Assistant, LinkedInâ€™s first large-scale AI agent for recruiters, designed to help streamline candidate sourcing and engagement.

Behind these product launches was a clear motivation to scale GenAI use cases efficiently and responsibly across LinkedInâ€™s ecosystem. 

Early GenAI experiments were valuable but siloed because each product team built its own scaffolding for prompts, model calls, and memory management. This fragmented approach made it difficult to maintain consistency, slowed iteration, and risked duplicating efforts. As adoption grew, the engineering organization recognized the need for a unified GenAI application stack that could serve as the foundation for all future AI-driven initiatives.

Note: This article is written in collaboration with the engineering team of LinkedIn. Special thanks to Karthik Ramgopal, a Distinguished Engineer from the LinkedIn engineering team, for helping us understand the GenAI architecture at LinkedIn.Â All credit for the technical details and diagrams shared in this article goes to the LinkedIn Engineering Team.

Read the full article here: https://lnkd.in/eQV6DW9b

#systemdesign #coding #linkedinÂ 
.

Kevin shared his incredible journey from quantitative finance to building and leading AI teams, offering a masterclass in creating value with new tech. Also, since he works on one of the most beloved podcast apps in the world, I asked Kevin for advice about retaining knowledge from all the stuff we consume, and, of course, what his favorite podcasts are!

Here are a few takeaways from our chat:

â†³ ğŸ’¡ ğ—™ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¹ ğ—¶ğ—» ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—º â€” don't start by asking what you can build with AI. Instead, focus on the user's problem first and foremost. AI is just a tool in the toolbox to solve it.

â†³ âš™ï¸ ğ—§ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ ğ—”ğ—œ ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—¸ğ—² ğ—®ğ—» ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—» â€” to handle the randomness of AI models, think of them as interns. Give the same task to multiple "interns" and have another one judge the best output.

â†³ ğŸš€ ğ—”ğ—œ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—»ğ—²ğ˜„ ğ—–ğ—£ğ—¨ â€” AI is becoming a commodity, accessible to everyone. Your competitive moat won't come from having the best model, but from classic advantages like network effects, brand, and user experience.

â†³ ğŸ“ˆ ğ—šğ—¼ ğ—¯ğ—²ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—± ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† â€” the biggest impact of AI in development isn't just about coding faster. It's about empowering teams to tackle things they previously couldn't, like building a video streaming infrastructure with no prior experience.

author: Khushal Jhalani
full_text:
Software engineering is probably 80% writing.

And I'm not talking about code:
- Jira Tickets
- Designs docs
- Presentations
- Emails & slack
- Documentation
- Internal and external blog posts, etc.

You may not realize it, but you try to program humans more than machines.

Original Post Credits: Louie Bacaj

author: Kovid Batra
full_text:
As humans, thereâ€™s undoubtedly one thing we continuously do, sometimes without even realizing it. 


âš–ï¸ Taking decisions. 

Think about it. Every action we take involves some level of decision-making, and making decisions for ourselves can sometimes be challenging.

Now, imagine the complexities of decision-making within an engineering team, where multiple individuals, possibly from diverse cultures and backgrounds, are involved.

I wish I could offer you a secret recipe for making decisions in this context, but, unfortunately, it doesnâ€™t exist (believe me, Iâ€™ve searched for it for 10 years).

However, having robust decision-making processes within your engineering team is crucial. 

Here are the benefits:

ğŸ”¥ Focuses effort
ğŸ”„ Ensures consistency
â³ Saves time
ğŸ§­ Provides direction
ğŸ›¡ï¸ Builds resilience

So, how do you make decisions? 

There are many different approaches, including:

ğŸª– Autocratic
ğŸ§  Experiential
ğŸš€ Empowered Autonomy
ğŸ“Š Data-Driven
ğŸ—³ï¸ Majority Rule
âœ… Consensus

Choosing your approach depends on various factors, such as:

- Your role and leadership style
- Your risk aversion
- Your relationship with stakeholders
- Your team's culture
- Your company's environment
- The specific nature of the decisions to be made

And particularly, the area in which you must make those decisions.

Yes, itâ€™s a lot to digest, but youâ€™re lucky. 

As I do every Thursday, Iâ€™ve simplified a complex topic like decision-making in Engineering Teams and shared the insights with 22.1K+ people who already subscribed to The Hybrid Hacker newsletter.

author: Kristina Ayanian
full_text:
Last week we launched Account Management on Nasdaq.

It turns Pylon into the first B2B Support Platform.

Up until this point, support platforms have focused solely on ticketing.

But B2B teams need more than that. They need a holistic way to manage their customers.

We intend to serve not just the support team, but the entire post-sales team including customer success, solutions, implementation, professional services teams, so they can all share data, views, and workflows.

Releasing Account Management is a big, but not final step in this direction. We have a lot more on the way.

Thank you for the opportunity to share our vision on your show Kristina Ayanian!

Laura is one the top experts on AI + developer productivity: no fluff, just things that work, those that don't, and why.

author: Liz Houser
full_text:
Recruiters offer our sales reps $400K roles. None have left.


Our reps are having a career year.

Our AE Liz closed $3M.

Every rep is over 100% quota.
And they do it while helping each other win.

In June, we launched self-serve.
And changed our pricing structure.

But our sales team didn't complain.
They leaned in.

John closed $200K+ in one quarter after our product launch.
Sam stepped up to close HubSpot when our VP of Sales got stranded in Nebraska.
Paul closed two deals while vacationing in Italy.
Marcus booked 20% of our outbound meetings.
Steve brought in 230+ new customers.

As a founder, there are a lot of moments that make the job hard.
Getting to work with a sales team like this isn't one of them.

full_text:

Liz was selling to the CEO of a company that was recording 1M meeting hours per month.
Theyâ€™d built their own meeting recording infrastructure.

99.5% uptime.
We offered 99.9%.

Leadership wasnâ€™t impressed.
A 0.4% difference doesnâ€™t justify ripping out something you already built.

This is where most ramping AEs lose the room.

Liz didnâ€™t argue the number.
She translated it.

â€œAt your scale, thatâ€™s 4,000 meetings per month that donâ€™t get recorded. What happens, when that happens?â€

Thatâ€™s when it connected:
- Customer conversations that canâ€™t be recovered.
- Customers lose trust fast when the product â€œmissesâ€ what they said.
- Engineering gets dragged into firefighting instead of shipping product differentiators.

They signed two weeks later.

This was Lizâ€™s second monthâ€¦

At enterprise scale, decimals arenâ€™t details.
Theyâ€™re thousands of conversations that either get captured or disappear.

author: Luca Sartoni
full_text:
If you asked me what my number one skill was as a kid, I would tell you it was emulation. I was always exceptionally good at observing and emulating others.

However, as I grew up, I came to understand that merely copying others doesn't add any value and won't lead to success.

I'm also not a genius. I rarely invented something that didn't already exist.

That's why I transformed emulation into a source of inspiration. Getting inspired in the end is a skill you have to learn.

Here's how it works:

1) ğŸ‘€ Observe how someone else is successfully adding value through their actions.
2) ğŸ”„ As an exercise, try to replicate what they are doing.
3) ğŸ§  Once you've mastered the same actions, start thinking about how you can improve upon them.
4) ğŸ”‘ Make these actions your own.

That's essentially how inspiration works, at least for me and I use this simple framework for almost everything.

This is how I quickly learned:

âœï¸ Writing a newsletter:  I drew heavy inspiration from Luca Sartoni to start writing; then I began reading ğŸŒ€ Luca Rossi's newsletter, which inspired me with its format and style. I then found inspiration in other outstanding writers such as Gregor Ojstersek, John Crickett, Jordan Cutler, Irina Stanescu, Ryan Peterman, Caleb Mellas, Amy Mitchell, Neo Kim, Raviraj Achar, and so many others.
 
ğŸ¨ Creating Visuals: since I wanted to improve the visuals of my newsletter, I started searching for tutorial and courses. I found one by Janis Ozolins that quickly taught me the basics. Later, I had the opportunity to meet Roberto Ferraro, who inspired me a lot about how to improve my visuals. Lately I've been gaining inspiration from Pejman Milani, Hannah Wilson and others.

ğŸ‘¥ Linkedin: It would be challenging to mention all the people from whom I have drawn inspiration on LinkedIn. Every day brings new sources of inspiration. To name a few individuals who have recently inspired me: Sergio Visinoni, Julia Zinovieva, Ryan McKesson, Omar Halabieh, Alex EwerlÃ¶f, Mauro B., Daniel Hauck, Adrian Stanek, GÃ¡bor Till, Itzy Sabo, Anco van der Wurff

And who inspires you? I'd appreciate your suggestions for inspiring people to follow in the comments.

â™»ï¸ PLEASE REPOST IF YOU FOUND IT USEFUL, IT MEANS A LOT TO ME.

---

ğŸ¤“ Consider subscribing to The Hybrid Hacker newsletter (link in bio)

author: Maja Voje
full_text:
If you're searching for GTM tech this Black Friday, start with these:

Maja and I asked our communities about their favorite B2B GTM tools in 2025 including which were "most impactful" and which are "must try". 195 software GTM leaders weighed in. (And Gemini sorted through 1,000+ open-ended responses ğŸ¤¯.)

ChatGPT topped the list of most impactful tools with 50 write-ins. They were followed by OG HubSpot (40 write-ins) and breakout unicorn Clay (30 write-ins). This list included tried-and-true tools you're probably familiar with like LinkedIn, Gong, Notion, 6sense, Canva, Figma, Apollo & ZoomInfo.

Things got more interesting on the "must try" list. GTM leaders are trying out vibecoding (Lovable - 2nd, Replit - 5th, Magic Patterns) and AI agents (n8n - 3rd, Relay.app, Dust). Folks are also on the lookout for more & better tooling for advanced GTM plays (see: Clay, Keyplay, Unify).

If the "must try" list is any indication, we're eager to graduate beyond ChatGPT to more advanced AI use cases. But 2025 is still the year of AI experimentation vs. true impact.

Read the full 2025 State of B2B GTM report here: https://lnkd.in/ea_zYUzB

---

PS: I'm working on a new Growth Unhinged perks program. Let me know your favorite GTM tools and I'll try to help you save some $$! ğŸ™
