author: Maja Voje
full_text:
What's the right go-to-market (GTM) motion for your product? I finally have data to give you a leg up â¤µï¸

Introducing the inaugural 2025 State of B2B GTM report. Maja Voje & I teamed up to bring you objective data into what's working in GTM right now and where is AI honestly making an impact. It's based on data from 195 B2B companies, mostly SaaS and hybrids of SaaS & AI.

Get the full report in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/ea_zYUzB

The five takeaways you need to know:

1. There are six main GTM motions in B2B. Inbound is the most popular, but not by much. 

As much as people love to hate on Outbound, don't count it out. 37% of B2B companies rely on either Outbound or an Account-Based GTM.

Intent-based outbound is the 2nd most popular channel in terms of where teams plan to increase GTM budget in 2026. Outbound! (The 1st is AI discovery.)

2. 2025 was a year of (endless) exploration. The average software company says they have 5 core GTM channels and another 5.5 GTM channel experiments.

This is, frankly, too ğŸ‘ da** ğŸ‘ many ğŸ‘ channels for a $1-10M ARR business!

3. 2026 needs to be the year of ruthless scaling.

The single best channel in terms of likelihood of having an impact surprised me: intimate events.

The first-ever GTM scorecard can help prioritize where to place your bets (see the full report ğŸ‘€).

4. Everyone uses AI, relatively few see real GTM impact.

Three-in-four GTM leaders said they have top-down pressure to adopt AI. But the impact of AI is a mixed bag. More than half (53%) said they see either no impact or limited impact from AI. 

The disillusionment was most acute around AI SDRs. In the words of one survey taker, â€œWe tried an AI SDR for six months and were unable to generate a single opportunity.â€ Ouch.

5. The new GTM tech stack is mostly ChatGPT?

Thereâ€™s been a proliferation of next-gen GTM tools. Only one, ChatGPT, is having a breakout impact.

ChatGPT was rated the #1 most impactful GTM tool with roughly 50 write-in mentions. The closest alternative was OG HubSpot, which had about 40 write-in mentions. Clay came in third with nearly 30 write-ins.

---

THANK YOU to everyone who supported the survey!! ğŸ™ğŸ™
 - Kyle & Maja

author: Maja Voje
full_text:
Introducing the 2025 GTM scorecard, just in time for annual planning â¤µï¸ 

Maja and I surveyed 195 B2B leaders about which GTM channels are working right now. We then mapped how popular different GTM channels are (x-axis) versus how likely they are to be impactful among adopters (y-axis).

The shorthand for interpreting this two-by-two:
1. Tried-and-true (upper right)
2. Oversaturated (lower right)
3. The next big thing (upper left)
4. Figuring it out (lower left)

I then cut the data for startups (<$10M ARR) vs. scaleups (>$10M ARR) & it's fascinating to see how the channels shift.

The best channels for startups*:
 - LinkedIn (#1)
 - Founder brand (#2)
 - Warm outbound (#3)
 - Intent-based outbound (#4)
 - Intimate events (#5)

*The magic tends to happen when you can combine these channels into a cohesive strategy, i.e. founder brand + LinkedIn + warm outbound & intimate events for those who engage.

The best channels for scaleups*:
 - Large conferences (#1)
 - SEO (#2)
 - Intimate events (#3)
 - Big product launches (#4)
 - Ecosystem marketing (#5)

*Scaleups are still seeing returns from their years of SEO investments. The question is whether they can translate their SEO into AI discovery or if they'll be leap-frogged by new entrants.

The TL;DR: No matter what stage you're at, you might want to plan for more intimate events (dinners, happy hours, etc.) next year. They're not the most scalable, but they're one of the few things that seems to work.

PS, the full report is available here: https://lnkd.in/ea_zYUzB

author: Maja Voje
full_text:
The GTM channels that worked before donâ€™t necessarily work today. Here's which GTM channels I'm betting on in 2026 for early-stage startups versus mature scaleups:

The data comes from the State of B2B GTM report (N=195 GTM leaders) w/ Maja Voje (read it here: https://lnkd.in/ea_zYUzB)

Early-stage B2B startups (<$10M ARR)

1. The most popular core channels for early-stage B2B startups include LinkedIn (67%), founder brand (53%), warm outbound (49%), SEO (45%), and intent-based outbound (37%).

2. But popular doesnâ€™t mean effective. Perhaps unsurprisingly, startups are struggling with SEO & paid ads. More are disappointed in the returns than satisfied with them.

3. The channel that consistently performed best: intimate in-person events (think: regional dinners, happy hours, meetups, hackathons). Nearly everyone who invested here said they were happy with the results.

B2B scaleups (>$10M ARR)

1. The most popular core channels for B2B scaleups include large conferences and tradeshows (80%), LinkedIn (78%), SEO (74%), paid ads (66%), and intimate in-person events (59%).

2. Outbound, particularly automated outbound via email, fell in the over-saturated quadrant as scaleups expanded beyond $10 million ARR. (You might've seen that Ramp just killed their automated outbound team.)

3. LinkedIn stops becoming a growth channel, too. RIP.

4. The positive: events have bounced back in a major way. Large conferences and intimate events are two of the best-performing channels. People are craving personal connection as an antidote to AI slop.

5. Two less talked about channels broke into the top right quadrant for scaleups: big product launches and ecosystem marketing. 

---

2025 was a year of near-endless channel exploration. The average scaleup said they have 6.8 core GTM channels and another 6.3 GTM channel experiments! Let's resolve to make 2026 the year of ruthless scaling. 

A thought exercise to start the year: If you couldnâ€™t invest in a single new channel in 2026, what would you do differently to hit your growth targets? 

---

Shoutout to Sam Jacobs, Asad Zaman & AJ Bruno for letting me join the Topline newsletter. Check out the post here: https://lnkd.in/eXzMfGNS

We needed everyone to help get us back on track.

We hit the number 3 days before EOM.

I'm so Fing proud of this team and grateful for the work everyone is putting in.

author: Manny Medina
full_text:
Everyone seems to be talking about AI agents. The biggest problem not enough people are talking about: how to monetize & capture the value of them.

Earlier this year Manny Medina (founder of Outreach & Paid) analyzed patterns from 60+ AI agent companies to put together a new framework for AI agent pricing.

He found 4 AI agent pricing models dominating the market. Many companies are using just 1 of the 4; others take a hybrid approach.

1. Price per workflow
2. Price per agent
3. Price per agent outcome
4. Price per agent action 

CJ Gustafson and I just sat down with Christopher O'Donnell, the former chief product officer of HubSpot, on the Mostly Growth podcast. Christopher is building his own AI-native company, Day AI, to reimagine CRM for the AI age. 

Where Christopher is betting on AI pricing: price-per-AI-agent.

This opens up access for everyone to use the CRM. It unlocks unlimited usage, integrations & data. And it's predictable for customers, fitting into their mental model for how to buy a CRM.

But each core user probably needs their own dedicated AI agent with custom permissions, workflows & data access. This means pricing remains similar to per-seat pricing while being more flexible. 

Day AI can expand as customers *either* add reps (who want their own AI agent copilot) and/or embrace automation (and want more AI agents). They're covered either way.

The jury is still out on the model (IMO), but one thing is clear: it beats the proliferation of credit models coming from every direction.

---

Also in the episode: what Christopher thinks about founder mode, his favorite new AI tool (Suno), building a top social gaming app in Brazil, and the perils of ecosystems.

Catch the full podcast on YouTube, Apple or Spotify. Hope you enjoy it ğŸ™ 

ğŸ“º Watch on YouTube: https://lnkd.in/eX-xvZpk

ğŸ§ Listen on Apple: https://lnkd.in/eug-AXc8

ğŸ§ Listen on Spotify: https://lnkd.in/eZgVQcGb

author: Mark Bayer
full_text:
Big thanks to Jordan Cutler, author of the excellent, widely-read weekly newsletter High Growth Engineer. We teamed up on today's guest post in HGE about storytelling (https://lnkd.in/e-38Pd66).

As you progress in your engineering career, the strong technical skills you've demonstrated won't be enough to get you promoted to the next level. They're necessary but not sufficient.

"What got you here won't get you there."

Storytelling skills are incredibly important everywhere, but especially in tech as you move to higher levels. The job will increasingly be about convincing others of your ideas on a larger and larger scale. Storytelling does just that.

You can check out the full storytelling post using the link above and subscribe to HGE here: https://lnkd.in/e3hrW-rc.

author: Mark Roberge
full_text:
I'm on the edge and I just can't take it anymore...



Since 2020, I've been focused on building at the bleeding edge of AI and GTM as the OG GTM Engineer...

Most of that work has been speaking to other in-the-trenches practitioners, not worrying about leaving folks behind.

Today, I'm so happy to announce that Topline Media to the world... a chance to bring some of my ideas to GTM leaders around the world and not just to those on the bleeding edge.

Some stats from the team:
1. Today it takes 8000 attempts to get 1 real customer meeting.
2. It takes dozens of meetings to close a deal.
3. And then 40 months of revenue to break even on that deal.

We need actual practices to get out of this steep decline... a media outlet that is about documenting building, not talking heads.

I'd suggest you subscribe as my goal specifically when I contribute is to translate what is happening at the bleeding edge actually building workflows (Claude Code, APIs, data workflows, PVPs, PQS, my love of vertical SaaS and why) to folks who want to experiment there.

So you'll see me talk about topics like...
1. Why ICP and TAM scoring lead you way astray, and what to do instead
2. The horizontal SaaS company thought trap, and how to escape
3. The exact steps to build a useful GTM engine from absolute 0

Fellow wonderful contributors:
Mark Roberge, Gaurav Agarwal hommiee, David Spitz, Cassie Young, MEEE, Peter Walker, LatanÃ© Conant (she/her), Kyle Lacy KYLLEE, Dave Kellogg, Amy Konary, Kyle Norton KYLLLEE AS WELL, and Craig Rosenberg YOOO.

Thanks to Sam Jacobs and Asad Zaman for having me!

If you'd like to see what's happening at the edge... I suggest you subscribe...

author: Matt Webb
full_text:
I enjoyed this article by Matt Webb about how to coordinate agents that do stuff for us: https://lnkd.in/dVQdgzBz

It also made me discover Weft, which I didnâ€™t know: https://lnkd.in/dXjUwzJp

Matt argues that the best abstraction for agents is *teammates*, and so they belong to our todo lists. E.g. Linear for work (which jumped on this and smartly released â€œLinear for Agentsâ€) andâ€¦ Apple Reminders for our lives.

Personally I donâ€™t use Reminders, I use Todoist, which has an API and MCP server, so I think I will tinker with it ğŸ¤” e.g. I may turn my own workspace in a Team, add a fake person who is an agent, and assign stuff to it.

Has anyone tried something similar?

All this stuff is duct-taped for now, but to me it makes sense. Makes me think that a lot of software may end up adding first-party support for agents as individual users, which is helpful and doesnâ€™t break how we have been using tools so far.

p.s. trying to post more â€œunfilteredâ€ thoughts on Linkedin, you know, as a human, ignoring the algorithm (two links in a post?!)

author: Maude Lemaire
full_text:
What does it really take to refactor big, critical systems without breaking everything?! ğŸ—ï¸

Today I spoke with Maude Lemaire, Principal Engineer at GitHub and author of the book "Refactoring at Scale." With over 8 years of experience at Slack (through its massive growth from 100 to 1200 engineers) and now tackling GitHub's massive cloud migration, Maude has seen it all when it comes to large-scale system changes.

Here are a few takeaways from our chat:

â†³ ğŸ—£ï¸ ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—ºğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜†ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ â€” the biggest mistake in large refactoring is making changes *too* invisible. You need to make it invisible to users but loud to your engineering teams, so they can quickly debug when things inevitably break.

â†³ ğŸ¯ ğ— ğ—®ğ—¸ğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—µğ˜ ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ â€” successful platform migrations focus on adoption. Water flows downstream, so meet developers where they are and make the new way the path of least resistance.

â†³ ğŸ” ğ—–ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† ğ—¼ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ ğ—·ğ˜‚ğ—±ğ—´ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ â€” when onboarding to complex legacy systems, ask "why is it this way?" with curiosity, rather than accusation. Understanding the archaeology of decisions helps you build better solutions.

â†³ ğŸš€ ğ—§ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ ğ—¶ğ—» ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» â€” forget perfect staging environments. Production has unique traffic patterns and edge cases you'll never reproduce. Use feature flags, canaries, and embrace controlled risk.

â†³ ğŸ“ ğ—¦ğ—µğ—¶ğ—³ğ˜ ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—³ğ˜ ğ—®ğ˜€ ğ—ºğ˜‚ğ—°ğ—µ ğ—®ğ˜€ ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² â€” meet developers in their IDE with immediate feedback. Finding out your test failed after 45 minutes of CI is a table-flipping moment that kills productivity.

â†³ ğŸ½ï¸ ğ—ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—°ğ—µğ—²ğ—» ğ—°ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ ğ—®ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—´ğ˜† â€” you'll never get to 100% with big migrations. Like a lived-in kitchen, some things will always remain on the counter, and that's perfectly fine.

Check out the full conversation with Maude in the comments!

author: Maura Rivera
full_text:
My former arch rival is my guest this week. Dun dun dunnnnnnnn.

No just kidding. Trying to get a thirsty hook. That was 7-8 years ago and so much has happened since then.

One of the best parts about running Exit Five is that each week I get to chat with a top CMO in B2B, and this week my guest is Maura Rivera from Qualified.

In a world where CMOs are changing jobs every 1-2 years, Maura has been holding it down at Qualified for SIX YEARS. That deserves some type of award, and is worth unpacking (plus she told me something like half of the marketing team has been there that long too, which says a lot).

We talked about:

â€¢ Why product launches are the glue for marketing (and why you need to have this cadence of product launches and a tight relationship with the VP Product)

â€¢  What agentic marketing really means for the future of marketing, how is it different than "marketing" and why outbound isÂ actuallyÂ working for them right now (I thought outbound is dead?)

â€¢ How events have become a huge part of their strategy. Plus, plenty of good banter along the way. This was a fun one. I want to go hangout with Maura now.

Episode 310 of the Dave Gerhardt Show (that's me) aka the Exit Five podcast is out everywhere now.

author: Meg Adams
full_text:
How do you build psychologically safe teams? ğŸ›¡ï¸

This week on the podcast I had an eye-opening conversation with Meg Adams, Senior Director of Engineering at The New York Times, about the neuroscience of leadership and creating psychological safety in engineering teams.

The problem with these topics is that they always risk staying fluffy and high-level, but Meg instead was super practical and provided plenty of examples.Â 
Â 
Here are a few things I learned:

â†³ ğŸ§  ğ—§ğ—µğ—² ğ—¦ğ—–ğ—”ğ—¥ğ—™ ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹ â€” our brains respond to social situations as if they were physical threats. The five key domains are Status, Certainty, Autonomy, Relatedness, and Fairness. When threatened, we lose cognitive capacity for creative problem solving.

â†³ ğŸ¯ ğ—˜ğ—»ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—²ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ—»ğ—²ğ—²ğ—± ğ—°ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜ğ˜† ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğ—®ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¼ğ—ºğ˜† â€” engineers are particularly sensitive to knowing where the goalpost is and having control over their time and approach. Most team practices (e.g. code reviews), when handled poorly can trigger status and autonomy threats.

â†³ ğŸ—£ï¸ ğ—”ğ—°ğ—¸ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜„ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—±ğ—´ğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ˜ğ—² â€” when you can't provide certainty (like during layoff rumors), just acknowledge the uncertainty. Saying "I don't have information to share right now" still provides some certainty about the process.

â†³ ğŸ¤ ğ— ğ—¼ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¯ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ğ˜€ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—°ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ â€” cultural change happens when leaders embody good behaviors in real situations, not through abstract processes or documents. The most powerful moments come from being part of a team and demonstrating these principles.

â†³ ğŸš¨ ğ— ğ—®ğ—»ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—®ğ˜ ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—¸ â€” individual contributors have more automatic relatedness from their team. Managers have at once 1) larger surface area for triggers, and 2) rarely anyone taking care of them.

You can find the full episode in the comments!

author: Menoua Keshishian
full_text:
I didn't believe it until I saw it: but it *really* works in open offices! And you cannot even hear devs "whispering."

This is ML engineer Menoua Keshishian at Wispr Flow HQ, in SF, coding... by whispering to Cursor Agent using his mic (a BOYA Gooseneck that costs ~$70).

I was standing next to him and heard nothing. Everyone in the office does the same.

I have no affiliation with Wispr Flow (this post is not paid, I have no form of financial ties or other etc) - but saw devs like Arvid Kahl use it and swear by it. So I also gave it a go, and it slowly is growing on me for agentic coding (when more context for the agent is more helpful than less). The setup is super clever: you press and hold a usually rarey used button (the fn button on the Mac) and then Wispr "listens" and when you stop, it insers the *meaning* of what you said (not the exact transcript!). When you ramble and self-correct, it gets it right most of the time!

So when I was in SF, I stopped at their offices to say hi to the team and learn more.

CEO and cofounder Tanay Kothari told me that based on their data of 20K users anonymously analyzed, devs who use Wispr do 18% "whispering" (vs 82% typing) in month 1, and 72% "whispering" (vs 28% typing) in month 5, and it grows almost linearly until that point.

It's an interesting new trend, and AI agents are the reason it works.

I shared more details in a summary of my trip to SF, and interesting startups I met: https://lnkd.in/eGZscGXj

Update: in the comments, see notes on how whispering strains vocal cords as much as shouting - keep that in mind! My use case is I am alone in my room and talk with normal voice to the agent, similar to how James Stanier shared below. Perhaps this setup works better for those working remote / in a separate space?

author: Meri Williams
full_text:
This week I had the pleasure of speaking with Meri Williams, CTO of Pleo and long-time host of LeadDev conferences, about one of tech's most challenging topics: ğ—±ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† ğ—¶ğ—» ğ—²ğ—»ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—²ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜ğ—²ğ—®ğ—ºğ˜€ ğŸ¨

With their 10+ years at LeadDev, Meri has a unique perspective on how engineering leadership has evolved â€” and what still needs to change.

Here is what I learned from them:

â†³ ğŸ”¬ ğ——ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—µğ—®ğ—¿ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¿, ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğ˜ğ—µğ—®ğ˜'ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—½ğ—¼ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜ â€” diverse teams have to rely on data more and collaborate better to reach consensus, as opposed to relying to hidden biases. This leads to stronger decisions.

â†³ ğŸ¯ ğ—™ğ—¼ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ˜€ ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—°ğ—¹ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» â€” people who consider joining your team will ask themselves: Am I expected here? Am I respected here? Can I be myself here and be successful? Work backwards from making success possible for everyone.

â†³ ğŸŸï¸ ğ—™ğ—¶ğ˜… ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—² â€” before adding diverse talent, audit your practices. Are all social events alcohol-focused? Do meetings work for people with kids? Diversity goes beyond genders and ethnicities. Change these before expecting different people coming and fix them for you.

And of course, no chat is complete these day without talking about AI. Meri has strong opinions about how AI changes how we develop talent:

â†³ ğŸ§  ğ—ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—²ğ—»ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—²ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—®ğ—» ğ˜„ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ â€” with AI, entry-level engineers are reviewing code at a much earlier point in their career. We need to teach these skills sooner.

â†³ ğŸ—ï¸ ğ—™ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—±ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ—ºğ—®ğ˜ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—®ğ—» ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ â€” when you can create so fast with AI, understanding scalability, maintainability, and security becomes critical to avoid future disasters.

â†³ ğŸ’¬ ğ—”ğ—œ ğ—®ğ˜€ ğ—®ğ—» ğ—²ğ—»ğ—±ğ—¹ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—¹ğ˜† ğ—½ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—¿ â€” junior engineers are using ChatGPT to ask the same questions repeatedly without fear. But to get the most value, they still need to learn how to ask good questions.

You can find the full episode in the comments!

author: Michelle Lim
full_text:
What is it like to be a founding engineer at a startup, and how do you become one? Michelle Lim joined Warp as the founding engineer, and she's now a founder at Flint AI where she is hiring founding engineers. We talk through her journey and tactics helpful for anyone wanting to make an impact at a startup.

Watch or listen:
â€¢ YouTube: https://lnkd.in/ezR5MnatÂ 
â€¢ Spotify: https://lnkd.in/e9RnsiV2Â 
â€¢ Apple: https://lnkd.in/e3PZTmrG

Brought to you by:
â€¢â Â StatsigÂ â  â€” â  The unified platform for flags, analytics, experiments, and more.  https://lnkd.in/eQkXqjMZ

â€¢â Â LinearÂ â  â€” â  The system for modern product development.Â https://lnkd.in/egxywckg

I really liked how Michelle was realistic how, as a founding engineer, you have two jobs at once:

#1: Software engineering. Build the stuff you need to do

#2: Everything else to help the business succeed, including lots of things that are not to do with software engineering! Do all of these once you did job #1 well. In return, you get to learn a lot on how a business is built - which will help you if and when you become a founder yourself!

Thanks for the great convo, Michelle, and keep it up!

author: Nicole Forsgren
full_text:
Finally, someone wrote it down in a book:

To understand what is going well/poorly inside your engineering org: ask the devs what this is! Talk to a bunch of them - from different teams, seniority levels etc - and understand what's really going on.

From the excellent new book by Nicole Forsgren and Abi Noda called "Frictionless"

Arrived yesterday. So far a very timely read.

The book attempts to answer the question: "AI can generate code in minutes - so why does shipping software still take forever?"

It's a very timely one. As with Accelerate, I think this might also become a classic

You can get the book from its website: https://lnkd.in/enbcjEdP

author: Niko Bonatsos
full_text:
Niko invested in Pylon when we were 3 months old.

Today, we're worth hundreds of millions, 74 people, and 5x'ing ARR YoY.

But back when he invested, we had close to nothing...

- 10 customers
- $60k ARR
- 0 employees
- first-time founders

...with no clear story on how we'd get to $1B ARR.

But he believed in us when no one else did.

Despite our many faults, he knew that Robert, Advith, and I would find a way to make Pylon successful.

And he was right.

Working with Niko while he was at General Catalyst was an absolute pleasure. He sat on our board, responded to messages quickly (always a text message away), pushed us to be more ambitious, questioned us in the right ways, helped us make critical hires, guided us on fundraises, got us featured in TechCrunch (twice), connected us to industry contacts, helped us find customers, and so much more.

Niko is a dream investor for any early-stage founder. 

Thank you for all the ways that you helped Pylon.

We can't wait to see what you do next!

author: Omar Halabieh
full_text:
Retrospective Meetings are a waste of time!


This is what I frequently hear from both engineers and managers.

However, just yesterday, I asked for feedback from some experienced people in my network with diverse backgrounds, and most of them agreed on the effectiveness of these meetings.

ğŸ¤” Why are people so divided on this topic?

I believe, as with many other things, the significant issue lies in how this tool is used, with Scrum likely being the primary cause of this negativity.

We've become used to:

- Countless retrospectives (at the end of every sprint)
- Endless retrospectives (I've witnessed retrospectives lasting an entire day!)

It's understandable why there's so much negativity, but I believe retrospectives can be useful and run effectively.

How?

ğŸ›ï¸ Cultivating the right culture (this is a prerequisite)
ğŸ“… Knowing when to conduct retrospectives
ğŸª– Assigning the appropriate facilitator
ğŸ‘¥ Identifying the right participants
ğŸ—ï¸ Properly preparing for the meeting
ğŸ”¶ Selecting the most effective formats

Interested in learning more?

You know, it's Thursday, your lucky day, and I've just published a comprehensive guide on running effective Retrospective MeetingsğŸ‘‡

https://lnkd.in/dW-MJhCH

A special thank you to all the people who helped by sharing their feedback about retrospectives.

If you are a Software or Systems Engineer, I'm almost sure there's one aspect you are overlooking in your career growth.

Why is it crucial, even more than mastering ML, Rust, Kubernetes or other technologies? 

While tech skills are essential, public speaking is key for those aiming for leadership roles (Tech Leads and EMs).

How do I know this?

ğŸ˜¥ From personal experience, neglecting public speaking has cost me a lot of opportunities.

Why is it so important? I'll give you four reasons:

ğŸ—£ï¸ Better Communication simplifies explaining complex tech concepts.

ğŸš€ Visibility: enhances your professional profile and opens new opportunities.

ğŸ¤ Team Collaboration: improves sharing ideas and working together.

ğŸŒ± Knowledge Reinforcement: preparing talks solidifies your understanding.

So, if you are early in your career, don't make the same mistake I did. Step out of your comfort zone and start practicing public speaking.

If you need help with that, my friend Pascalle Bergmans ğŸ§šâ€â™€ï¸ has just launched an awesome course and offered a Â£50 discount for my audience.

author: Peter Walker
full_text:
I'm having some major cognitive dissonance about startup M&A. Anyone else confused? 

It *seems* to be ğŸŒ¶ï¸ with a record number of acquisitions in 2025 according to Peter Walker (see the chart). Yet Jason M. Lemkin & others are pointing out that in SaaS "the exits... are no more." What gives?!?

CJ and I discussed this with SaaS legend Dave Kellogg on today's Mostly Growth podcast. What we're seeing:

1. M&A is hot and there are buyers at the table. 

Big Tech co's increasingly need an AI story. This could be partially due to the lenient regulatory environment as well.

2. Exit *count* is up, but it's not clear if the $$ of exits are up. 

Peter Walker shared that ~75-80% of the exits are Seed/Series A companies. Many of these look more like tuck-ins or acquihires.

3. AI companies are the hottest targets. 

Some of these are AI-native (see: SFDC buying Doti & Convergence AI, Meta buying Scale AI), as expected. Others aren't AI-native but they benefit from the AI boom by *selling* to AI companies (see: OpenAI buying Statsig).

4. There's less & less interest for "good-not-great" SaaS companies.

The best liquidity path is probably PE. Yet PE might be unwilling to pay anywhere near the price of the last VC round. And PE can afford to be highly selective, looking for profitable market leaders who they can make AI-powered.

5. Know your target buyer & position the business to be attractive for them.

If that's PE, buyers want to see (a) profitability, (b) market leadership -- likely in a specific vertical, (c) stickiness, and (d) a SaaS + AI story. If that's BigTech, buyers want to see growth (ideally 30%+) + Rule of 40 + a clear fit with their 3-5 year roadmap.

---

Also in today's episode: it's the end of the ARR era and Dave feels fine, scheduling norms, whether your weekly martini counts as ARR, Instacart memberships, credit card perks & Dave's favorite dictation app (Wispr Flow).

author: Pranav Piyush
full_text:
How often do you take risks in marketing? New ideas, experiments, etc.

I've done over 300 hours of interviews with VPs and CMOs. I spend my days talking to marketers (the real ones, currently doing the work) and I think the one thing that "creative" and "risk taking" marketing teams have in common:

Someone at the top actually gives a shit.

They actually care about marketing. They have taste. They know that marketing is not some magic coin operated machine. That you must spend money to make money. That you must try new things and find new channels because the opportunities often appear where the competitors are not.

On Friday Matt and I were on a call with a VP Marketing at a $40M revenue IT company; he said they STOOD OUT because all of their competitors were running ads on one platform (you can guess) but none of them were running ads over here. Guess what working? Running ads where competitors were not active.

No annoying question from the CMO or CFO "well our competitors are showing up in Google Search ads, why aren't we?" Because that was an intentional strategy decision.

So it's not some rogue marketer: it's about the team, the leadership. Do they actually give a shit about marketing? Do they understand how marketing works? And what great marketing requires?

Listen to a Pranav Piyush here talk about how he is approaching advertising at Paramark (clip from a webinar we did on marketing experiments and testing)

Great marketers have strong opinions! They take chances! Don't let the CFO run marketing!

author: Pranav Piyush
full_text:
Why are you asking about marketing attribution?

To measure marketing's impact?
Is it about getting credit? 
Is it about proving what was sales sourced vs. marketing sourced?
Is it to make a point to the CFO?

Pranav Piyush was VP Marketing at Bill . com and worked in Growth at Adobe and Dropbox. 

Today he spends his time trying to help marketers solve the measurement at Paramark; he brings a sharp point of view on attribution, channel performance, and how to actually prove whatâ€™s working across your paid media mix.

He makes a bunch of these concepts easy to understand, and my favorite principle of his is STOP TREATING YOUR CUSTOMERS LIKE MORONS (all caps).

This is a time of year when many marketers are thinking about channel bets and campaigns for 2026, and this is a good episode to revisit from the spring.

We covered:

â€¢ Why most marketers are misusing the word â€œtestâ€ and how to run true experiments with lift, control, and causality
â€¢ How even small teams can apply experiment design (on a $10K budget or less) to make smarter spend decisions

This was from episode # 259 of "The Dave Gerhardt Show" if you search for it; you can find all episodes on YouTube and Spotify.

author: Rahul Pandey
full_text:
One of my early career mistakes was believing that 'expertise' is difficult or impossible to attain.

A Staff Engineer at Pinterest exposed my mistake: within 2 weeks, he knew more about the codebase than me, even though I had been working in that area for a year.

Not only did he ramp up dramatically faster, he was able to understand the abstractions far better than me. 

After a few more weeks, he understood several abstractions and libraries more deeply than anyone in the entire company.

Expertise is not something you magically get when you become senior enough. It's a prerequisite for seniority, and you can start building expertise today.

You can become more knowledgeable than anyoneÂ as long as you narrow the scope appropriately. e.g. "In one afternoon, I can understand more about the flags to configureÂ git logÂ compared to anyone on my team of 10 people."

Jordan Cutler talks more about this in his guide about becoming the go-to expert as a software engineer: https://lnkd.in/gBvqibJ2

author: Rob Bowley
full_text:
Have ChatGPTs and other LLM based generative AI models already reached their zenith?

AsÂ Louie BacajÂ says in the screenshot, once sites like StackOverflow go, the quality of the content fed into LLMs goes down.

LLMs will also cannibalise themselves as they begin to feed off more and more LLM generated content.

Additionally, it's likely more sites will block LLMs from harvesting content as they're eating into their business models (as Twitter & Reddit already have).

So it's quite possible LLM output quality has already reached a zenith point (there are reports that OpenAI ChatGPT quality has already gone down, but due to cost saving efforts).

#aiÂ #generativeaiÂ #artificialintelligenceÂ #llmsÂ #largelanguagemodels

author: Rob Litterst
full_text:
2025 will be remembered as the year when seemingly everybody lost confidence in their pricing. Among the top 500 players in SaaS and AI with transparent pricing, there were more than 1,800 pricing changes in 2025 alone.

Thatâ€™s a staggering 3.6 pricing changes per company.Â Some, like Lovable, made a meaningful pricing change every ğŸ‘ single ğŸ‘ month in 2025.

I enlisted help from Rob Litterst, co-founder of pricing intelligence platform PricingSaaS, to give readers a tactical rundown of what happened and what (if anything) seems to be working in SaaS pricing.

Here's the TL;DR. Read the full report here: https://lnkd.in/eptCbRBz

Trend 1: Credit models exploded in popularity, up 126% YoY

Most credits models fall into one of four buckets based on this 2x2: (a) is it more customer-friendly or vendor-friendly? & (b) are credits cost-based or value-based?

 - AI credits as product feature (see: HubSpot, Adobe)
 - AI credits as a creative sandbox (see: Lovable, Replit)
 - AI credits as enterprise infra (see: Figma, Cursor)
 - AI credits as a pass-through utility (see: Clay, PostHog)

Trend 2: The great re-bundling of AI

The more credit models flood the marketplace, the more customers will want to return to simplicity. In 2025 the pendulum swung toward credits. In 2026 it'll likely swing back toward simplicity and predictability.

Some of the biggest names in SaaS -- including Notion, Slack & Loom -- launched their first AI product as an add-on, and have since bundled that functionality into their core pricing model. Each had charged between $4 to $10 per user for an AI add-on. Now they're bundling AI and raising prices by between $2.50 and $5 per user.

Trend 3: Making seat-based pricing work harder

As companies introduce more complex pricing models, seats look customer-friendly by comparison.

Companies doing this well are layering additional value dimensions on top of the seat. Instead of a seat being just permission to log in, a seat becomes a gateway to more product capability, more automation, more consumption, more outcomes, or more flexibility.

Trend 4: The emergence of choose-your-own-pricing

For the past decade, vendors held most of the leverage: long-term contracts, rigid license models, and extractive pricing practices were staples of the legacy playbook. 

AI breaks that model. The demand for optionality is reshaping how SaaS companies think about pricing.

---

The full report has a ton of different examples & screenshots to help you shape your 2026 pricing strategy. Hope you find it useful.

 -KP

---

Today's post is supported by Metronome who just launched a new 5-minute quiz to help you find your ideal pricing model (link in comments).

Here are some of the things I learned:

author: Robert Eng
full_text:
My parents immigrated to the US in 1996.

They never could've imagined that their son would ring the Nasdaq closing bell in Times Square (thanks to Pylon being on this year's Enterprise 30 list).

My Co-Founders (Robert, Advith) and I are so thankful to our team who has been working tirelessly for the past 2 years and 4 months to get us to this point. I'm so happy the hard work is being recognized.

Thank you to our early customers who made bets on the team and product, and could see where Pylon could go long term. We're working incredibly hard to be a great long-term partner for you.

In 7 years I hope we'll come back to Nasdaq and go public.

Lots of hard work until then.

Onwards.


--

If you haven't heard of Pylon, we're building the first Customer Support Platform built for B2B.

12 of this year's Enterprise 30 list are already customers! 

What's a B2B Support Platform?

Imagine if Zendesk (Support Ticketing) and Gainsight (Customer Success) had a baby.

One platform for your entire post-sales team.

That's Pylon.

author: Robert Eng
full_text:
The secret behind our product process?

It's still founder-led by Robert and Advith. 

They are deeply involved in every step.

They...

â†’ talk to customers (3-4 calls / day)
â†’ participate in design reviews (weekly)
â†’ understand business context (market)
â†’ work directly with design, eng, support, CS, sales

So many companies hand off product early on but we've seen it as so critical that it's one of the last things we wanted to hand off.

That said... given our multi-product vision, we need PMs to join the team.

If you'd like to work directly with founders and eventually have me post about you on LinkedIn...

Apply! JD in comments.


-- Notes --

- They are helped by working with an absolutely cracked design team (Wendy, Oliver, Ben) and engineers, with no middle-men in-between.

- Do I as CEO get involved with product decision making? Almost entirely no. The honest reason is Advith and Robert are way better at it than I am. I learned this the hard way at the start of the company. For almost every debate we'd have about product, they would have the right intuition on what made sense. It's truly incredible to watch and results in almost no throw away work for our team.

author: Robert Eng
full_text:
Here's how we split work among 3 co-founders 2 years in... 

â†’ I own Sales + Marketing
â†’ Robert owns Migrations + Product + Design
â†’ Advith owns Post-Sales + Product + Engineering

Everything else gets punted elsewhere.


-- Notes --

1/ All three of us come from software engineering backgrounds

2/ When we started all three of us worked on engineering and sales (the only two jobs that existed). Three months in we started to specialize more and that's continued as a trend as new business critical projects have come up (e.g. Migrations came up in the past couple quarters)

3/ Notice all of this work is core product + GTM work. There are other categories but those we try to minimize time on only as needed or try to have other team members pick them up

4/ Strategy is a shared responsibility. It feels like an living organism where if one of us feels something we immediately bring it up and have longer discussions

author: Robert Eng
full_text:
INTRODUCING PYLON'S NEW BRAND!

Our previous brand developed organically from Robert Eng's original logo design and my very basic design skills.

We wanted our new brand to be more refined, and something that would scale with us longer-term.

We anchored the new brand in the idea of support, drawing inspiration from the structural supports of bridges and architectural plans to reflect strength, reliability, and scalability.

The general theme is light, includes shades of various bright colors that we can associate with new platform functionality, structures that we can combine to represent different product concepts, and is easy for non-designers to use.

We're really excited to finally share it with you here.


--

Thank you to both Karine Hsu and the Slope team, and Wendy Vang and Oliver R. on our own team for helping put this new brand together.

author: Robert Eng
full_text:
This video re-surfaced of our old office. It shows how raw the early days were... Normalized chaos, mattresses on the ground, and a sense of scrappy energy.

This was technically our second office. The first was just working out of Robert and Advith's apartment during YC. Then after, we moved out as we brought on our first hire.

We (founders) both lived and worked out of this space for about a year until the team was ~10 people. The rest of the team would commute in and work together in the common area.

It was so packed by the end that our founding AE's desk was feet away from Advith's bed.

It was so much fun.

The space had such great energy and excitement.

And for those wondering, yes we did make people take their shoes off as they entered ğŸ˜‚


--

Fast forward to today, we took over the UserTesting building (now "the Pylon building") right across from the SF Caltrain station. The team has grown 4x since then and we're firing on all cylinders.

We're building, selling, and hiring. 

There are so many ways you can get involved...

author: Roberto Ferraro
full_text:
We often come across the motto 'Lead with Heart,' and, while it's intriguing, I believe it's not entirely accurate.

ğŸ’¡ Lead both with head and heart, instead.

This imho falls under the concept of 'Emotional Intelligence', which involves the ability to recognize, understand, and manage our own emotions, as well as the capacity to recognize, understand, and influence the emotions of others.

But how do you achieve that?

ğŸ¤” Self-Awareness: recognize your feelings and their impact on those around you. It involves being honest with yourself and having confidence in who you are.

ğŸŒ€ Self-Regulation: understand your emotions and think before reacting. Adapt to changes without losing control.

ğŸ’ Compassion: understand the feelings of others, treat them with care, without becoming emotionally involved in their experiences.

ğŸ¤ Develop Social Skills: build positive relationships and guide people effectively. Communicate transparently, resolve conflicts, and connect with others.

Curious to hear about how you work on developing your Emotional Intelligence, let me know in the comments ğŸ™‚ğŸ‘‡

Visual inspired by Roberto Ferraro ğŸ™‚


â™»ï¸ PLEASE REPOST IF YOU FOUND IT USEFUL, IT MEANS A LOT TO ME.

---

author: Roberto Ferraro
full_text:
In my life, I've seen many experts become somewhat annoyed by others asking questions. 


â›½ï¸ However, questions are what fuel the engine of innovation.

Without them, many things we take for granted today would not exist.

Let me give you some examples.

ğŸŒ The Internet: it began as a question about how computers at different locations could communicate with each other effectively.

ğŸ“± Smartphones: the development of smartphones started with questions about combining the functionality of a phone and a computer.

ğŸ’¡ Electricity: the exploration of electricity started with simple questions about the nature of lightning and static.

ğŸ’‰ Vaccines: the development of vaccines began with questions about how to prevent diseases and how the immune system works.

ğŸš€ Space Exploration: questions about what lies beyond Earth led to the entire field of space exploration and technology.

How this relates with leadership?

Easy. 

Leadership is about fostering an environment where questioning is encouraged, as it drives innovation. 

When you come across people keen to challenge the status quo, don't block their path; support them instead, as they could become key contributors to your team's success.

Visual inspired by a conversation I had with Roberto Ferraro ğŸ™‚

â™»ï¸ PLEASE REPOST IF YOU FOUND IT USEFUL, IT MEANS A LOT TO ME.

author: Roberto Ferraro
full_text:
It took me years to learn one fundamental skill that is crucial for both leaders and engineers.


ğŸ‘‚ Active Listening.

I'm sure you've already heard about it, but what does it mean to listen actively?

I like to break it down this way:

ğŸ”¥ Focus: listen intentionally and make eye contact to show you are completely engaged.

ğŸ‘€ Observe: it might seem counterintuitive, but observing nonverbal cues is a part of actively listening to someone.

ğŸ§  Reflect: consider the speaker's words to fully grasp their meaning and implications.

ğŸ™‹â€â™€ï¸ Ask: Interact with the speaker by asking questions to clarify points and encourage further discussion.

â¸ï¸ Breathe: pause and take a breath, allowing for better processing of information and preventing hasty reactions.

ğŸ“ Remember: journal after conversations, so in the follow-ups, you can demonstrate to the other person that you genuinely care and remember.

ğŸ¤— Empathize: connect with the speaker's emotions by showing understanding of their feelings and perspectives. Just ensure not to become overly involved.

For me, it took years to develop sufficient active listening skills, and I am still working to improve them.

And you? Ar you a good active listener?

author: Ryan Peterman
full_text:
Software engineers shouldn't only grow through years of experience.

Improving this way is too slow and passive. I got promoted to Staff in 3 years by:

- Working with talented peers
- Taking on larger and larger scope projects
- Having incredible managers and mentors
- Focusing on impact over all else

Time only helps so much, optimizing your growth rate and impact are much more important.

author: Ryan Peterman
full_text:
If you're a software engineer looking to grow from anything from soft skills to technical skills, here are some up-and-coming free newsletters that you'll find helpful: 

1. System Design Newsletter by Neo Kim - Breaks down real-world engineering examples to teach system design https://lnkd.in/gewfQQVh

2. Byte-Sized Design by Alex Nguyen - Digestible case studies to help you learn from how large companies design their systems https://lnkd.in/gdekpcG3

3. Engineer's Codex - Provides regular deep dives and learnings from big tech companies https://lnkd.in/gDJAXfrv

4. Tech Lead Mentor by Raviraj Achar - He shares tons of learnings from growing to Staff with experience from Meta and Microsoft https://lnkd.in/gGiy4778

5. High Growth Engineer by Jordan Cutler - He writes a concise newsletter packed with actionable takeaways for engineers https://lnkd.in/gZDg5_nj

6. Hybrid Hacker by Nicola Ballotta - Writes about engineering management and general software engineering careers https://lnkd.in/gsWpmjNJ

7. Tech World With Milan by Dr Milan MilanoviÄ‡ - He shares about tech industry trends and helpful technical deep dives https://lnkd.in/gHq7ZnWn

8. Refactoring by ğŸŒ€ Luca Rossi - His writing style is easy to digest and covers everything from soft skills to software engineering https://lnkd.in/gmpKzuud

9. Engineering Leadership by Gregor Ojstersek - One of the publications focused on engineering management and leadership topics https://lnkd.in/gWpnKyPe

10. EcZachly Data Engineering Newsletter by Zach Wilson - He shares his story on fast data engineering career growth at FAANG-like companies https://lnkd.in/g-bRiACH

11. Seattle Data Guy's Newsletter by Benjamin Rogojan - Learning a lot about data engineering from his regular technical posts https://lnkd.in/g6SfPau4

12. FAANG FIRE by Andre Nader - This newsletter has taught me a good bit about personal finance https://lnkd.in/gDmwNdqB

13. Wes Kao's newsletter - Her writing has tons of learnings for all working professionals https://lnkd.in/g3zdd-Bc

14. Level Up Software Engineering by Caleb Mellas - His writing is packed with learnings that can help you grow to Senior https://lnkd.in/gcQgHAad

15. Musings Of A Caring Techie by Irina Stanescu - Her newsletter is refreshing since it talks about leadership, self-development, and mental health in tech https://lnkd.in/gj7_NTqY

16. Leading Developers by Anton Zaides - Learn practical advice from mistakes he made so you can avoid them https://lnkd.in/gbr5YGEj

This definitely doesn't cover all of them, what's your favorite newsletter?

author: Ryuichi Kubuki
full_text:
Pinch me: my book is this week's best-seller in Japan's largest book store:

The photo is from Kinokuniya Shinjuku, the flagship bookstore complex in the Shinjuku district of Tokyo. It is probably the most famous and historic book retailer in Japan. It's a multi-floor shop with a massive selection, known for its wide range of specialized books. You can see two copies of The Software Engineer's Guidebook on the top shelf on the picture.

The Japanese version of The Software Engineer's Guidebook launched two weeks ago, translated by Ryuichi Kubuki (thank you for the phenomenal work!) published by O'Reilly Japan. Oâ€™Reilly told me that the book was temporarily out of stock for a few days, thanks to stronger-than-expected demand.

I love how the book's cover is very different from the English version - though if you zoom in you can see "The Software Engineer's Guidebook" in English showing up on the left side of the book.

If you live in Japan, you can order the book on Amazon Japan and find it in book stores: https://lnkd.in/e7FE2EXB

And also on the best seller list - and on the bottom right part of the photo - isÂ  the Japanese version of the excellent AI Engineering book byÂ Chip Huyen! Chip's book is a masterpiece, I recommend it to anyone and everyone who would like to get up to speed on building on top of LLMs.

author: Sam Stahl
full_text:
Our founding AE interviewed with 20+ startups before choosing us. His framework for picking the right bet is brutal - and every candidate should steal it.

Sam Stahl was sitting in a hotel room in Mexico, injured from surfing, deciding where to work next. 

He realized he only had a few shots at finding the right early-stage company - each choice would cost him years, so he needed to choose wisely.

His filter:
1/ Seed stage only (mission intact)
2/ YC company (best hit rate for identifying winners)
3/ founders who sold the first $1M themselves (red flag when they hire sales to â€œfigure it outâ€)
4/ technical product (he loves technical buyers)

Other founders promised heâ€™d â€œbuy a lamboâ€ after selling $800K.
We told him: â€œYou could join us and we could fail tomorrow. this is risky, and we donâ€™t want to get your hopes up.â€

That pragmatism sealed it.

He said he spent more time evaluating whether he wanted to work with us than our metrics.
â€œDo I like these people?â€
â€œAre they good communicators?â€
â€œWould I trust them in the trenches 12+ hours a day?â€

Thatâ€™s why Sam chose Recall.ai.
And why heâ€™s still here more than 2 years later.

author: Sheril Mathews
full_text:
â€œAsk and you shall receive.â€
But in leadership, itâ€™s often the opposite.

Give and only then you shall receive. ğŸ‘‡

Give energy + engagement to get more energy + engagement.
Give more responsibility, in order to get more responsibility.

Give open communication, to get open communication.
Give trust, in order to be trusted.

Instead leaders inadvertently often do the opposite.Â 
Eg expecting people to trust them, but donâ€™t trust their own people.

Leadership is an amplification mechanism.Â 
Whatever you do gets amplified and comes back to you 10X.Â 
There is nowhere to hide. 

You can do the opposite but itâ€™s not sustainable in the long run.
This is not a morality position.
Rather, itâ€™s a performance position. 

Teams with the above characteristics simply outperform others in the long run.

Which one would you rather have?

#leadership #management

author: Sidwyn Koh
full_text:
As engineers, our greatest tool isnâ€™t our code.

Itâ€™s our writing.

Writing helps us share ideas, align teams, and explain decisions. 

Writing well makes everything clearer and more impactful.

Hereâ€™s how I write better at work:

1/ Know your audience: Who will read this? What do they already know? Tailor your writing to their needs.

2/ Clarify your core message: What am I trying to convey? Use short sentences. Avoid jargon when possible.

3/ Continuously edit your work: Your first draft is never perfect. I always read and tweak my writing multiple times.

4/ Seek feedback from senior folks: Reach out to senior engineers to review and give feedback. Their perspectives are valuable.

P.S. Want to write like a senior engineer? Jordan Cutler and I are launching WriteEdge â€“ a platform to help you write tech specs & project updates like a senior engineer. Get simulated feedback from tech leads, product managers, and CTOs. Check it out:

author: Simon Willison
full_text:
Ironic: as LLMs make writing much easier, I am finding not more, but less interesting and novel things to read online.

And so I keep paying more attention to the fewer people who still write their original thoughts (without LLMs - you can tell how repetitive / pattern matching it gets with them, including on LinkedIn.)

By â€œinteresting thingsâ€ I mean when people share their own experiences, connecting the dots, own speculation/analysis etc.

Eg learnings they had on stuff they recently did, and so on.

Anyway, power to those who didnâ€™t forget writing helps you think and reflect as well!

Examples of people who I keep paying attention to thanks to writing about their experiences: Simon Willison and Sean Goedecke on their respective blogs, where they publish regularly: https://simonwillison.net/ and https://lnkd.in/dk7Ywgxm

author: Sophie Z. Novati
full_text:
AI doesn't make you a 10x engineer at ALL times.

It makes you a 10-100x engineer temporarily, for very specific situations.

â€¢ When you can get a 10-hour task done in 1 hour
â€¢ When you can spin up 5 prototypes in ways you couldn't have before because it would have been too much effort
â€¢ When you can take on tasks you wouldn't have before because the ROI wouldn't have been high enough

But you need to know which situations this ^ actually works.

Here are 3 situations where you'll actually get things done 10x faster:
1. Research

âŒ DONT: Painstakingly go through 10-20 links from Google and collect everything into a report
âœ… DO: Ask Perplexity or GPT Deep Research and have it compile the entire report for you

2. Writing tests

âŒ DONT: Write all your test cases by hand, line-by-line
âœ… DO: The test setup, then use agent mode to have it generate all cases and test itself until the test passes

3. Communicating your impact

âŒ DONT: Write your self-review and submit the first draft
âœ… DO: Write your self-review (or have AI generate a first draft), then tell it to act as your manager crafting the highest quality, most clear review possible and give you suggestions. Work with it like a partner.

--
P.S. If you liked these suggestions, check the latest High Growth Engineer article covering even more of them, with the exact prompts. Sophie Z. Novati, CEO of Formation, shares what she and the thousands of engineers she teaches have been using.

Get the tips here: https://lnkd.in/ewVxiq9F

author: Stacy Pavlyshyna
full_text:
You shouldn't always listen to customers.

I went on Ramen Talks with Stacy Pavlyshyna (co-founder at Awesomic) to talk about building a company and why...

1/ You should talk to your customers all the time, but not necessarily build exactly what they ask for

2/ Choosing your co-founders is more important than choosing an idea

3/ To us, optimizing for fun and adventure is way more compelling than optimizing for money or passion


We also talk about new challenges at this stage...

â†’ Focusing on winning market, now that we have product/market fit
â†’ Managing higher burn and spend as the team grows
â†’ Scaling every function to hit the next level of revenue

Thank you to Stacy and the team at Awesomic for having me on the show!

Watch the full episode here: https://lnkd.in/gUt4bMEG

author: Steve McConnell, CFPÂ®
full_text:
Code CompleteÂ is one of the most enduring books on software engineering.Â Steve McConnell, wrote the 900-page handbook just five years into his career, capturing what he wished heâ€™d known when starting out. Decades later, the lessons remain relevant, and Code Complete is still a best-seller.

Steve rarely gives interviews, so I hope you enjoy this special one, going into Steve's software engineering career principles, what has (not) changed since publishing Code Complete, the importance of focused personal energy, and more.

Watch or listen: 
â€¢ YouTube: https://lnkd.in/eZCYBm4UÂ 
â€¢ Spotify: https://lnkd.in/ew2pVNnxÂ 
â€¢ Apple: https://lnkd.in/eU3UyGNi 

Brought to you by:
â€¢ StatsigÂ â  â€” â  The unified platform for flags, analytics, experiments, and more. Check them out: https://lnkd.in/eQkXqjMZ

â€¢ Linear â€” The system for modern product development. Try it yourself: https://lnkd.in/eHCspybm

---

An interesting topic that Steve has never written about, but we went into detail: the importance of focused personal energy. In Steve's words:

"A topic that I don't think I've ever written about, but that is worth just throwing on the table, is that focused application of personal energy makes up for a lot of other deficiencies.

In startup mode, when you're talking about not having well-defined roles, if everybody's actually working in a focused way and they care about getting work done and they're applying a lot of energy: mistakes aren't a big deal! You just go in and you fix it. You've got the energy to do it.

If you're working in a super process-oriented way and people are thinking half about their home life, and they're checked out, and now they're 45 instead 27. Not that that's a universal pattern or anything, but if you don't have the same level of personal energy to correct mistakes, the mistakes linger. They affect more people, affect more downstream products, work products, and it just becomes a much bigger deal."

Thank you Steve for the great conversation - and for writing this book!

author: Tanmay Munigala
full_text:
I just finished Louie Bacaj's excellent "Timeless Career Advice For Software Engineers" course!

Here are my top 10 takeaways from it:

1. Stick to startups/high-growth or big tech companies for a meaningful tech career

- Startups/high-growth companies to optimize for responsibility/scope
- Big tech companies to optimize for learning engineering best practices and compensation
- Work at companies where software directly ties to revenue (the product is the software itself)

2. Focus on ownership

- Stick to companies where software engineers are empowered to own and maintain their code (even after it's rolled out)
- Develop an ownership mindset - it's not your fault, but it's your responsibility

3. Deliver massive value

- What 20% of work will get you 80% of the results? Focus on that
- Make your code functional first
- Think about performance in B2C companies and maintainability in B2B companies

4. Develop an abundance mindset

- Find problems and opportunities to create more value in your product/system for your customers
- More problems you solve -> More resources for your company -> More rewards for you and your team

5. Build up your people skills

- Double down on relationships at work
- Empathise with your teammates and customers
- Learn to communicate effectively in conversations and meetings

6. Grow your influence through writing and speaking

- Write blog posts about your work - free credibility for you and your company
- Leverage opportunities to speak and present in meetings and presentations
- A public body of work >>> your resume
- Setup team and (eventually) company-wide initiatives. Ex: tech-talks, design reviews

7. Understand how promotions work

- Understand what the company values and deliver it. Different companies value different things
- Add value, make noise (in that order)
- Perform at the next level, and you'll be there soon

8. Leverage the power of 1 on 1 meetings

- Most important meetings of your career
- Take ownership of setting up 1 on 1's with key people - peers, product people, engineers and leaders (even from other teams) 

9. Nail your mid-year and annual reviews

- Take notes about your work and achievements weekly
- Write an excellent review for yourself

10. Master engineering concepts

- Data structures and algorithms
- One functional and one object-oriented language
- Design patterns and system design
- Concurrency and asynchronous programming
- Scalability, reliability and DevOps
- Domain-driven design

Lots more I couldn't cover here! 

Highly recommend checking it out for a holistic guide to a meaningful software engineering career - https://lnkd.in/gu4jWtXk

#careeradvice #softwareengineering #coding

author: Teresa Nesteby
full_text:
Out of our first 100 customers, only 1 has churned. 

Here's why that's so surprising...

When we signed them, Pylon was just a Zendesk integration for B2B companies to scale Slack support. 

Fast forward to now, we've expanded to...

1/ More channels (Teams, Discord, Telegram, in-app chat, email, ticket forms)

2/ AI agents and assistants

3/ Account Intelligence (AI-native Gainsight)

4/ Product Intelligence (AI feature request tracking)


The product has changed, and our customers have grown with us. 

Thank you to our oldest customers for your ongoing support. Special shoutout to Teresa Nesteby at Hightouch for being the first!

We're honored to build the best support platform for your teams.

author: Thiago Ghisi
full_text:
Iâ€™ve delivered 100+ large features over last 10+ years as an Engineer/Manager/Director, here is a lesson I learned 3 years ago that completely changed the game:

> A bad & unclear decision (yet intentional) is better than no decision in 99% of cases.

This might seem extreme/unproductive, but isnâ€™t.

Without a larger plan, there are some technical decisions you just canâ€™t make decisively. 

â€”> Are you all aiming for Future State A or Future State B? 

Teams often hedge and avoid making the small decisions because they donâ€™t know what the big ones will be.

Not making a decision might end up being worse than any of the decisions on the table would have been. 

This especially shows up with architectural decisions, where teams donâ€™t commit to one approach or another, and end up trying to be flexible enough to support both.

It is better to make a "bad & wrong decision" today (and fail/revisit and improve later) than no decision today and tomorrow with the "illusion" that a perfect decision or solution will appear tomorrow.

In my experience, most projects fail or get delayed not because developers are slow, but because the analysis paralysis of over-engineering that slows down the decisions that the team, the department or the company has to make to move things forward even when they donâ€™t have all the info.

And, in my experience, when you have an aggressive deadline or release target (as it was almost always the case for me and my teams in those high-performing/hyper-growth companies), you will never have all the info you need. Or, when you have that, it will be way too late.

Practice: 24-Hour Decision Making.

Promoting the idea that making a decision & iterating on it even when there is some disagreement is better for the team in the long-term than spending a lot of time trying to local optimize a decision with a lot of unproductive discussions.

Having a winner or a losser in a discussion/decision is less important to us than moving forward and iterating on things as a team and getting real feedback from users (it could be even internal/alpha users) from the production environment (it could be from the staging in some cases as well) after have gone full cycle (from requirements to deployment) and end-to-end (from database to UX).

On Slack Threads that go wild for a few hours or Pull Requests that get stuck for more than 1 day:

Here is how we did it:

Thread in m1-us-payments-v2

> thiagoghisi: 

â±24-Hour Decision Pending starting now: 

> Sep 22 at 3pm EST:

> Question to be answered: How do we want to handle Back Navigation on Global Payments for Radio Selectors as Payment Amount, Payment Date & Bank Account?

------ after a sync ------

> Sep 23 at 330pm EST:

â±Time to decision: 24 hours and 30 minutes.

> Decision: Make tapping on back button after selecting Payment Date, Payment Amount & Bank Account will be required for both iOS and Android for all cases. cc/ ...

> Link to ADR: ...

author: Thiago Ghisi
full_text:
Can you let go of your tech identity? And what happens when you do?

This week I spoke with my friend Thiago Ghisi, former Director of Engineering at Nubank, who quit his job seven months ago to go on a sabbatical. Not only that. After 15+ years in tech at companies like Thoughtworks and Apple, he is now starting a PhD in psychology.

So this isn't your typical "I traveled the world" story. Thiago used Claude Code to analyze 20 years of his own data â€” emails, notes, highlights, conversations â€” to better understand himself. And he is now putting everything to good use.

It was an incredible chat, and here are a few takeaways:

1) ğ—Ÿğ—²ğ˜ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—´ğ—¼ ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸ ğ—¶ğ—±ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† â€” it's hard to stop measuring yourself by productivity. The rational mind wants to do what â€œan engineering director should doâ€, but real discovery comes from following your curiosity.

2) ğ—£ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¹ğ˜† ğ—ºğ—®ğ—¸ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜€ğ—² ğ—¯ğ—®ğ—°ğ—¸ğ˜„ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—±ğ˜€ â€” if you optimize for short-term results, you'll keep doing what you always did. Connecting the dots takes months, not days.

3) ğ—–ğ—¹ğ—®ğ˜‚ğ—±ğ—² ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—±ğ—² ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—³-ğ—±ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—°ğ—¼ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜† â€” Thiago parsed Gmail, LinkedIn, Kindle highlights, and years of notes into markdown repos. He traced when ideas first appeared in his life and found material for therapy exercises.

4) ğ—–ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—®ğ—» ğ˜ƒğ˜€ ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—¿ğ˜ğ˜† ğ—³ğ˜‚ğ—²ğ—¹ â€” doing things because of deadlines or guilt is "dirty fuel." Clean fuel is working on something bigger than yourself, driven from the inside out rather than the outside in.

5) ğ—”ğ˜€ğ—¸ ğ˜„ğ—µğ—¼ ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜€ğ—½ğ—¶ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ â€” is it people who did one thing their whole life, or polymaths who reinvented themselves? Your answer reveals what you actually want.

author: Thiago Ghisi
full_text:
What type of manager are you?

Are you:
- An Operator, focused on stability and execution?
- A Guide, nurturing your team culture?
- A Driver, pushing for change? Or
- A Catalyst, inspiring your team to evolve?

These days I am reviewing the top articles we published this year, and I keep going back to the one about engineering manager archetypes, written with my friend Thiago Ghisi.

Thiago designed two axes along which you can place yourself â€” one about people vs execution, and another about stability vs change. There is so much you can understand about your role (and about yourself) by thinking about what you prioritize in these tradeoffs.

I find these quadrants useful in many ways:
â€“ I can reflect on what I *default* to â€” the style that fits my personality best.
â€“ I can reflect on what my team needs right now. E.g. is it time to nurture culture and tighten screws, or just create momentum and ship fast?
â€“ I can reflect on my team composition. Do we overly skew in some direction? Do we need more (or less) of some of these?

It's a handy mental model that I added to my EM *tools*.

What about you? Do you see yourself in some of these categories?

GitHub Copilot either is getting ~100% adoption (unlikely) or itâ€™s expanding the dev pool (likely!) or this number could include many people who are no -developers and not really â€œusingâ€ GH Copilot (could be - Microsoft doesnâ€™t make it clear what qualifies as a user, but itâ€™s safe to assume itâ€™s a paid account!)

Iâ€™m assuming this number means the number of accounts that are paid for this plugin - and companies donâ€™t like to pay for something their staff wonâ€™t use.

So we could see more people doing what accounts for professional software development with these LLM-powered coding tools! (So much for what many non-developers said recently: how AI tools would be reducing the need for software engineers? Which was nonsense to start with for anyone who built software and also used these toolsâ€¦)

author: Torsten Walbaum
full_text:
This one communication shift took my friend from rejections to landing a senior 270k offer in big tech.

âŒ Before, he'd get a question like, "Tell me about how you made an impact on your team."

And he'd answer like, "Yeah, there was this one time... < speak for a minute on the story >... oh and there was this other time too... < another one >." 

But the interviewer would already be lost by the end of the first one. They want someone senior, someone who can take a step back first.

I told him, you need to show your STRUCTURED thought process. Seniors speak in bullet points first, then details after.

âœ… So he switched it to, "Sure. When I'm making impact on the team, I like to think about 3 things--opportunity, effort, and risk. Each quarter, we map projects on these axes and one of the projects I proposed had high opportunity and medium effort/risk. Let me tell you more about that one, why I worked on it, and how I drove it forward..."

Once he switched to this, his interviewer's eyes started lighting up early on in his answer. He finally figured it out. Then, the offers followed.

So why is the second one better?
1. It shows you don't just jump into solutions.
2. It shows your decision criteria for action. You won't work on unimpactful work.
3. It gives your interviewer an overview first, almost like an "agenda" at the start of a presentation. They know what to expect.

Before you answer, take a step back, share your thought process, and show your structured thinking. Don't just dive in and start going off on stories.

--
Recently when working with Torsten Walbaum (ex-Rippling/Uber/Meta Director), I learned there was a framework this relates to called MECE--mutually exclusive, collectively exhaustive. When it gets applied, it looks a lot like the example my friend used to get his senior offers.

In today's High Growth Engineer post, Torsten shows you how to use it for 5 use cases as an engineer--interviews, investigations, debugging, explaining a system, and when proposing ideas.

Join 80k+ engineers and check it out here: https://lnkd.in/e-MBdkjg

author: Torsten Walbaum
full_text:
This framework I never knew I needed got me compliments on my communication within a week.

It's called MECE.

Huh? mice? No. MECE ğŸ˜‚. It stands for "Mutually Exclusive, Collectively Exhaustive." It forces your communication to be structured.

Let's take an incident investigation as an example. Many times, engineers are dropping messages in the channel like throwing darts.

âŒ Before: "It could be the landing page. No, that's not it. Maybe seasonality? Nope, that's not it either... anyone have other ideas?"

âœ… After: "If signups are down, it's either actually down or it's a false positive. If it's a false positive, we can check for seasonality or a data issue. If it's an actual drop, it could be that it's iOS only, android only, or both. Let's narrow it down."

MECE tells you to come up with all the mutually exclusive and many options as possible upfront, then narrow down and cross out. 

This has a few benefits:
1. You can literally SEE the structure via a tree this gives your communication and thinking
2. Once you see it, you can delegate each of those to others working on the issue
3. Finally, you can cross out each item on the tree as you go, and give accurate estimates to leaders of when it'll be resolved. No more, "we're not sure when it'll be fixed. It's too ambiguous." 

To apply it yourself, before your next message, think about how you can communicate using a "tree structure" like the one on the right. Avoid windy roads and darts.

Have you heard of MECE before and where else do you think you can use it?

--
Tomorrow, I'll share 4 more use cases you can use this to level up your communication, thinking, and problem-solving. We have a special guest post from Torsten Walbaum (ex-Rippling, Uber, Google) on High Growth Engineer.

To not miss it, hit the link next to my profile picture above!

author: Torsten Walbaum
full_text:
Deep Research mode is like having a junior McKinsey analyst on demand. It easily saves me 10+ hours per week. Yet it's one of the most underused AI functions that exists today. Here's how to use it for GTM â¤µï¸ 

(Huge shoutout to Torsten Walbaum from Operator's Handbook for the epic deep dive!)

1. Pick the right Deep Research tool

ChatGPT is the best general-purpose tool (for now) w/ the recent release of GPT-5 (no more model switching) and Agent Mode (ability to properly interact with websites).

Gemini is a great fallback option w/ more generous usage limits. Perplexity works well, too, and has more granular source controls.

2. Be aware of the limitations -- and build workarounds into your prompts

ChatGPT, for example, often shows bad judgment w/ picking sources. Point it to the highest quality *kinds* of sources & always ask it to provide in-text citations.

Context matters to get customized insights. Make sure to provide all the context that a human team member would need as well. 

And always ask for a research plan before getting started (Gemini does this by default) & specify an easy-to-digest report format.

3. Find a practical use case that delivers immediate value

Five ideas to get you started:
 - Step-by-step guide for large in-house projects like figuring out how to build (or re-build) marketing attribution
 - Researching competitors' ads strategies
 - Conducting an audit of your homepage or landing pages
 - Analyzing competitors' product features
 - Market assessment for international expansion

---

Get the Deep Research prompts, sample outputs & more advice in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter: https://lnkd.in/e7AUitbh

Hope you find this useful ğŸ™

#ai #deepreserach #chatgpt

author: Tuomas Artman
full_text:

author: Vic Vijayakumar
full_text:
The more senior of a developer you are, the less a company cares during the interview process whether you know their tech stack and the programming language they use.

Good recruiters and interviewers know that senior programmers can translate their experience from one language/stack to another with ease.

This rule goes out the window for startups that havenâ€™t figured out hiring yet, or don't have mature onboarding practices.

At those companies youâ€™ll get questions like â€œwhat is your favorite Python 3.10 feature?â€ and youâ€™ll be told that you have to use only their preferred language in the interview.

author: Vic Vijayakumar
full_text:
I recently interviewed at a few different places. At the end of each interview, the interviewer usually asks: â€œdo you have any questions for me?â€

Donâ€™t waste this opportunity with questions that donâ€™t matter, or that you can ask your recruiter.

Here are some questions I like to help me understand team health & company culture:

- How much vacation have you taken this year?
- What is the process when an incident happens on production? While youâ€™re asleep?
- How do you know what to work on next?
- If you learn something really cool, how do you share that with the other engineers?
- What is something youâ€™d change about the company?
- What would cause you to leave the company?
- How messy is engineering? Do you feel empowered to fix the mess?
- Do you deploy code on Fridays?
- What is the managerâ€™s leadership style?
- Are you working on a promotion? How do you stay on track?
- What are some fun facts about your teammates?

You likely wonâ€™t have time for every one of these, so pick and choose what feels right in the moment, and what you need most to know.

Best of luck in your interviews! â¤ï¸

Now... I'm proud to announce they've migrated to Pylon from Zendesk.

HackerRank serves thousands of companies and millions of developers who need technical support, and Zendesk wasn't cutting it.

They did a full migration, which included...
â†’ 140K+ contacts
â†’ 136K+ tickets
â†’ 129 users working out of Pylon
â†’ 400+ knowledge base articles 

The migration was completed with no disruption to their customers.


-- Why they migrated --

ğ—¥ğ—²ğ—½ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´: V wasn't happy with Zendesk reporting. It was hard to create charts and calculate metrics she wanted. Getting numbers was always a pain. Now with Pylon, she has a strong set of default dashboards to work with and creating custom charts is quick and easy.

ğ—ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜„ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—±ğ—´ğ—² ğ— ğ—®ğ—»ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜: Creating and maintaining knowledge content is much easier with Pylon. While Zendesk requires manual work to identify knowledge gaps and write content, Pylon does it for you. The team can now identify knowledge gaps with AI, draft articles based on previous responses, generate drafts into pre-made templates, check for similar articles, and translate articles to multiple languages. This saves the team an incredible amount of time.

author: Vincent Pierri
full_text:
How to nail your next big talk ğŸ‘‡

I used to be terrified of public speaking. But I pushed through the nerves (with an assist from Big Pharma) & am absolutely glad I did.

If you're even a little bit like me, you'll want to bookmark this post from Vincent Pierri. He's personally delivered 300+ unique talks over the last 5 years. Now he's sharing his proven framework for a better 30 min keynote.

Read the full story in Growth Unhinged here: https://lnkd.in/eydNVYxG

The framework in four steps:

1ï¸âƒ£ Nail the intro (5 minutes)

Every great talk begins with tension.

Think of your intro as the â€œhook.â€ Itâ€™s where you earn the right to keep peopleâ€™s attention. 

If you lose the first five minutes, youâ€™ll spend the next twenty-five trying to win them back.

2ï¸âƒ£ Build trust (3 minutes)

Trust-building is where you prove youâ€™ve walked the path. And your title isn't enough to get the audience on your side.

Three ways to do it:
 - Experience.Â A quick story of failure, experiment, or success.
 - Research.Â Credible data, case studies, or benchmarks.
 - Relatability.Â A short personal story that shows youâ€™ve been in their shoes.

3ï¸âƒ£ Deliver three main points (3 Ã— 6 minutes)

Three points is the sweet spot. Enough to feel substantial. Not so much that people forget them by lunch.

Each point follows the same mini-framework:
 - One-Liner (1 min)
 - Analogy (2 min)
 - Examples (3 min)

4ï¸âƒ£ Close strong (4 minutes)

Too many talks fizzle at the end. 

Instead, close with a one-two punch:
 - Final Story (2 min)
 - Call to Action (2 min)

---

I can't wait to try out this framework for my next talk. Hope you find it as useful as I did ğŸ™ 

#publicspeaking #keynote
