author: Vojsava (Sava) Livadhi
full_text:
A Mother's Plea: Seeking AlphaFold Experts for a Rare Cancer Mission

This is the most important post I'll ever write. My son is turning 21 tomorrow, August 23rd. For the last 2.5 years, he has been bravely battling Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS), a rare and under-researched cancer.

ASPS is driven by a specific gene fusion protein (ASPSCR1-TFE3). This protein is the engine of his cancer, yet we lack a detailed understanding of its structure. This is where we see a path for hope, and where I desperately need your help.

We are searching for brilliant mindsâ€”individuals, researchers, or institutionsâ€”with expertise in using AlphaFold to create a 3D model of this specific fusion protein. Creating this structural "blueprint" is not just an academic exercise; it's a critical step that could allow us to identify this protein's vulnerabilities. The ultimate goal is to find existing, approved drugs that could be repurposed to "fit" and disable this engine, opening up new, out-of-the-box treatment strategies.

The power of the LinkedIn community is immense. A simple share could connect this plea to the one person or lab in the world that can help us move the needle in the fight against this rare disease.

My birthday wish for my son is hope, powered by action. Please, not only share this post but also ask your network to share it. You never know whose screen it might cross.

Thank you for your time and support.

#ASPS #AlveolarSoftPartSarcoma #RareCancer #CancerResearch #AlphaFold #DrugRepurposing #Sarcoma #Bioinformatics #ComputationalBiology #StructuralBiology #MedicalResearch #GoogleDeepMind #IsomorphicLab #GoogleAICoScientist
Please message me for any additional information vlivadhi@yahoo.com

full_text:
Brothers. Since Day One.
Some friendships fade. Some friendships stretch across decades, deployments, life, loss, and every version of who weâ€™ve become.

Staff Sergeant Jason Richards, USMC

We grew up together. We got in trouble together. We figured life out the hard way. And they put on the uniform and carried a weight most people will never understand.

Wendy Harris (can you make sure they both see this...going to be like hearding cats. Godspeed). 
First memory of Jed: 3 years old, in a diaper, running laps around a basketball goal like it was the Indy 500.
Not much has changed â€” still too small to play and still wearing diapers, just a different brand (according to him).

Jason â€” the quiet one until the moment it mattered. The one who runs toward the fire when everyone else steps back. Never had to say much â€” because he showed up.

I didnâ€™t serve. They did.

But I learned from them â€” loyalty, accountability, and doing hard things without needing applause for it.

Now your turn.

Who in the service are you personally thankful for?
Before anyone gets dramatic:
Yes â€” we honor all veterans and active service members.

But today is about the individuals who shaped your life.
Drop a name. Tell a story. Let them be seen while theyâ€™re still here to hear it.

Boomband need to borrow a speaker today. I'll give it back, someday. Maybe. Probably not.

author: Wendy Vang
full_text:
Pylon's ğ—ºğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜ ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ğ—²ğ—± ğ—³ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—² is our Analytics.

That ends today. 

We've completely rebuilt our Analytics from scratch.

Here's what we tried, what we screwed up, and what's coming.


ğ—©ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğŸ­, The Basics (Nov 2023)

Our first attempt at analytics was quite loved by customers.

At the time our customers were mostly small startups with simple needs. We built an out-of-the-box set of dashboards that covered the common use cases of support analytics (SLA-tracking, CSAT, TTFR, TTR, basic filtering...).

As we moved upmarket...
1/ Everyone was requesting custom metrics
2/ Queries were becoming inefficient and slow

We needed an upgrade.


ğ—©ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğŸ®, Advanced Reporting (June 2024)

We knew custom reporting was going to be blackhole of work that long-term led to fully customer-customizable dashboards. 

We had four choices:Â 
1/ Do nothing for now
2/ Do custom work per customerÂ 
3/ Build full custom reporting in-houseÂ 
4/ Use an embeddable analytics vendor

At the time Pylon was under 10 people total and we had no capacity to do the frontend work so we chose Option 4 (use a vendor). This was the first time we chose to not build a core feature like this in-house as we ultimately want full control of the end-user experience.

We built out the new reporting with the chosen vendor over ~3 weeks.

On the surface the new reporting looked really good (not visually, but in terms of functionality). You could add custom charts of any type, create custom formulas, label the Y and X axis, and effectively build most of what you would want. It was really great for demos.

But in practice it was incredibly hard to use, lacked core capabilities (like the ability to filter off of dynamic custom fields), and visually looked not stylized to the rest of the product.

We started to discover some of these issues during the implementation, but it still felt like there was more upside than downside so we released it.

Feedback was not great but we hoped our vendor would fix changes quickly. Unfortunately they weren't fast enough and we lost confidence that they would be a good long-term solution.

As a stop-gap we also built out a data warehouse integration so customers could export their data back to Snowflake or BigQuery to use with their own BI tools.

Finally, a few months ago the vendor told us they were being acquired. That was the final straw. We needed to move off ASAP.


ğ—©ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğŸ¯, New Reporting (Today)

Today's release is back to being built entirely in-house. It's been rolled out in beta to all customers with an option to flip back to old analytics until we plug some custom reporting gaps.

This time we have the capacity to do it right between Wendy (prev product design at Amplitude), Matt, and Tom.

--
*Reached the LinkedIn character limit

author: Wes Kao
full_text:
After landing a $350k offer in big tech, my friend quoted this interview tip as what helped him the most in landing the job.

Don't answer the question. Answer the question BEHIND the question.

Here's an example:

â€¢ Interviewer asks... "Tell me about your biggest failure"
â€¢ You respond by telling them about a big project that didn't ship on time and everyone moved on. That feels like a failure, right?

The problem is, the question behind the question was, "How well do you learn from your big failures?" So you can still tell the story about your biggest failure, but you need to touch on what you learned from it! Every answer you give uncovers more to the interviewer about how you are to work with (the pie below).

Here are some more examples:
â€¢ Biggest disagreement -> Can you work with others? (not a chance to brag about swapping teams due to arguments)
â€¢ A project you are proud of -> How large is your scope and do you approach projects methodically?
â€¢ A time when you missed a deadline -> Do you let others know ahead of time when your estimate is off? How do you approach your relationship with stakeholders?

Each question has something underlying the interviewer is trying to get at.

Figure out what it is. Answer THAT question and you'll see the offers start coming in.

--
The thing is, this framework isn't just useful for interviews. You can use it when you're fielding questions during a presentation, or when you're dealing with hard questions from your manager on why something hasn't shipped.

To see how AND learn 4 other top communication frameworks like this one, click the link next to my profile picture.

Tomorrow's High Growth Engineer issue will feature some of Wes Kao's most valuable frameworks engineers can use every day.

author: Wes Kao
full_text:
Delegation is hard. Especially if you don't have formal authority. But with this framework, I broke through my "delegation imposter syndrome" in 1 week.

It's called CEDAF, and it does a few key things:
1. It gives you a way to influence without authority through excitement
2. It ensures the other person does the task how you envision (or both agree to)
3. It prevents the project from going sideways once it begins

So here's the 5-step CEDAF process with examples:
1. Comprehension
Explain it in a way that's easy to understand. Start by explaining the high-level steps, then dig into each one individually where they need more details.

2. Excitement
Get the person excited by sharing what's in it for them. 

For example, "This will be great for your visibility" or "<x> contributes to <y big initiative> in a positive way."

3. Derisk
Think to some of the things they might get blocked by early on, and address those upfront. You can also ask them what they see as risks.

Ask, "What risks do you see?" and "How are you considering approaching it?"

4. Align / Accountability
Ensure they feel it's doable and accept the challenge.

Ask, "Do you feel like this is doable?" or "Do you feel like you have a clear picture of what â€˜doneâ€™ looks like?"

5. Feedback loop
Follow up in the earliest, non-micromanagey feedback loop that makes sense to ensure everything is going as you discussed. Adjust based on that initial check-in.

Since learning CEDAF, I managed to ship 3+ projects through others. Big kudos to Wes Kao for initially creating and sharing it. 

--
Today's High Growth Engineer newsletter features 5 frameworks like this that help you master communication and influence as an engineer. The frameworks all come from Wes Kao, 2-time founder and executive.

You don't want to miss this one! Check it out here: https://lnkd.in/ejHvmgiN

author: Will Mannon
full_text:
Yesterday we ran our first Act Two pre-program workshop. Louie Bacaj led a private vibe coding workshop co-organized by Abhilasha Krishnan for the SHEmantra community. 

Louie walked the attendees through an eight-step process to build a working habit tracker app using Claude Code. Abhilasha got hers working, asked the AI to make it â€œfancierâ€ (which it did â€“ adding colors, streaks, quotes, and sound effects), and then deployed it live to the internet using CloudFlare. 

Weâ€™ll be running two public-facing â€œApp in an Hourâ€ workshops next week â€“ Tuesday (7pm ET) and Thursday (1pm ET). Learn more + register using the links in the first comment. 

If you've been wanting to try out vibe coding for yourself, but haven't been sure where to start, these sessions are built for you.

author: Yaakov Carno
full_text:
We're in a new UX era for software: the era of the prompt bar. That doesn't mean you can just add a prompt bar & move on. What 40+ of the best AI-native companies are doing:

I enlisted Yaakov Carno to map out AI prompt journeys across products like Canva, Notion, Vercel, Lovable, Airtable (& lesser known AI companies). He traced every step from homepage to first value. 

The 7 most interesting observations â¤µï¸

1. Consider offering multiple entry points: the prompt bar OR a visual UX. 

Gamma and Wix are two ğŸ”¥ examples. Gamma even has 3 options.

2. Increase relevance with a "hidden" step between the prompt bar & output. 

Lovable, for example, has a series of onboarding questions to collect more context.

3. Donâ€™t just tell users they can â€œgenerate anything.â€ Show them specific, meaningful examples that connect to their job-to-be-done. 

Canva, for instance, has a visual use case selector w/ a category & sub-category.

4. Use the prompt bar to educate users about what kind of tasks your product supports. 

Zapier there are sample prompts for lead management, customer support, marketing & growth, and project mgmt.

5. Distinguish whether the AI is a copilot or autopilot. 

Notion nails this with a mix of placeholder text, surrounding CTAs, and examples that clearly convey what you can do and why.

6. Integrate context, data, and sources at the beginning.

bolt.new has a new minimalistic design that focuses only on importing from Figma and GitHub. Constraints increase the likelihood of relevant, valuable outputs.

7. Add a fun factor to make the experience feel different & maybe a bit magical.

Playfulness can lower hesitation.Â RiffÂ andÂ LeapÂ use â€œShuffleâ€ or â€œSurprise meâ€ icons to encourage exploration.

---

Read the full deep dive in today's Growth Unhinged newsletter here: https://lnkd.in/ecJ8TRFJ

Then chime in: Do you have a favorite AI prompt journey? And what new tools are folks using to build & optimize these new UX experiences?

Hope you find this useful ğŸ™

#ux #ai #genai #product

author: Yangshun Tay
full_text:
One of the biggest regrets in my career was not being aware of engineering career levels early enough.

Learn from my mistake, I don't want the same to happen to you.

Understanding what is expected of each engineering level would have helped me make better decisions earlier in my career.

I put together this mega engineering levels cheatsheet from junior levels up to staff level. 

If you are an engineer, go through it and see if you are due for a promotion, or identify gaps and work towards the next level.

If you are a student, get a sense of what is expected of you as you progress in your career.

Note: These are general guidelines for the standard tech company, using Meta and Google as reference. There can and will be deviations/exceptions depending on company culture and priorities (e.g. some high level engineers still write a lot of code).

#softwareengineering #career #faang #meta #google
__________

I post regularly about software engineering, front end, memes, and more. 
Follow me Yangshun Tay and my company GreatFrontEnd

author: Yoona Kim
full_text:
I should not be sharing this.

But I built a Tone-of-Voice GPT for Pylonâ€”and it actually works.

For context, up until a couple months ago all of Pylon's content had been written by me.

Then a couple of months ago our new Product Marketer Yoona joined.

Since then, I've learned I am very very picky when it comes to Pylon's "voice".

So as we're interviewing candidates for new marketing roles and asking them to write, I'm realizing it's near impossible to describe exactly what I'm looking for. 

So as I was trying to describe what I was looking for in a Google Doc to a candidate, I decided to prompt engineer my way out of this.

I went into ChatGPT (using o3) and started describing what I wanted.

"""
Make a "tone of voice" guide for Pylon that can be fed to a OpenAI GPT prompt that my team can use to edit their writing samples to conform to the tone of voice for all of our copy.

The brand tone is:
- Concise
...[hidden]

The brand tone is NOT:
- "Sales-y"
...[hidden]

Industry specific:
- If we reference customer support or service, never say "customer service" always say "customer support"
...[hidden]

For LinkedIn in particular:
- First line should always be under 140 characters so that it does not wrap when viewed on mobile
...[hidden]

For Emails:
- Keep the signature very short
...[hidden]

Samples of existing Emails:
...[redacted]

Samples of existing posts:
...[redacted]
"""

And it works like magic ğŸª„

Want to see what the finalized prompt looks like?

Comment "PYLON CUSTOMER SUPPORT" and your email and I'll shoot it over to you!


--

Don't know what Pylon is?

We're the first customer support platform built for B2B companies. 

It combines reactive customer work (tickets) and proactive (account management).

It's like if Zendesk and Gainsight had a baby.

More at usepylon[dot]com

author: Yoona Kim
full_text:
NEW ROLE: MARKETING GENERALIST 

Work with Yoona and me to create a content machine and become our 2nd marketer!

Projects you'd take over:
- Daily product updates 5x/week on LinkedIn & X
- Industry spotlights posts
- Customer newsletter
- Assist with bigger product launches and videos
- ...and much more!

There are at least two personas that we think would excel in this role. 

First, the "Early Career Marketer" persona. You have 1-2 years of experience doing marketing at a B2B startup. You've seen the different types of marketing work that need to get done at B2B startups and are ready to own many of them yourself. 

Second, the "You Want To Get Into Tech" persona. You may have just graduated with a non-standard tech major (history, english, ...) OR you work outside of tech but are trying to make your way into an AI startup.


We're screening for the following qualities:

1/ You're organized (you'll own a content calendar and have to balance multiple projects at once)
2/ You're a clear, concise writer and able to write in a startup-friendly and conversational tone
3/ Excited to work in-person 5x / week in our SF office. You should be the type of person who finds this fun
4/ You're scrappy and not afraid of long days (see Yoona in the office at 9:15pm)

Apply here: 
https://lnkd.in/g3XJG6JU

- 33 people fully in-person in SF
- raised $20M (a16z, General Catalyst, Y Combinator)
- massive market (displacing Salesforce and Zendesk) 
- free breakfast, lunch, and dinner

author: Zach Wilson
full_text:
If you're a software engineer looking to grow, here are 13 resources to get your weekly dose of wisdom:

1) Data Engineering Newsletter by Zach Wilson: https://lnkd.in/ejC7bgVK. Personal stories from his experience at Meta, Netflix, and Airbnb all the way to data deep-dives. Zach does it all.

2) Coding Challenges by John Crickett: https://lnkd.in/et9b6VDQ. Level up by building fully functional applications

3) Leading Developers by Anton Zaides: https://lnkd.in/dNbn8y9W. Reflections, stories, and lessons on being a better engineering leader from a Director of Engineering

4) Engineering Leadership by Gregor Ojstersek: https://lnkd.in/eaYUVCSc. Learn how to become a better engineering leader

5) Wes Kao's Newsletter by Wes Kao: https://lnkd.in/ej48BXXZ. Actionable, insightful frameworks and advice on many soft skill topics--managing up, giving feedback, etc.

6) Developing Dev by Ryan Peterman: https://lnkd.in/e4JxSQg5. Learn how to level up from a Staff Software Engineer at Instagram

7) The Software Engineer Weekly by Kevin Naughton: https://lnkd.in/eqEVNG5W. Tips from a Google SWE on career growth, productivity, mental and physical health

8) Leadership Letters by Akash Mukherjee: https://lnkd.in/eeEzxjzK. Akash is a Staff Engineer at Apple. He gets into his wealth of personal stories and always shared actionable takeaways

9) The Caring Techie by Irina Stanescu: https://lnkd.in/e5qybckA. Build soft skills from an experienced IC, manager, and tech lead. She's done it all

10) The Operator's Handbook by Torsten Walbaum: https://lnkd.in/etNH6juK. Some of the most in-depth how-to guides on being a better operator.

11) The Hustling Engineer by Hemant Pandey: https://lnkd.in/e3kzc8B6. Concise, actionable takeaways on every article for leveling up as an engineer from a Senior Engineer at Meta

12) Strategize your Career by Francisco Manuel Soto RamÃ­rez: https://lnkd.in/eCnJv76m. His advice is actionable, concise, and clear. He shares everything he uses himself too

13) The T-Shaped Dev - by Petar Ivanov: https://lnkd.in/eEaS_eMy. Petar shares approachable intros to technical topics and helps you be more productive

Tell me which one is your favorite in the comments! Also, feel free to share any I missed since there are so many good ones.

author: brendan short
full_text:
ICYMI: Automation doesnâ€™t need to mean more spray-and-pray. Here are my favorite automated GTM plays youâ€™re not running â¤µï¸

Signal-based plays
1. Warm outbound campaign targeting recent (de-anonymized) website visitors
2. Competitor displacement campaign w/ tech stack signals
3. Customers' competitor outbound campaign referencing a use case you believe is relevant to the industry
4. 'Look-a-like' outbound campaign targeting similar companies to recent closed-won customers
5. â€˜Look-a-likeâ€™ LinkedIn ad campaign targeting the same companies & reinforcing the outbound message
6. Outbound campaign targeting former bosses of recent job switchers
7. Outbound campaign targeting companies that have recently posted relevant jobs
8. Geo-specific outbound campaign referencing an upcoming/recent event

Warm outbound plays
9. Prospect re-engagement campaign w/ past prospects who've changed companies
10. Prospect re-engagement campaign w/ closed-lost deals from 9 months ago (referencing what was discussed on the last call)
11. Champion outreach campaign w/ past champions who've changed companies
12. ICP-fit warm intro campaign w/ the prior companies of existing champions
13. ICP-fit warm intro campaign w/ mutual investors
14. 'Alumni' outbound campaign w/ the prior employees of new flagship customers

Personalization plays
15. Prospect research brief ahead of 1st call pulling in recent events and/or competitive intel
16. Account-specific landing pages with personalized copy
17. Outbound campaign including a "1:1 video" (automated) made specifically for that prospect

Social plays
18. LinkedIn connection request campaign referencing past posts
19. Influencer/creator list build based on LinkedIn activity of existing users

Product-led plays
20. Product-led outbound campaign targeting an exec buyer when there are multiple accounts from the same domain (roll-up play)
21. Product-led sales campaign reaching out to non-users within an account that has 1+ existing existing user
22. Product-led sales campaign targeting Admins when a free account reaches an â€˜aha momentâ€™ in the product
23. Product-led sales campaign targeting Admins when a free account visits a high-intent website page (integrations, enterprise landing page, pricing page)

Expansion plays
24. Expansion campaign leveraging product usage data indicating the account is approaching limits (usage, seats, credits)
25. Expansion campaign offering product assistance when an account begins a free trial of an upsell package

The future of automated GTM: 
 - the highly relevant, precise targeting of ABX
 - the efficiency gains from AI & web-scraping
 - the ability to get real-life data from GTM experiments

Shoutout to Brendan Short for the ğŸ”¥ collab. Don't miss the full post here: https://lnkd.in/e2q2B3sn

PS, Growth Unhinged is off this week (OOO ğŸ˜´). Back next Wednesday at 6:50am!

#ai #gtm #gtmengineering

author: âš¡ Roland Ligtenberg
full_text:
You might not have heard of Housecall Pro, but it's a vSaaS juggernaut doing hundreds of millions in ARR. A surprising way they got there:

Cold calling, even when the product started at only $4/mo ğŸ¤¯. The math on that is hurting my brain.

âš¡ Roland Ligtenberg, co-founder & SVP of Growth, just joined the Mostly Growth podcast & shared Housecall Pro's unconventional growth journey. 

My biggest learnings:

1. Start w/ where your customers get their business. In the trades, that's still over the phone. 

Housecall Pro cold called prospects even when their product was $4/mo. It's a core part of the GTM today even though they've got a free trial/PLG offer and a $59/mo. price point.

Why it works: (a) their prospects still answer the phone, (b) Housecall Pro solves a big problem for them, (c) they've been able to scale cold calling through outsourcing, & (d) their product is sticky once it's bought.

2. Find the hyper-specific jargon for your sub-verticals & use it in your outreach.

Housecall Pro sells into 55 (!) different sub-verticals (plumbers, electrical, etc.). Each could have it's own vertical software. 

When they talk about fittings & specs, plumbers see that this is software purpose-built for them. They're using AI to help with hyper-specific personalization & seeing the results in conversion data. 

3. Organic word-of-mouth is a huge acquisition channel. But you don't need to do referral links/credits to track and grow WoM.

A lot of WoM growth shows up as direct traffic to the website. It's hard to see what moves it. Housecall Pro regularly checks in w/ customers and directly asks "have you recommended us to any of your friends?" This isn't NPS, this is actual referrals. 

Roland measures this data & tracks it month-over-month & quarter-over-quarter. This unlocks the ability to run growth experiments like sending pros Yeti mugs/coolers, running sweepstakes, or paying for beer at local meetups.

4. The magic of vSaaS is in the layer-cake strategy. But the first layer needs to be fully baked before adding more.

Housecall Pro started w/ scheduling & payments. That's still their hero offering even though they have 12+ products incl. payroll, FinTech, and 24/7 call answering. The key is to figure out who the prospect is when they come to the front door, that way Housecall Pro can take them to the right room.

---

The full episode is out now on YouTube, Apple & Spotify. And catch the video to see Roland's most unique growth tactic as Buddy the Elf ğŸ˜‚

ğŸ“º Watch on YouTube: https://lnkd.in/eAHXrEAz

ğŸ§ Listen on Apple Podcasts: https://lnkd.in/eb8G2is2

ğŸ§ Listen on Spotify: https://lnkd.in/eb6F-XRT

#gtm #outbound #verticalsaas #startup

author: ğŸ” Umberto Nicoletti
full_text:
How can a power adapter set off a 25-year career in tech?! ğŸ”Œ

Today we published an incredible guest article from my friend Umberto Nicoletti, Director of Product & Engineering at Proemion, who explored lessons learned throughout his journey in tech.

He talks about Open Source, self-doubt, coaching, communities, and how a forgotten power adapter at a conference in Germany ended up shaping his entire career!

Here are some of the things I learned from Umberto:

ğŸ¯ ğ—™ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—± ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—œğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—®ğ—¶ â€” the best careers sit at the intersection of what you love, what you're good at, what the world needs, and what you can get paid for. When you're aligned with all four, everything becomes easier.

ğŸ² ğ—–ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ˜ğ—² ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—¹ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ—¸ ğ˜€ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—³ğ—®ğ—°ğ—² ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—® â€” luck plays a huge role in careers, but it can be cultivated. Show up, contribute to communities, and stay in touch with interesting people.

ğŸ§° ğ—•ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—± ğ—²ğ˜…ğ—½ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ—² ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—±ğ˜€ â€” being a generalist pays off. The ability to move across domains creates versatility that unlocks unexpected career paths.

ğŸ”­ ğ—£ğ—¹ğ—®ğ˜† ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—´ğ—®ğ—ºğ—² â€” treat every interaction as part of an infinite game. When you're playing for the long term, occasional setbacks become just wrinkles in a larger journey.

ğŸª´ ğ—šğ—²ğ˜ ğ—µğ—²ğ—¹ğ—½ â€” it's not lonely at the top unless you choose it to be. Coaching, communities, and peers are invaluable for fighting impostor syndrome and growing as a leader. Don't wait to join the conversation.

My favorite quote from the piece: "Careers are very much by chance, but you always want to have a clear roadmap of what you wanna do" â€” Lisa Su, CEO of AMD
